questions.text: 1. A 60-year-old woman comes with chronic vulval itching and pain. On examination, there is a vulval lesion suspicious of vulval cancer. Which of the following lymph node/s should be considered for a sentinel node biopsy to look for the metastatic spread?
questions.solution:
The first lymph node/s the vulval malignancy spreads to are the superficial inguinal lymph nodes.

The sentinel lymph node, which is the first node in a regional lymphatic basin that receives lymph flow from the primary tumour, is often used to assess the presence or absence of metastatic lesions in the lymph nodes.

The most common type of spread in vulval cancer is lymphatic. A most important prognostic factor is lymph node status.

First lymph node involved the superficial inguinal lymph node > deep inguinal lymph node > (Gland of Cloquet), femoral group of lymph nodes to external iliac glands, obturator and common iliac nodes in the advanced stages.

The sentinel lymph node biopsy helps evaluate the spread of vulval cancer.

Pearl PM1426: Treatment Modality in Vulval Cancer

Stage Treatment
1A
  •  Radical wide local excision
     
1B
  • Partial vulvectomy + ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection
II
  • Tumor 2-4cm – total vulvectomy + B/L groin lymph node dissection
  • Tumor >4cm or poorly differentiated – radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
 
III
  • Megavoltage radiotherapy
  • Local surgical excision - Radical vulvectomy + B/L lymphadenectomy + pelvic lymph node dissection
  • Local recurrence – chemotherapy
 
IV
  • Chemotherapy or radiotherapy
  • Local excision on residual tumor
  • ipsilateral inguinofemoral lymph node + ve – contralateral node removed
  • Femoral lymph node +ve – pelvic lymph node removed

questions.text: 2. An unvaccinated child is given an intradermal injection of diluted diphtheria toxin into his left forearm and is examined for any erythema/induration. Which of the following tests shares a similar immunological basis to this test?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is representative of the Schick test, which is used to test the susceptibility of a person to diphtheria. The Schick test is a type of neutralisation reaction. Among the given options, Nagler’s reaction is the only neutralisation test.

Neutralisation test is a type of antigen-antibody test wherein the reaction between viruses/toxins with their corresponding neutralising antibodies is visualised.

Examples of neutralisation tests include-

* Virus neutralisation tests: Neutralisation of viruses by antibodies.

* Plaque inhibition test for neutralisation of bacteriophages

* Toxin neutralisation tests: Bacterial exotoxins by antibodies

* Nagler reaction: done for the detection of alpha toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens(Option A)

* Schick test: Neutralisation of diphtheria toxin by circulating antitoxin

* Anti-streptolysin O test: Neutralisation of streptococcal O hemolysin produced by beta-hemolytic streptococci.



Other options:

Option B: Wassermann test is an example of a complement fixation test. It is a nonspecific test for the diagnosis of syphilis. An antigen combines with its (specific) antibody in the presence of complement, and the antigen-antibody complex adsorbs the complement. This reaction is not visible and requires the use of an indicator (sheep erythrocytes and the specific anti-erythrocyte antibody).



Option C: VDRL test is a type of precipitation test (slide flocculation test) used for the diagnosis of syphilis. In the precipitation test, a soluble antigen binds with its antibody and forms an insoluble antigen-antibody complex. If instead of forming precipitates, the complex remains suspended in the form of floccules, it is called flocculation. 

Option D: Widal test is a type of tube agglutination test used in the diagnosis of typhoid. Here, a particulate antigen binds with its antibody and forms a clump.

Pearl PM2187: Serological tests in microbiology

Precipitation test:

* Ascoli's thermoprecipitin test: Anthrax

* Streptococci grouping: Lancefield technique

* VDRL test for syphilis (slide flocculation test)

* Kahn test for syphilis (tube flocculation test)

* Elek gel precipitation test for C.diphtheria

Agglutination test:

* Widal test- typhoid

* Weil- Felix reaction- Typhus fever

* Streptococcus MG agglutination test- Mycoplasma pneumoniae

* Paul Bunnel test- Infectious mononucleiosis

* Coombs test

* Rose Waaler test- Rheumatoid arthritis

* Microscopic Agglutination test- Leptospirosis

* Anti streptolysin O test

Complement fixation test:

* Wasserman reaction(syphilis)

* Treponema pallidum immobilization test

Neutralization test:

* Schik test for diptheria

* Anti streptolysin O test

* Nagler's reaction (clostridium perfringens)

questions.text: 3. During couples therapy, the wife complains about the husband's behaviour during intercourse. The husband says that he does not obtain pleasure unless he is yelled at and beaten. Which of the following paraphilias does the husband suffer from?
questions.solution:
The person in question is sexually aroused by being humiliated and injured by the sexual partner, which is highly suggestive of sexual masochism.

Paraphilias or perversions are sexual stimuli or acts that are deviations from normal sexual behaviours but are necessary for some people to experience arousal and orgasm.

Sexual arousal and pleasure stemming from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer is a paraphilia known as sexual masochism. This is a disorder that is widely seen in men rather than women. Moral masochism involves a need to suffer but is not accompanied by sexual fantasies. 

Another specific diagnosis that falls under masochism is autoerotic asphyxiation/asphyxiophilia. This is the act of achieving or heightening sexual arousal as a result of constriction of the airway or restriction of breathing.

Other options :

Option A: Frotteurism is when a person receives sexual gratification by touching or rubbing their genitalia against a non-consenting person. This behaviour often occurs in busy and crowded places like buses. It is predominantly described in men.

Option C: When the sexual focus is on a particular object which is associated with the human body (a shoe, for example), the paraphilia is known as fetishism. This is found mostly in men. The object of desire usually plays a part during masturbation or sexual intercourse.

Option D: Sexual arousal obtained from the physical or psychological suffering of another person is known as sexual sadism. It is commonly seen in males with the onset before the age of 18. Hereditary predisposition and a history of sexual abuse may be contributory factors to developing sexual sadism.

Other important paraphilic disorders include:

*  Exhibitionism - Urge to expose genitals to a stranger or unsuspecting person.

* Pedophilia - Recurrent intense sexual urges or arousal by children less than 13 years of age over a period of at least 6 months.

* Voyeurism (scopophilia)- Urge to watch an unsuspecting person naked or in sexual activity.

* Transvestism - Fantasies and sexual urges to dress in opposite-gender clothing.

* Telephone and computer scatologia - Obscene phone calls or sending of videos and images to an unsuspecting recipient.

* Necrophilia - Sexual gratification from dead bodies.

* Zoophilia - Urge to engage in sexual activity like intercourse, masturbation, or oral-genital contact with an animal.

* Coprophilia - Sexual pleasure associated with a desire to defecate on the partner, to be defecated on, or to eat faeces (coprophilia).

* Urophilia - Sexual pleasure associated with the desire to urinate on a partner or to be urinated on.

* Hypoxyphilia - The desire to achieve an altered state of consciousness secondary to hypoxia while experiencing orgasm. They may use volatile nitrite or nitrous oxide to produce hypoxia.

questions.text: 4. A young patient who is a known case of glaucoma presented with a sudden onset of decreased vision. Following an ophthalmic examination, a provisional diagnosis of glaukomflecken was made. This condition refers to:

choices.text: Posterior subcapsular opacities secondary to angle closure glaucoma
Anterior subcapsular opacities secondary to angle closure glaucoma
Corneal opacity secondary to open angle glaucoma
Corneal opacity secondary to angle closure glaucoma

questions.solution:
Glaukomflecken refers to anterior subcapsular lenticular opacity secondary to angle-closure glaucoma.

Marked elevation of intraocular pressure in acute congestive angle closure may cause small anterior grey-white subcapsular or capsular opacities to form within the pupillary area. This is called glaukomflecken and indicates focal infarcts of the lens epithelium. This finding is strongly suggestive of a previous episode of acute congestive angle closure.

The images below show glaukomflecken in a patient with angle closure glaucoma.





It is a component of Vogt's triad that is seen after an acute attack of primary angle closure. It includes glaukomflecken, patches of iris atrophy, and a slightly dilated nonreactive pupil.

questions.text: 5. A 40-year-old male presented to the OPD with a history of low-grade fever, cough, and generalised malaise. He recently took a hiking vacation in Chicago. Physical findings are notable for a raised, ulcerated skin lesion. Chest X-ray reveals a mass-like consolidation in the left upper lobe. The causative agent expresses BAD-1 glycoprotein. What are the microscopic findings of the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette points towards a diagnosis of Blastomycosis. It shows broad-based budding yeast under microscopy. 

Blastomycosis (North American Blastomycosis/Gilchrist disease/Chicago disease) refers to a systemic mycosis caused by the dimorphic fungus Blastomyces dermatitidis. It is characterised by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions in the lungs and skin and is acquired by the inhalation of spores. Yeast expresses BAD-1 glycoprotein, which is responsible for virulence and immune response. 

Patients with blastomycosis often present with low-grade fever, cough, and hemoptysis, ulcerated skin lesions, and may have a history of travel to endemic areas of epidemiological distribution. It can mimic TB clinically. 

It has three forms: 

* Pulmonary infection - can be asymptomatic, focal or diffuse consolidation, military lesions, or abscess formation. Pulmonary form often mimics Histoplasmosis and TB.

* Disseminated disease can lead to multiple abscesses and has a high fatality rate.

* Cutaneous disease over the skin of the face. Lesions may be papules, around which secondary nodules develop and coalesce to form elevated ulcerative lesions. 

B. dermatitidis, when cultured at 37°C, shows thick double-walled refractile round yeast cells with a single broad-based bud. At 25°C, filamentous and septate fungal hyphae are present. Localized lesions are effectively managed with itraconazole for 6 months. Invasive or severe cases are treated with amphotericin B.

Other options:

Option A: Cigar-shaped yeast is seen in microscopy of sporotrichosis, a subcutaneous mycosis caused by a thermally dimorphic fungus, Sporothrix schenkii.

Option C: Spherules with endospores are a characteristic finding seen in Coccidioidomycosis, also known as Valley fever or Desert Rheumatism/California fever. It is caused by a thermally dimorphic fungus, Coccidioides immitis. Most patients are asymptomatic and may also present with pneumonia-like pulmonary findings. 

Option D: Narrow-based budding within macrophages is suggestive of histoplasmosis caused by a thermally dimorphic fungus, Histoplasma capsulatum. It can present with similar pulmonary findings, but does not express BAD-1 glycoprotein. On microscopic examination, tiny oval yeast cells with narrow-based budding are seen inside macrophages at 37°C.

Pearl PM2370: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings





1. Histoplasma:

* Mycelial growth showing spherical spores, which are large (8-10 μm size) and thick-walled, with tubercular projections.

* Tiny oval yeast cells (2-4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 



2. Blastomyces: Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 



3. Coccidoides: Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20-80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 



4. Paracoccidioides: Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

Pearl PM0567: Common names of various fungal infections

Disease

Common name

Histoplasmosis

Darling’s disease

Sporotrichosis

Rose-thorn or Rose gardener’s disease

Para-coccidioidomycosis

South American blastomycosis

Coccidioidomycosis

Valley fever or desert rheumatism

Blastomycosis

North American blastomycosis, Gilchrist's disease

questions.text:
6. A 9-year-old child has had a high-grade fever for the past four days. On examination, you also notice conjunctival redness, strawberry tongue, erythematous feet, and cervical lymphadenopathy. The RT-PCR test is positive for COVID-19. Laboratory investigations show ESR - 71mm and CRP - 22 mg/L. The panel done for tropical infections is negative. Which of the following is best suited to treat this patient?

ESR- Erythrocyte sedimentation rate CRP- C-reactive protein

choices.text: IV methylprednisolone, IVIG (Immune globulins, intravenous) and antimicrobials
IV methylprednisolone and IVIG (Immune globulins, intravenous)

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing a child with unremitting fever for>3 days, testing positive for COVID, along with conjunctival redness, strawberry tongue, erythematous feet, and cervical lymphadenopathy, is indicative of Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) with Kawasaki Disease (KD) phenotype, which is treated with IV methylprednisolone and IVIG.

Multi-System Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) is a new syndrome in children characterised by unremitting fever >38ºC and epidemiological linkage with SARS-CoV-2

Diagnostic criteria (WHO) :

* Children and adolescents 0–18 years of age with fever ≥3 days

* And any two of the following:

* Rash or bilateral non-purulent conjunctivitis or mucocutaneous inflammation signs (oral, hands or feet)

* Hypotension or shock

* Features of myocardial dysfunction, pericarditis, valvulitis, or coronary abnormalities (including ECHO findings or elevated Troponin/NT-proBNP)

* Evidence of coagulopathy (PT, PTT, elevated D-dimers)

* Acute gastrointestinal problems (diarrhoea, vomiting, or abdominal pain)

* And elevated markers of inflammation, such as ESR (>40 mm), C-reactive protein (>5 mg/L), or procalcitonin

* And no other obvious microbial cause of inflammation, including bacterial sepsis, staphylococcal or streptococcal shock syndromes

* And evidence of recent COVID-19 infection (RT-PCR, antigen test or serology positive), or likely contact with patients with COVID-19

Alternative diagnoses that must be excluded before making a diagnosis of MIS-C :

* Tropical fevers (malaria, dengue, scrub typhus, enteric fever)

* Toxic shock syndrome (staphylococcal or streptococcal)

* Bacterial sepsis

MIS-C with Kawasaki Disease (KD) phenotype is characterised by fever, conjunctival redness, oropharyngeal findings (red and/or cracked lips, strawberry tongue), rash, swollen and/or erythematous hands and feet and cervical lymphadenopathy.

Management of MIS-C Kawasaki Phenotype :

IVIG 2 gm/kg over 12-16 hours (max. 100 g), and IV methylprednisolone 1-2 mg/kg/day is administered. If symptoms persist for 48-72 hours of treatment, or if early worsening occurs, an expert is consulted for biologicals.

IVIG is to be given more slowly (over up to 48 hours) in children with cardiac failure/ fluid overload, and steroids are tapered over 2-3 weeks with clinical and CRP monitoring.

A combination of IV methylprednisolone, IVIG (Immune globulins, intravenous) and antimicrobials is used to treat MIS-C with shock.

Only IV methylprednisolone is used to treat MIS-C without shock.

The management algorithm for a child with MIS-C is as follows.

questions.text:
7. A G2P2A0L1 woman has a history of a stillborn baby who looked like the one given in the image below after the birth. In which conditions does sensitization of the mother's immune system occur leading to the following outcome?

* Delivery of O+ve infant by a O-ve mother. 

* Abdominal trauma

* Amniocentesis 

* Abruptio placenta
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Rh alloimmunization. The given image is that of hydrops fetalis. The correct answer is 1, 2, 3, 4.

Rh alloimmunization occurs when an Rh-negative mother produces antibodies to Rh antigens due to an Rh-positive fetus. (statement 1)

Alloimmunization occurs in two stages. First, sensitisation occurs during the first pregnancy, then the immunisation occurs. Sensitisation occurs during situations of fetomaternal bleeds.

Examples of these situations include miscarriage, amniocentesis (statement 3), embryoreduction, ectopic pregnancy, hydatidiform mole, cordocentesis, placenta previa with bleeding, abruption of the placenta (statement 4), intrauterine fetal demise, external cephalic version, abdominal trauma (statement 2), and delivery of an Rh-positive infant to an Rh-negative mother. It can also occur during the third stage of labour, manual removal of the placenta, and after a cesarean section. 

Rh immunisation can be prevented if the mother is unimmunized. Here, she is given Rh anti-D immunoglobulin (IgG) intramuscularly after childbirth. This blocks the Rh-antigen of the fetal cells, removing the intact, antibody-coated fetal red cells from circulation by the spleen or lymph nodes, and inhibits the production of IgG from the B cells. 

It should ideally be administered within 72 hours or preferably earlier after delivery or abortion. The dose can be calculated using the Kleihauer-Betke test. 

The antibodies formed as a result of immunisation are IgM and IgG. However, only IgG antibodies are small enough to cross the placenta and cause hemolytic disease in the fetus. The three manifestations of the hemolytic disease include hydrops fetalis, icterus gravis neonatorum, and congenital anaemia of the newborn. 

Hydrops fetalis is the most severe form of Rh hemolytic disease in the fetus. There is widespread erythrocyte destruction leading to anaemia, anoxemia, and metabolic acidosis. This leads to hepatic injury, causing hypoproteinemia and subsequently generalised oedema, ascites, and hydrothorax. 

The following image shows a stillborn baby with hydrops fetalis.

questions.text: 8. A 34-year-old female patient with repeated attacks of mania and alternating depression was treated with a pharmacological agent. She has been taking that drug for over six years now. She presents to your OPD with complaints of polyuria, polydipsia, and fatigue. On examination, she seems dehydrated, her eyes are sunken, the oral mucosa and tongue are dry, and the skin pinch test reveals absent turgidity of skin. Her RBS value is 100mg/dl. You decide to treat her for nephrogenic diabetes insipidus and start her on a drug ‘X’ 5mg QID. What is the likely mechanism of action of the drug 'X'?

choices.text: Blocks lithium transport by sodium channels

questions.solution:
The drug ‘X’ is Amiloride, and it acts in this case by blocking the lithium transport by the sodium channels into the collecting tubule.

The condition spoken of in the given clinical scenario is nephrogenic diabetes insipidus secondary to lithium toxicity. Lithium is the drug of choice for Bipolar mood disorder. Lithium acts on the collecting tubules. Amiloride, a potassium-sparing diuretic, is preferred in this condition as it has an additional lithium channel-blocking effect. 

Other drugs given in the options:

Thiazides are used in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus due to their paradoxical anti-diuretic action. These are the first-line drugs used in the treatment of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. 

Loop diuretic acts on the Na+ K+ 2Cl- symporter, but is not given in diabetes insipidus as it can worsen the condition.

Chlorpropamide is preferred for central diabetes insipidus owing to its enhancing action on circulating vasopressin.

Pearl PM0392: Site and mechanism of action of diuretics

Diuretics  Site of action  

Enzyme/receptor/transporter inhibited 
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors   Proximal tubule   Carbonic anhydrase  
Loop diuretics  Thick ascending loop of Henle  Na+- K+- 2Cl- symporter
Thiazides Distal convoluted tubule  Na+- Cl- symporter
Epithelial sodium channel inhibitors  Late distal tubule and collecting ducts   ENaC 
Aldosterone antagonists  Late distal tubule and collecting ducts  Mineralocorticoid receptors (indirectly ENaC) 


 



Pearl PM0502: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use
Baseline studies:
  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism


Pearl PM1535: Causes of Nephrogenic DI

*  Drugs

* Lithium

* Amphotericin B

* Demeclocycline

* Cisplatin

* Aminoglycosides

* Foscarnet

* Methoxyflurane

* Rifampin

*  Genetic

* X-linked recessive (AVP receptor-2 gene)

* Autosomal recessive (AQP2 gene)

* Autosomal dominant (AQP2 gene)

*  Metabolic

* Hypercalcemia, hypercalciuria

* Hypokalemia

* Hyperoxaluria

* Sarcoidosis

* Sjogren syndrome

* Polycystic kidney disease

* Amyloidosis

* Vascular

* Sickle cell disease and trait

* Ischemia (acute tubular necrosis)

* Idiopathic

questions.text: 9. A patient presented with swelling in the left side of the floor of the mouth, which was painless, smooth, soft, fluctuant, and brilliantly transilluminant. On further examination of the patient, a swelling was noticed in the left submandibular region. It was bidigitally palpable and cross-fluctuant. The cross-fluctuation of the swelling is across which muscle?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests the most probable diagnosis to be a plunging ranula. Cross-fluctuation in a plunging ranula is across the mylohyoid muscle.

Plunging ranula extends into the submandibular region through the deeper part of the posterior margin of the mylohyoid muscle. It is cross-sectional across the mylohyoid. It presents as a soft, fluctuant, non-tender, dumbbell-shaped swelling in the submandibular region. It is bidigitally palpable.

A ranula is an extravasation cyst arising from the sublingual gland. Occasionally, it can arise from the submandibular salivary gland also. Initially, there is a blockage of the duct (of the sublingual gland), causing a retention cyst, which causes rupture of the acini due to increased pressure, leading to an extravasation cyst.

An image showing the site of a plunging ranula is shown below:



The paired sublingual salivary glands are located beneath the mucosa of the anterior part of the floor of the mouth, anterior to the submandibular ducts and above the mylohyoid and geniohyoid muscles. It is closely related to the lingual nerve and the submandibular salivary duct.

Treatment includes removal of the sublingual gland, as this gland has multiple ducts, and ranulas can recur if the gland is left behind. Incision, drainage and marsupialisation have low success rates. Injecting OK-432 at the local site produces inflammation and fibrosis. Injection of botulinum toxin has shown a success rate but needs further evaluation.

The image given below shows a plunging ranula:



Pearl PM1690: Plunging ranula

It is a form of mucous retention cyst that can arise from both sublingual and submandibular salivary glands and presents as dumb-bell-shaped swelling that is soft, fluctuant and painless in the submandibular or submental region of the neck.

* It shows cross fluctuation along the mylohyoid

* Treatment is by removal of the sublingual gland and aspiration of the saliva out from the sac. The cervical approach which was previously used is now contraindicated.

* Conditions with cross fluctuation are :

* Plunging ranula

* Bilocular hydrocele

* Compound palmar ganglion

* Psoas abscess

Note:

The term ‘ranula’ is applied to a mucous extravasation cyst that arises from the sublingual gland.

Pearl PM2120: Brilliantly Transilluminating Swellings

* Vaginal hydrocele

* Epididymal cyst

* Cystic hygroma

* Ranula

* Meningocele

questions.text: 10. In which phase of the surgical safety checklist is the site of surgery marking checked?
questions.solution:
The site of surgery marking is checked in the sign-in phase of the surgical safety checklist.

The sign-in phase is before the induction of anaesthesia. It requires an anaesthetist and a nurse. The patient’s identity, procedure, consent of the patient, and the site of surgery marking are checked in this phase. Along with this, if there is any allergy, difficulty in the airway, or aspiration risk, it is checked. Pulse oximetry and anaesthetic machines are also checked.

Other options:

Option B: The sign-out phase takes place before the patient exits the operating room. It involves the anaesthetist, nurse, and surgeon. During this phase, the procedure performed is confirmed, instruments and mop counts are verified, and specimen labels are reviewed. Any important issues for post-operative care in recovery are also discussed.

Option C: Time in - There is no such phase in the surgical safety checklist.

Option D: The time-out phase is before the skin incision. It requires an anaesthetist, a nurse, and a surgeon. The patient’s identity, procedure, and site of surgery marking are reconfirmed. Antibiotic prophylaxis is verified, potential critical events are reviewed, and necessary imaging is displayed.

Since the question is specifically asking about checking the site of skin marking, Sign-in is a better answer than Time-out, as the steps in the Sign-in phase are carried out before the Time-out phase. 

                    SIGN IN

Before induction of anesthesia(with nurse & anesthetist).

                TIME OUT

Before skin incision (with nurse anesthetist & surgeon)

                  SIGN OUT

Before the patient leaves OT (with nurse anesthetist & surgeon)

Confirmation by the patient of-

  • Identity
  • Site(marked)
  • Procedure
  • Written consent

Reconfirm-

  • Patient and site
  • Procedure name
  • Time

Name of procedure done and Instrument, sponge, and needle count (by nurse)
Known allergies, difficult airway, or aspiration risk Introduction of all team members with their names and roles  Specimen labelling (by nurse)
Risk of > 500 ml blood loss Antibiotic prophylaxis given Actual blood loss(by anesthetist)
Proper functioning of the anesthesia machine and the pulse oximeter on the patient. Anticipated critical events, including blood loss(by surgeon) Any key concerns for the patient's recovery

questions.text: 11. A microbiologist received a sample of fluid collected by USG-guided pleural tapping in a 30-year-old female. He used the following medium for a solid culture. The function of which of the following contents of the given medium is not correctly matched?

choices.text: Glycerol - source of carbon, favours growth of M. tuberculosis, but not M. bovis
Malachite green - restricts growth of contaminants
Coagulated hen’s egg - provide fatty acids and protein required for metabolism
L-Asparagine - acts as a buffer in the medium

questions.solution:
The image shows Lowenstein–Jensen (LJ) medium, where L-asparagine is the primary nitrogen source (also contributes carbon), not a buffering agent. Buffering in LJ is mainly from phosphates/citrate in the mineral salt mixture.

The Lowenstein–Jensen (LJ) medium is the most widely used egg-based selective medium for the cultivation of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

The following are the contents of LJ medium along with their specific function:

* Coagulated hen’s egg: Provides fatty acids and protein required for metabolism. (Option C)

* Malachite green: Prevents growth of contaminants. (Option B)

* Mineral salt solution: Buffer.

* Glycerol: Source of carbon, favors growth of M. tuberculosis, but not M. Bovis. (Option A)

* L-asparagine: Source of Nitrogen. 

After inoculation, the medium is incubated at 37 °C, and colonies typically appear within 2–8 weeks due to the slow-growing nature of tubercle bacilli. Mycobacterium tuberculosis colonies on LJ medium are rough, raised, irregular colonies that are creamy white, and buff-colored. (rough, tough, buff). 

It is sterilised by inspissation, that is, the application of a temperature of 75°C for three consecutive days

Pearl PM0001: Organisms and selective Culture Media

questions.text: 12. Which of the following diseases does not follow a mitochondrial inheritance?
questions.solution:
Fragile X syndrome does not follow a mitochondrial pattern of inheritance. 

Fragile X syndrome is an X-linked recessive condition with variable patterns of transmission that results from a trinucleotide expansion mutation in the familial mental retardation-1 (FMR-1) gene, causing CGG repeats. It is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability in males and overall the second most common cause after Down syndrome. 

Disorders associated with mitochondrial inheritance:

* Leber Hereditary Optic Neuropathy is a neurodegenerative disease causing progressive bilateral loss of central vision, usually starting between ages 15 and 35, potentially leading to blindness. Some may also have cardiac issues

* Kearns-Sayre Syndrome is characterized by ophthalmoplegia, retinal degeneration, and complete heart block.

* Leigh Syndrome is an infantile disease marked by lactic acidosis, halted development, feeding problems, seizures, and weakness. Death typically occurs within 1 to 2 years. It can be due to both nuclear mutation and mitochondrial DNA mutation.

* Myoclonic Epilepsy with Ragged Red Fibers has features of myoclonus and myopathy, identified by ragged red fibers in muscle biopsies.

* MELAS (Mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes) involves recurrent neurological dysfunction, cognitive changes, muscle weakness, and lactic acidosis.

NOTE- Mutations of mitochondrial inheritance are exclusively inherited from the affected mother.

questions.text: 13. Which of the following is medial to the pyramidal eminence of the middle ear?
questions.solution:
Sinus tympani is medial to the pyramidal eminence of the middle ear.

The pyramidal eminence is situated in the posterior wall of the middle ear in front of the vertical part of the facial nerve canal. It is hollow and contains the stapedius muscle. Its summit is pierced by the tendon of stapedius.

It divides the posterior space into a medial sinus tympani and a lateral facial recess. It is a landmark for the second genu of the facial nerve and houses the vertical segment of the facial nerve & the nerve to stapedius. The aditus (opening to the mastoid) lies just above it.

Image showing sinus tympani and pyramid is:



The sinus tympani, a hidden area of the middle ear, is the most common site for residual cholesteatoma, as it is difficult to remove the disease from this area.

questions.text: 14. A 33-year-old patient presents with flaccid bullae over his face and erosions over his oral mucosa. An immunofluorescence study of his lesions revealed the following picture. Which of the following is the mainstay treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
The immunofluorescence pattern shows a fish-net appearance, suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris, for which systemic corticosteroids are considered the mainstay of treatment. However, steroid-sparing drugs like azathioprine, cyclophosphamide, rituximab, and mycophenolate mofetil can also be used in combination with corticosteroids to reduce the dose of corticosteroids

Pemphigus is a group of chronic immunobullous disorders that are characterized by the presence of antibodies against desmosomal proteins expressed in the skin and mucous tissue.

Clinical features of pemphigus vulgaris are:

* Oral lesions

* Mucosal lesions

* Cutaneous lesions(scalp, face, neck, upper chest and back)

* Flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid

* Rupture of blisters producing painful erosions

* Healing occurs without scarring

* Nail dystrophies

The fish-net appearance of pemphigus vulgaris is due to anti-desmoglein IgG antibodies deposited on the desmosomes (Dsg3 more than Dsg1), which are present intercellularly. Direct immunofluorescence of a skin sample with anti-IgG shows intercellular IgG deposits in the epidermis, in a characteristic fishnet/chickenwire appearance.

Systemic corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment for controlling pemphigus, improving the quality of life, and reducing disease activity. Other steroid-sparing drugs that are used in combination to reduce the dose of steroids include azathioprine, cyclophosphamide (option C), rituximab (option B), and mycophenolate mofetil (option D). 

Below is the image showing oral mucosal lesions of pemphigus vulgaris:





Pearl PM0224: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens

Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase
Linear IgA disease     Pruritic small papules on extensor surfaces; occasionally larger, arciform blisters  Subepidermal blister with neutrophil-rich infiltrate  Linear band of IgA in epidermalBMZ BPAG2

* Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus

* Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus

questions.text: 15. A middle-aged man presents with complaints of biliary colic and fatigue for the past 2 weeks. He admits to consuming raw, fresh water fish recently. Stool microscopy shows the following findings. Which of the following parasites has an infective form similar to the causative pathogen?
questions.solution:
Paragonimus westermanii has an infective form similar to the causative pathogen.

The given clinical history of a middle-aged man presenting with complaints of biliary colic and fatigue, and consuming raw fresh water fish, with stool microscopy showing an operculated egg, is suggestive of a liver fluke infection, Clonorchis or Opisthorchis. Both have metacercaria as their infective form. Among the above options, only Paragonimus westermanii has metacercaria as its infective form.

Both Clonorchis and Opisthorchis have the same life cycle. Humans are infected by eating raw or undercooked fish containing encysted larvae (metacercariae). 

Diphyllobothrium latum (a cestode) and all trematodes, including liver and lung flukes except Schistosoma, show operculated eggs.

The lifecycle of Clonorchis is as shown below:



Paragonimus westermani is a trematode. The transmission to humans occurs by eating raw or undercooked crab or crayfish containing metacercariae. The metacercariae excyst in the human gut, and young worms migrate to the lungs, where they become encapsulated in lung tissue.

The life cycle of Paragonimus is as shown below:



Other options:

Option A: Hymenolepsis nana - The infective form is an egg, which is non-operculated and contains polar filaments and hexacanth larva. It is transmitted via the feco-oral route by ingestion of its eggs in contaminated food/water.

The life cycle of H.nana is shown below:



Option B: Taenia solium - The infective form is cysticercus cellulosae larva, which is acquired by ingestion of undercooked and contaminated pork. It has a non-operculated egg, which is characterized by a thick, radially striated shell containing a hexacanth larva.

The life cycle of T.solium is shown below:



Option D: Schistosoma mansoni- The infective form is a cercaria larva, which is acquired due to penetration into the skin. It has a non-operculated egg with a lateral spine.

questions.text: 16. A 35 year old male who is a known case of asthma is planned for laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. Which of the following muscle relaxants will be most preferred in this case?
questions.solution:
In the clinical scenario of an asthma patient undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy, cisatracurium is the most preferred of the given muscle relaxants.

Non-depolarizing muscle relaxants cause histamine release, but cisatracurium, compared to the other muscle relaxants, is the least histamine-releasing. d-Tubocurarine is the most potent histamine releaser among available muscle relaxants (Option A)

Other histamine-releasing muscle relaxants:

* Metocurine

* Atracurium (Option C)

* Mivacurium (Option D)

The principles of anesthetic management in asthma include: 

* Avoid manipulation of the airway in a lightly anesthetized patient

* Use bronchodilating anesthetics

* Avoid drugs that release histamine

Intravenous induction of anesthesia in asthmatic patients can be done either by propofol or by ketamine to diminish bronchospasm.

Pearl PM0247: Muscle relaxant with histamine release.

Muscle relaxants causing histamine release leading to hypotension, tachycardia, flushing:

Most likely: d-tubocurarine

Likely: 

* Atracurium

* Mivacurium

* Succinyl choline

Least likely:

* Vecuronium

* Cisatracurium

* Rocuronium

* Pancuronium

questions.text: 17. A paediatrician is evaluating a child's developmental milestones. The doctor hands an object to her, lets her play with it and hides it, and observes her reaction, which is shown below. Which of the following language milestones is expected in this child at this age?

choices.text: Uses pronouns like I, me and you

questions.solution:
According to the given clinical scenario, the child has developed object permanence, which suggests the age of the child is 9 months. At this age, the child can say bisyllables like "mama" and "dada."

Object permanence is the understanding that the object continues to exist even when not seen. When the pediatrician hides the object, a baby who is 4 to 7 months of age would not search for it and quickly gives up, while a baby of 9 months of age understands that the object is hidden and continues to exist, and therefore searches for it. This reflects on sensorimotor cognitive development. 

By 9 months, infants begin producing bisyllabic sounds such as “mama” and “dada”. Initially, these may be repetitive babbling, but gradually they are associated with parents or caregivers and gain social meaning.

Other options:

Option A: Monosyllabic sounds (e.g., “ba,” “da”) emerge earlier, typically by 6 months, coinciding with cooing and simple babbling.

Option B: 1–2 words with meaning (like “ball,” “bye”) usually appear at 12 months of age, when receptive vocabulary is expanding. 

Option D: Use of pronouns (“I,” “me,” “you”) requires higher linguistic and social cognition, appearing around 2 years.

Pearl PM1927: Language milestones

 
Age Milestone
1 month Alerts to sound
2 months Coos (musical vowel sound)
4 months Laughs aloud
6 months Monosyllables sounds (ma, ba)
9 months Bisyllables (mama, baba)
12 months 1-2 words with meaning
18 months 8-10 word vocabulary
2 years 2-3 word sentences (uses pronouns like I, me, you)
3 years Asks questions and knows name and gender
4 years Sings songs, poems and tells stories
5 years Asks meaning of words

questions.text: 18. A 26-year-old woman presents with a facial rash, joint pains, and photosensitivity for the past six months. A suspicion of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is kept, and further investigations are initiated by the rheumatologist. Which of the following test results rules out SLE on the first hand itself based on EULAR 2019 criteria?
questions.solution:
An ANA titre <1:80 on HEp-2 cells rules out SLE.

The EULAR/ACR classification criteria require a positive ANA titer (≥1:80 on HEp-2 cells or equivalent) as the entry criterion. 

SLE is a systemic autoimmune disease characterised by tissue and organ damage due to tissue-binding autoantibodies and immune complexes. The diagnosis of SLE relies on a combination of clinical manifestations and immunologic markers.

The clinical and immunological manifestations required for the diagnosis of SLE, as per the EULAR 2019 Criteria, are as follows:

                                           Entry criteria- ANA titre > 1:80 on Hep-2 cells.

                                                                       If Absent- No SLE

                                                 If Present- Apply Additive Criteria

                                                                   ADDITIVE CRITERIA

                          Occurrence of a criterion on at least 1 occasion is sufficient

   Within each domain, count the highest weighted criteria towards the total score
Clinical domain with score Immunological domain with score

Antiphospholipid antibodies (Anti-cardiolipin antibodies/ Anti β2GP-1 antibodies/Lupus anticoagulant) -  2

Hematologic-

Leukopenia - 3

Thrombocytopenia - 4

Autoimmune hemolytic anemia - 4

Complement proteins

Low C3 and low C4- 4

       Classify as SLE with a score of 10 or more if the entry criterion is fulfilled

questions.text: 19. A forensic anthropologist is examining a skull excavated from a construction site. He calculated the cephalic index of the skull to be 72 . What is the most probable type of skull?
questions.solution:
Dolichocephalic is the correct type of skull when the cephalic index is less than 75. These skulls are long-headed, with a greater anteroposterior diameter compared to breadth, and are commonly seen in Negroid races.

The cephalic index is used to determine the race of the individual. It is an anthropometric ratio:

Cephalic index = Maximum skull breadth x 100 / Maximum skull length

The skull breadth is measured between the two parietal eminences, and the skull length is measured from the glabella to the external occipital protuberance using calipers.

There are three main racial groups: Caucasian, Mongoloid, and Negroid. All the skulls cannot be accurately differentiated into the 3 broad categories because of racial mixing. The skull offers the best evidence of racial origins.

Type of skull Cephalic index

 Race(s)

Dolichocephalic (long-headed)

  70-75 Pure Aryan, Aborigines, Negroes

Mesaticephalic (medium-headed) (Option B)

 75-80 Europeans, Chinese, Indians

Brachycephalic (short-headed) (Option A)

80-85

 Mongolian


The skull of an Indian is said to be 'Caucasian with a few Negroid features.'



The hyperbrachycephalic (Option D) variant, characterized by a very round or broad head with a cephalic index of 85–89.9, is often observed in cases of Apert syndrome.

Pearl PM0053: Indices for determination of race and sex of an individual

To determine the sex of an individual -



Krogman's degree of accuracy in sexing adult skeletal remains:

* Entire skeleton – 100%

* Pelvis alone – 95%

* Skull alone – 90%

* Pelvis plus skull – 98%

* Long bones alone – 80%

 

To determine the race of an individual -

questions.text: 20. A 28-year-old male patient came to the hospital with complaints of paroxysmal vertigo and drop attacks during arm exercise. This is due to_______.

choices.text: Occlusion in the 1st part of subclavian artery
Occlusion in the 2nd part of subclavian artery
Occlusion in the 3rd part of subclavian artery

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Subclavian steal syndrome. It occurs due to occlusion in the 1st part of the subclavian artery.

Subclavian steal syndrome results from steno-occlusive disease of the proximal subclavian artery, causing reversed blood flow in the ipsilateral vertebral artery. This can lead to symptoms like vertigo, drop attacks, and arm claudication due to reduced vertebrobasilar and upper limb perfusion. Atherosclerosis is the most common cause, and symptom severity correlates with greater inter-arm blood pressure differences.

Doppler ultrasound is used for screening. CT or MR angiography is needed for confirmation. Initial treatment is conservative; stenting is preferred over bypass surgery in persistent cases.

questions.text: 21. A 20-year-old woman presented with multiple pruritic linear erythematous papules and vesicles on her wrist and forearm, as depicted in the image below. The patient developed these lesions after wearing a new metalic bracelet gifted to her. A patch test was was done to confirm the diagnosis. When should you ask her to return for removal of the patch for an initial reading ?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of allergic contact dermatitis, for which patch testing is performed, and the patch is removed after 48 hours to examine the site of reaction for initial reading.

Allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) is an inflammatory condition caused due to a delayed hypersensitivity reaction (Type 4 hypersensitivity) to a specific allergen that comes into direct contact with the skin. Some common allergens include nickel (found in artificial jewelry), PPD/Para-phenylene diamine (in hair dye), chromate (in cement), rubber or latex, cosmetics, etc. A Patch test is used for the diagnosis of ACD.

Patch testing is a test to detect sensitivity to a specific allergen. A battery of suspected allergens is applied to the patient’s back under occlusive dressings or patches. It is allowed to remain in contact with the skin for 48 hours.

* 48 hours:  Patch removal for initial reading to detect delayed hypersensitivity reaction.

* 72-96 hours: Final reading done for confirmation. 

Below is the image showing the patch test done on the back of the patient:

questions.text: 22. Which of the following is the most common cause of Cushingoid features?
questions.solution:
Iatrogenic hypercortisolism is the most common cause of Cushingoid features.

Ectopic tumour ACTH production, cortisol-producing adrenal adenomas, adrenal carcinoma, and adrenal hyperplasia are the other causes associated.

Pearl PM1549: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Exogenous causes (iatrogenic)

* Prolonged administration of glucocorticoids (most common cause of Cushing's)

Endogenous causes

* ACTH independent (primary hypercortisolism)

* Adrenocortical adenoma 

* Adrenocortical carcinoma 

* Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia

* ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)

* Cushing’s disease: ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (most common cause of endogenous Cushing's)

* Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors

* Small-cell lung carcinoma

* Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors

* Medullary thyroid carcinoma

* Pheochromocytoma

Rare causes

* Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia

* Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease

* McCune – Albright syndrome

questions.text: 23. Shaffer’s sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
Shaffer’s sign or tobacco dusting refers to the presence of pigment cells in the anterior vitreous. It is seen in retinal detachment (RD), especially rhegmatogenous retinal detachment.

The image shows tobacco dust appearance (Shaffer's sign) in the anterior vitreous:



In rhegmatogenous retinal detachment, fluid accumulates after a break (tear) occurs in the retina. The most dangerous type of retinal break is a horseshoe tear. The most dangerous location of the retinal break is the superior temporal retina. 

Risk factors for the development of rhegmatogenous RD are:

* High myopia

* Blunt trauma

* Previous cataract surgery (aphakia and pseudophakia)

* Lattice degeneration of the retina

Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment presents with photopsia (flashes of light from vitreoretinal traction), floaters (often due to vitreous haemorrhage), and a visual field defect described as a black curtain or veil. Clinical signs include Shaffer's sign (pigment in the anterior vitreous, or "tobacco dusting"), a convex configuration of the detached retina, and a corrugated, undulating retinal surface.

The given image shows an approach to the management of retinal detachment:

  • Central retinal artery occlusion
  • Massive vitreous hemorrhage
  • Retinal detachment involving macula
  • Ischemic central retinal vein occlusion
Sudden painless onset of diminution of vision
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Methyl alcohol amblyopia
  • Non-ischemic central retinal vein occlusion

  • Acute congestive glaucoma
  • Acute iridocyclitis
  • Injury to eyeball
Gradual painless diminution of vision

  • Optic atrophy

questions.text: 24. A 65-year-old male with a 30-pack-year smoking history presents with a chronic productive cough, progressive exertional breathlessness, and wheezing. On auscultation, coarse crackles are heard. Which of the following best explains the likely ventilation-perfusion relationship in his lungs?

choices.text: Uniformly high V/Q throughout the lungs

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation suggests chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), most likely with features of chronic bronchitis, which creates areas of low ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) ratio.

Chronic bronchitis presents with mucopurulent sputum production with cough, breathlessness, and coarse crackles on auscultation. A long history of smoking is a major risk factor in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. In COPD, airflow obstruction caused by airway inflammation and structural damage leads to reduced ventilation in the affected alveoli, while perfusion is relatively preserved. This mismatch results in impaired gas exchange and hypoxemia, resulting in low V/Q. 

Other options:

Option A: High V/Q usually occurs at the apex of the lung or in cases like pulmonary embolism (V/Q= ∞).

Option B: COPD leads to areas of mismatch between ventilation and perfusion, so the V/Q is abnormal in affected regions.  

Option D: Dead space refers to ventilation without perfusion (V/Q= ∞), which is typically seen with pulmonary embolism and not COPD. 

Note: The normal value of V/Q is 0.8.

questions.text: 25. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in a patient with gout with concurrent G6PD deficiency anemia?
questions.solution:
Pegloticase should be avoided in a patient with gout with concurrent G6PD deficiency anemia. 

Allopurinol, colchicine, febuxostat, and pegloticase are all used in the treatment of Gout.  

Pegloticase is a urate oxidase that breaks down uric acid through an enzymatic reaction that produces hydrogen peroxide, a strong oxidizing by-product. In individuals with G6PD deficiency, there is insufficient production of NADPH, which is required to maintain reduced glutathione.

Reduced glutathione normally protects red blood cells by neutralizing hydrogen peroxide. Without this protection, hydrogen peroxide accumulates and causes oxidative damage to red blood cells, leading to membrane instability and ultimately acute hemolytic anemia, which can be severe and life-threatening.

Allopurinol and febuxostat are xanthine oxidase inhibitors that are used in the treatment of gout and hyperuricemia.

Colchicine has a variety of mechanisms of action, ranging from antimitotic activity, inhibition of neutrophil motility, and inhibition histamine release from mast cells. It is used in an acute attack of gout.

questions.text: 26. The ability to detect a false null hypothesis will decrease if:

choices.text: Alpha increases / chance of type I error increases
The size of the difference between the sample mean and the hypothesized population mean increases

questions.solution:
The ability of a test to avoid false negative error (type II or β error) is called the Power of the Test (“the ability of a test to reject a null hypothesis when it is false”). The test's power decreases if the sample size decreases.

It is expressed as 1 - β. Thus, A test’s power will increase if:

* β error decreases

* The width of the confidence interval (i.e., the margin of error) decreases

* Sample size increases (Option C)

* Sampling error decreases(Option D)

Other Options:

Option A: An increase in the significance level (alpha) means that the statistical test is more likely to reject the null hypothesis for a given effect. Consequently, the probability of detecting a false null hypothesis, i.e., statistical power increases, not decreases.

Option B: A larger difference between the sample mean and the hypothesized mean indicates a greater effect size, which is easier to detect amid sampling variability. Thus, as the effect size increases, statistical power also increases.

Pearl PM1098: Concepts in Hypothesis Testing

Probability value (p value)

* A probability value is the probability of an outcome given the hypothesis.

* It is not the probability of the hypothesis given the outcome, although the probability of the given hypothesis is not ignored.

* If the probability of an outcome is sufficiently low, we have evidence that the hypothesis is false.

* It is also called the p value.

The Null Hypothesis and Alternative Hypothesis

* The hypothesis that an apparent effect or outcome is only due to chance is a null hypothesis.

* In other words, a null hypothesis is one where there is no difference between the specified sample and population and any observed difference is due to chance or some other error.

* A null hypothesis is represented by H0.

* If the null hypothesis is rejected as false, then there is an alternative or experimental hypothesis (HA), which is logically accepted.

Criterion or Significance Level (α)

* If the probability value of an outcome is sufficiently low, then the null hypothesis is rejected.

* This point below which we would define the probability value as being low enough to reject the null hypothesis is called the criterion or significance level or α (alpha) level.

* When the null hypothesis is rejected, the effect or outcome is said to be statistically significant.

* By convention (but not always), the level of α is 0.05, i.e., if the probability value of an outcome is less than or equal to 0.05 (p value ≤ 0.05), then the null hypothesis is rejected.

* If it is greater than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is accepted.

* Although by convention the level of α is 0.05, it can be lower but cannot be any higher.

Type I Error

* The interpretation of p value ≤ 0.05 is that an investigator can be 95% sure that the result was not obtained by chance.

* It also means that there is a 5% probability that the result was obtained by chance.

* From this, we can deduce that the null hypothesis might indeed be true even though we rejected it.

* This is a type I error. In other words, when an alternative hypothesis is accepted even when it is false and the null hypothesis is true, it is a type I error or false positive error.

* It is also called an alpha (α) error as it is related to the criterion α.

* The lower the α level, the lower the rate of a type I error being made.

* Thus, it can be said that α is the maximum tolerable probability that a type I error is being made and that the p value is the probability that a significant difference is declared when there is none.

Type II Error

* The error that is made by rejecting an alternative hypothesis when it is true or failing to reject a null hypothesis when it is false is called a type II error.

* It is also called a false negative error and more commonly, as a beta (β) error.

* If the null hypothesis is false, then the probability of a type II error is β.

* The power of a statistical test is indicated by 1–β.

Power of a Test

* The power of a test is the ability of a statistical test to avoid a type II error, which depends on its ability to detect a false null hypothesis.

* It is equal to 1–β, which is the probability that a false null hypothesis will be rejected.

* By convention, a test is required to have a power of 0.8 (or a β of 0.2) to be acceptable. This is to say that a study that has less than 80% chance of detecting a false null hypothesis is unacceptable.

* Type I errors are easily reduced by reducing the criterion α.

* A test's power will increase in the following conditions:

* If α increases, but this will increase the chance of a type I error.

* If the difference between the sample mean and hypothesized mean increases. This is also called effect size.

* If sampling error decreases.

* If the sample size (n) increases.

questions.text: 27. The patient presented with a swelling over the right arm, as shown in the image. He gives no complaints of pain or tenderness over the swelling. On examination, the slip sign is positive. What part of the body is least likely to be affected by this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows swelling due to a lipoma. The brain is the least likely part of the body to be affected by this condition.

A lipoma is a benign neoplasm arising from yellow fat, composed of mature adipocytes. It is called a universal tumour (ubiquitous tumour) as it can occur anywhere in the body and is least likely to be affected in the brain. It can be localised (encapsulated) or diffuse (non-encapsulated). It can be superficial or deep. It is common in the palm, sole, head, and neck.

Recurrence is high after incomplete removal. Malignant transformation of lipoma is non-existent. Liposarcoma does not arise from mature fat cells but from primitive mesenchymal cells. Clinically, it is a painless, soft to firm swelling with a slip sign positive. The size of the swelling may increase over the course of time. Management is by excision of the lipoma under local anaesthesia.

questions.text:
28. A 4 mm ureteric calculus is observed in the lower part of the ureter. What is the plan of management?

PCNL - Percutaneous nephrolithotomy URS - Ureteroscopic retrieval of stones ESWL - Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy
questions.solution:
Conservative management is the best course in the given scenario.

Ureteric calculi are stones present in the ureter that have passed from the kidney into the ureter.

Indications for conservative management:

* Small (<5 mm) calculi

* Non-obstructive

* Asymptomatic

* Normal renal function

If stones are >5 mm or present distally in the ureter, or in case of post-ESWL, medical expulsive therapy with tamsulosin is indicated.

Other Options:

Option B: In Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL), endoscopic instruments are inserted into the kidney through a percutaneous technique, and stones are fragmented and removed. It is mainly used in treating large stones and stones in the proximal ureter.

Indications for percutaneous nephrolithotomy include:

* Renal stones >2 cm

* Lower-pole renal stones

* Failed ESWL or RIRS for renal calculi

* Staghorn calculi

Option C: Ureteroscopic retrieval of stone (URS) is the preferred treatment in non-impacted ureteric stones >5-6mm in size.

Option D: Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a non-invasive method that generates shockwaves outside the body, which are focused on the stones. It is the most common method of treating urinary tract stones. Patients having renal stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment. Cystine stones, which are often multiple and very hard, are relatively resistant to ESWL due to their hardness.

Pearl PM0310: Management of renal and ureteric calculi



ESWL: Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy

PCNL: Percutaneous nephrolithotomy

URS: Ureteroscopic retrieval of stones

Pearl PM0311: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones



Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text:
29. Arterial blood gas analysis of a person with liver disease reveals the following results. What type of metabolic and/or respiratory abnormality is likely to be present?

* PaCO2= 35

* HCO3- = 32

* pH = 7.5

* Anion gap = 16

* Na+ = 140

* K+ = 4.0

* Cl-= 91

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis and compensatory respiratory acidosis
Metabolic acidosis and compensatory respiratory alkalosis
Metabolic alkalosis and simultaneous respiratory alkalosis

questions.solution:
The given arterial blood gas (ABG) result shows metabolic alkalosis and simultaneous respiratory alkalosis.

ABG analysis is done to assess disturbances of the normal acid-base homeostasis. It is calculated using the following steps:

Step 1: Determine if acidemia or alkalemia is present. Acidemia is a blood pH below 7.35 and alkalemia is a blood pH above 7.45. 

The ABG given here shows a pH of 7.5 which is above the limit of 7.45. Thus there is alkalemia.

pH = 7.5 Increased  Normal - 7.35 to 7.45
PCO2 = 35 Normal  Normal - 35 to 45 mmHg
HCO3- = 32 Increased  Normal - 20 to 28 mEq/L


Step 2: Look for the cause of acidemia/alkalemia. Acidosis is the pathological process that causes an increase in hydrogen ions. Alkalosis is the pathological process that causes a decrease in hydrogen ions. 

Here, the value of HCO3- is 32 (increase in bicarbonate ions). PCO2 is within normal limits. Thus, the primary acid-base disorder is metabolic alkalosis. 

During a simple metabolic disorder, you would expect there to be respiratory compensation (and vice versa). 

The expected respiratory compensation during metabolic alkalosis is : PCO2 = (HCO3- ) + 15 or PCO2 increases by 6 mmHg for each 10mEq/L increase in HCO3- .  

Thus, the expected increase in PCO2 should be 32 + 15  = 47 mmHg. However, the PCO2 here is only 35 mmHg, and hence there is no respiratory compensation.

Step 3: Since CO2 is 35, which is below the compensatory values, it suggests that there is a simultaneous respiratory alkalosis.

Thus, the ABG above shows a mixed disorder of metabolic alkalosis with simultaneous respiratory alkalosis.

Pearl PM1343: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory


Pearl PM1341: Causes of Acid-Base Disorders

Metabolic acidosis

Metabolic alkalosis

Respiratory acidosis

Respiratory alkalosis

Ketoacidosis

Lactic acidosis

Chronic renal failure

Salicylate intoxication

Methanol/formaldehyde intoxication

Ethylene glycol intoxication

Diarrhoea

Renal tubular acidosis

Vomiting

Hyperaldosteronism

Loop or thiazide diuretics

Opiates, sedatives, anesthesia

Guillain- Barre syndrome, Polio, ALS, multiple sclerosis

Airway obstruction

Adult respiratory distress syndrome, COPD

Pneumonia, pulmonary embolism

High altitude

Psychogenic


Pearl PM2098: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis
Acute

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Acute

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

questions.text: 30. The following set of instruments are not used in ________ .
questions.solution:
The following set of instruments are not used in Spinal anesthesia.

The given image shows an Epidural set, containing an epidural catheter, an 18-G Tuohy needle and a syringe, which is used in epidural anesthesia. It is used in obstetric analgesia, post-operative analgesia, surgical anesthesia, chronic pain management, and segmental blocks, but not in spinal anesthesia.

The Tuohy needle has a blunt, curved tip that helps to prevent accidental dural puncture. The Crawford needle is also an epidural needle that is a straight needle without a curved tip, and has a greater incidence of dural puncture.

questions.text: 31. A 56-year-old hypertensive man presented with a 2-day history of continuous gnawing pain in the hypogastric region. An ultrasound revealed a pulsatile intra-abdominal mass. CT image is given below. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Follow up with serial abdominal ultrasound

questions.solution:
The image shows an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The next best in management in this case is operative repair as the patient is symptomatic.

Abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) are often asymptomatic and are frequently discovered incidentally during investigations for unrelated issues. Occasionally, they may present with abdominal pain and a pulsatile mass. Rupture of aneurysm presents with acute pain and hypotension.

Management of abdominal aortic aneurysms:

* Statins- Atherosclerosis is the most common pathology associated with abdominal aortic aneurysms. Hence, statins are prescribed to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.

* Asymptomatic aneurysms <5.5 cm in diameter- serial abdominal ultrasound to monitor the rate of expansion of the aneurysm.

*

Indications for surgical repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA):

Symptomatic aneurysms of any size Rapidly expanding aneurysms Aneurysms with a diameter of ≥5.5 cm

Note: Medical management with beta-blockers is not effective in reducing the rate of growth of abdominal aortic aneurysms.

questions.text: 32. A 50-year-old woman presents with postprandial epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, and weight loss. A barium study shows an abrupt cut-off of contrast flow from the duodenum to the jejunum. Which surgery is not performed in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of superior mesenteric artery syndrome (SMA), in which Billroth I surgery is not performed. The mainstay of surgical management is to bypass the obstructed duodenum.

It is most commonly seen in young, asthenic individuals (women more than men) and in patients with anorexia nervosa. Predisposing factors include rapid weight loss, prolonged supine immobilization, scoliosis, and application of body casts.

The clinical features are those of proximal intestinal obstruction, presenting with profuse vomiting, persistent nausea, postprandial epigastric pain, and abdominal distension. The diagnosis is usually made with a barium upper GI study or hypotonic duodenography, which demonstrates abrupt cessation of contrast flow from the duodenum to the jejunum.

Initial management is conservative with nutritional rehabilitation and postural changes; however, if this fails, surgery is required. 

The definitive operative procedures aim to bypass the obstruction:

* Duodenojejunostomy (Procedure of choice): Directly bypasses the compressed third part of the duodenum by creating an anastomosis between the duodenum (usually the second part) and the jejunum. It is most physiological as it preserves the gastric emptying pathway. (Option A).

* Gastrojejunostomy: Creates a bypass from the stomach to the jejunum. It is simpler than duodenojejunostomy. (Option B)

* Strong’s Procedure (Duodenal derotation): Division of the ligament of Treitz to mobilize and shift the duodenum downward and to the right, relieving vascular compression. It avoids the creation of a bypass anastomosis. (Option C)



In Billroth I (gastroduodenostomy), the lower half of the stomach is removed, and the cut end of the stomach is anastomosed to the first part of the duodenum. It is typically performed for peptic ulcer disease. Since the obstruction in SMA syndrome lies distal to the anastomosis (in the third part of the duodenum), Billroth I does not relieve the compression and hence has no role in treatment.

questions.text: 33. All of the following modalities are mass approaches for communication, except _______.
questions.solution:
Role play is the dramatization of social situations for health education by those taking part in it. It is a group approach of communication.

A workshop is a series of meetings with an emphasis on individual work within the group. External consultants or experts may be involved.

A symposium is a series of lectures on a selected subject by experts after which the audience is allowed to ask questions (no discussion is involved).

Seminars are similar to conferences and incorporate a variety of methods like speeches, discussions for health education, which may last for half a day to a week.

Methods of Health Communication    
Individual approach Group approach Mass approach
  1. Personal contact
  2. Home visits
  3. Personal letters
  1. Lectures
  2. Demonstrations
  3. Discussion methods
    • Group discussions
    • Panel discussion
    • Symposium
    • Workshop
    • Conferences
    • Seminars
    • Role play
  1. TV
  2. Radio
  3. Newspaper
  4. Printed material
  5. Direct mailing
  6. Posters
  7. Health museums
  8. Health exhibitions
  9. Folk method
  10. Internet

questions.text: 34. A 7-year-old boy presents with a 3-month history of increasing irritability and a noticeable decline in school performance. He has become clumsy and unsteady on his feet. His mother mentions that to encourage him to play outside, she recently set up a small garden for him in the yard of their city home, where he spends hours playing in the soil. A physical examination reveals significant pallor. The peripheral blood smear shows basophilic stippling. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis that can explain the presentation is sideroblastic anemia due to lead poisoning. 

The boy presents with pallor, irritability, declining school performance, and clumsiness, along with basophilic stippling on peripheral smear. His chronic exposure to soil in an urban garden is a classic source of lead toxicity.

Sideroblastic anemia occurs in lead poisoning as lead inhibits the enzymes ferrochelatase and δ-aminolevulinate dehydratase, which are responsible for the heme synthesis pathway. This leads to the accumulation of the heme precursors in the cell. They can be stained by Prussian blue staining and can be visualized in the RBCs on a peripheral smear.

The hematological findings that are associated with lead poisoning are:

* Anemia

* Pappenheimer bodies

* Dimorphic RBCs

* Ringed sideroblasts (shown below)

* Basophilic stippling of the RBCs.

A host of pathological features can be found in lead poisoning, as summarized in the figure.





Other options:

Option A: Vitamin B12 deficiency causes macrocytic anemia with hypersegmented neutrophils and neurologic deficits but does not cause sideroblastic changes.

Option B: Beta thalassemia minor typically presents with mild microcytosis and is often asymptomatic or mild anemia, without neurological signs. 

Option C: Acute intermittent porphyria presents with abdominal pain, neuropathy, and psychiatric manifestations, but anemia and basophilic stippling are absent; the onset is usually later in childhood or adolescence. It is caused by a deficiency of porphobilinogen deaminase (also called hydroxymethylbilane synthase), leading to accumulation of porphobilinogen and δ-aminolevulinic acid.

Pearl PM2101: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

Lead Toxicity
Source of exposure

Occupational exposure

Lead paint
Route of absorption

Children - GI tract

Adults - Respiratory tract
Mechanism of action
  • Binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits
    • ALA dehydratase
    • Ferrochelatase
  • Inhibits pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase
  • Competes with calcium
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

GI tract, Bone marrow, Peripheral nerves
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Kidney

Characteristic clinical findings

(ABCDEF)

A - Anemia with basophilic stippling

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

E - Encephalopathy- Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsions, and coma

F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)
Diagnosis Blood lead levels
Treatment Calcium EDTA; succimer(DMSA)


Pearl PM1268: Features of Peripheral Blood Smear in Different Anemias

questions.text: 35. A 25-year-old female with low visual acuity underwent a routine eye exam. On direct illumination, whorl-like radial grey opacities are seen in the corneal epithelium. Which of the following is most likely the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of whorl-like radial grey opacities in the corneal epithelium is suggestive of Lisch Epithelial Dystrophy.

Lisch epithelial corneal dystrophy (LECD), an X-linked dominant condition, is also known as band-shaped and whorled microcystic dystrophy of the corneal epithelium. It is a type of epithelial dystrophy. It occurs in childhood and can lead to slow and progressive deterioration of vision due to corneal opacification.

Direct illumination reveals grey colored opacities in corneal epithelium that can assume different shapes, like radial, whorl-like, flame/feathery-shaped. Blurring of vision often takes place when the pupillary margin gets involved.

Image showing a gray, banded shape, sharply demarcated corneal opacity as seen in Lisch epithelial dystrophy:



Corneal dystrophies are primarily a bilateral, inherited, non-inflammatory condition specific to the cornea. They are free of any association with any systemic disease and usually present in the first or second decades of life.

Based on the layers of the cornea involved, they are classified into epithelial, Bowman layer, stroma, Descemet's membrane, and endothelial dystrophies.

Other options:

Option B: Granular corneal dystrophy is a type of stromal dystrophy of the cornea. It is of autosomal dominant inheritance and is caused by a defect in the TGFB1 gene. The condition is characterised by milky granular hyaline deposits in the anterior stroma. The following image shows numerous irregularly shaped, discrete, crumb-like corneal opacities of granular dystrophy.



Option C: Lattice dystrophy is a stromal dystrophy of the cornea. The classic form of lattice corneal dystrophy has an autosomal dominant inheritance and is caused by a defect in the TGFB1 gene. It is characterised by recurrent corneal erosions at the end of the first decade of age. Histopathology in lattice corneal dystrophy will show the deposition of amyloid in the stroma. These deposits stain with Congo red stain and exhibit apple green birefringence on polarised microscopy.



Option D: Reis–Buckler dystrophy, an autosomal dominant disorder, is characterised by the replacement of the Bowman layer with connective tissue bands, primarily affecting the Bowman layer and superficial stroma. In this condition, there are grey-white, geographic subepithelial opacities (that are most dense centrally and increase over time, eventually forming a reticular pattern.



Pearl PM0711: Types of Corneal Dystrophies

Epithelial

* Epithelial basement membrane dystrophy (EBMD)

* Epithelial recurrent erosion dystrophy

* Meesman’s dystrophy

* Lisch’s epithelial dystrophy

* Gelatinous drop-like dystrophy

Bowman’s Membrane

* Thiel-Behnke corneal dystrophy

* Grayson-Wilbrandt corneal dystrophy

Stromal Corneal Dystrophies

* Granular dystrophy

* Macular corneal dystrophy

* Schnyder corneal dystrophy

* Fleck corneal dystrophy

* Posterior amorphous corneal dystrophy

* Central cloudy dystrophy of Francois

Descemet membrane and Endothelial corneal dystrophy

* Posterior polymorphous corneal dystrophy (PPCD)
