* X-linked endothelial corneal dystrophy

questions.text: 36. Which of the following neurodegenerative diseases has superoxide dismutase 1 inclusions?
questions.solution:
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) has superoxide dismutase type 1 (SOD1) inclusions.

It is a form of motor neuron disease that includes upper and lower motor neuron pathology. It is a progressive disease occurring due to the accumulation of mutated SOD1 proteins, causing increased free radicals, followed by cellular injury of neurons and apoptosis. 

ALS is characterized by muscle weakness, atrophy, fasciculations, spasticity, and hyperreflexia. Bulbar involvement causes speech and swallowing difficulties. Cognitive function and sensation are generally preserved, except in cases with concurrent frontotemporal dementia.

Pathology includes neurofilament accumulations, ubiquitin-positive inclusions, and neuroinflammation. Riluzole and edaravone offer modest benefits. Tofersen is approved for SOD1 mutation ALS.

The diseases and their associated inclusion bodies are given below:

Disease Inclusion bodies
Huntington's disease Huntington (Polyglutamine)
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis SOD1
Spinal-bulbar muscular atrophy Androgen receptor (Polyglutamine-containing)
Multiple system atrophy

α-synuclein
Progressive supranuclear palsy

Tau
Frontotemporal lobar degeneration

Tau, TDP-43

questions.text: 37. A 70-year-old woman admitted to the surgical ward had been diagnosed with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. Which of the following is not a suitable next step for this patient?
questions.solution:
Switching to warfarin is not a suitable next step for patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). 

Warfarin should not be administered in HIT until platelets return to their baseline level. If warfarin was administered, give vitamin K to restore the INR to normal. 

Patients with HIT, particularly those with associated thrombosis, have increased thrombin generation that can lead to consumption of protein C. Suppose these patients are given warfarin without a concomitant parenteral anticoagulant to inhibit thrombin or thrombin generation. In that case, the further decrease in protein C levels induced by the vitamin K antagonist can trigger skin necrosis.

It occurs more with unfractionated heparin than with low molecular weight (LMW) heparin. It is more common in surgical patients and more common in women than in men.

HIT is a lethal complication of heparin use and results from an autoantibody directed against endogenous platelet factor 4 (PF4) in complex with heparin. These antibodies bind simultaneously to the heparin-PF4 complex and to platelet Fc receptors, activating the platelets and generating platelet microparticles. This can cause catastrophic arterial and venous thrombosis.

Features:

* Thrombocytopenia: Platelet count of ≤100,000/μL or a decrease in platelet count of ≥50%

* Platelet count falls 5–14 days after starting heparin

Investigations:

* ELISA to detect antibodies against heparin-PF4 complexes (most sensitive)

* Platelet activation assays

* Serotonin release assay (most specific)

Treatment:

* Stop all heparin.

* Give an alternative anticoagulant, such as lepirudin, argatroban, bivalirudin, fondaparinux or rivaroxaban.

* Do not give platelet transfusions.

Other options: 

Option A: Heparin should be discontinued if the patient has HIT. 

Option B: Lepirudin can be administered as it is an alternative anticoagulant. 

Option D: Rivaroxaban can be given as it is an alternative anticoagulant.

questions.text: 38. A 24-year-old female patient came with complaints of dyspnea, dysphagia, hoarseness of voice, and cough for a few months. A mass in the thyroid gland was detected, and a diagnosis of Reidel's thyroiditis was made. Which among the following condition has pathophysiology similar to Reidel's thyroiditis?
questions.solution:
Riedel's thyroiditis is an IgG4-related disease. Among the given options, the condition that has pathophysiology similar to Reidel's thyroiditis is retroperitoneal fibrosis, which is also an IgG4-related disease.

IgG4-related disease is a group of disorders characterized by tissue infiltrates predominantly composed of IgG4 antibody-producing plasma cells and lymphocytes, fibrosis, obliterative phlebitis, and increased serum IgG4. It is predominantly seen in middle-aged men. The IgG4-related disease spectrum includes:

* Mikulicz syndrome 

* Riedel thyroiditis

* Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis

* Autoimmune pancreatitis

* Inflammatory pseudotumors of the orbit, lungs, and kidney

Riedel thyroiditis is a rare disorder characterized by extensive fibrosis of the thyroid gland and adjacent structures. They present with a nontender, hard-fixed thyroid mass leading to suspicion of malignancy. Diagnosis requires an open biopsy and surgical resection relieves compressive symptoms. It may be associated with IgG4-related disease-causing idiopathic fibrosis at other sites. 

Retroperitoneal fibrosis is an IgG4-related disease that presents with backache, low abdominal pain, lower limb edema, and hydronephrosis from ureteral involvement.

Other options:

Option A: Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune thyroiditis that destroys the thyroid gland and leads to gradual, progressive thyroid failure. This occurs due to the breakdown in self-tolerance to thyroid autoantigens. 

Option B: De Quervain thyroiditis is also known as granulomatous thyroiditis. It is triggered by a viral infection. A viral upper respiratory tract infection causes host tissue damage that stimulates a cytotoxic T lymphocyte response to one or more thyroid antigens that damages thyroid follicle cells.

Option D: Amyloidosis is a condition associated with inherited and inflammatory disorders in which extracellular deposits of abnormal fibrillar proteins cause tissue damage and functional compromise.

questions.text: 39. A 19-year-old woman has recurrent sinopulmonary infections and chronic diarrhea. A sweat chloride test shows 79 mEq/L (normal 40 mEq/L). What best describes the secretory mechanism of the glands involved over the majority of the skin surface?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis in which the secretory mechanism of the glands can be best described as merocrine.

Cystic fibrosis presents as recurrent respiratory infection and chronic diarrhea with greasy stools and two positive sweat chloride tests. It affects many exocrine cells, including the typical sweat gland on the body’s surface, which is a type of merocrine gland.

The primary defect in cystic fibrosis is an abnormality in chloride and bicarbonate ion transport due to defects in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene on chromosome 7q. The functions of CFTR are tissue-specific, and one of the chief affected tissues is the sweat glands distributed all over the body.

Simple/typical sweat glands are merocrine glands. In merocrine glands, the secretions are initially packed into membrane-bound vesicles, shifted to the cell surface, and poured out by exocytosis. The cell remains intact. The stimulus for secretion is predominantly due to raised intracellular calcium. It is the most commonly seen mechanism of exocrine secretion. 

While undoubtedly, atypical sweat glands (which are apocrine) will also be affected, these do not form the majority of the body’s surface and are an exception to the norm.



Other options:

Option A: Apocrine glands release their secretions by pinching off a portion of the cell's cytoplasm. They are found in areas such as armpits and groin. An example includes milk fat secretion from the mammary glands.



Option C: Holocrine glands release their secretions by rupturing the entire cell, which then becomes part of the secretion. An example is the sebaceous glands in the skin.



Option D: Endocrine glands secrete hormones directly into the bloodstream without using ducts, regulating body functions like growth and metabolism.

Pearl PM0709: Comparison between Types of Sweat Glands

Feature

Apocrine sweat gland

Eccrine sweat gland

Activity

Active at puberty

Throughout life

Opening on the surface

Around hair shaft

Through sweat pores

Function

Provides peculiar odour

Maintains temperature

Nervous control

Postganglionic sympathetic neurons which are adrenergic

Postganglionic sympathetic neurons which are cholinergic

Secretions

Viscid with lipids and proteins

Watery with salts

questions.text:
40. A patient with acute exacerbation of COPD has been admitted to ICU. From the given image, identify which of the following oxygen therapy is being used in this patient?

COPD - Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
questions.solution:
The image shown above shows non-invasive mechanical ventilation.

Non-invasive ventilation (NIV) is delivered via a tight-fitting face mask, which obviates the need for and complications of endotracheal intubation/ invasive mechanical ventilation. Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and Bilevel positive airway pressure (BiPAP) modes are used for administering non-invasive ventilation.

Positive-pressure ventilation helps with stiff lungs and high airway resistance. Here, gas flow and pressure can be adjusted to improve inflation. Disadvantages include poor ventilation-perfusion matching, lower cardiac output, and lung injury. Increased chest pressure reduces blood return to the heart. Barotrauma results from high pressures, and volutrauma occurs from repeated alveolar collapse and reopening. Air flows to the upper lung areas, while blood flows to the lower regions, increasing the dead space.

Other options:

Option A: Invasive mechanical ventilation occurs via a tracheal or tracheostomy tube after endotracheal intubation.

Option C: A non-rebreather mask has a one-way valve that allows inhalation from the reservoir bag while preventing exhaled gas from re-entering, thus avoiding rebreathing. Though theoretically it is capable of 100% FiO2, its practical FiO2 is closer to 80% due to mask leaks. 

An image showing a non-rebreather mask is given below:



Option D: An oxygen hood is a plastic dome or box with warmed and humidified oxygen inside.

An image showing an oxygen hood is given below:

questions.text: 41. After a recent event of severe floods in a metropolitan city, the local government has planned to implement certain measures which include floodwater diversion and storage, building new underground sewage lines with increased capacity, performing land surveys, and limit the construction of new buildings in flood-impacted areas. The given measures are part of which of the following phases of disaster management?
questions.solution:
The measures given in the question, are part of disaster mitigation.

Disaster mitigation includes measures taken to prevent hazards from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies. Some of these measures include:

* Flood mitigation

* Land-use planning

* Improved building codes

* Reduction and protection of vulnerable populations or structures.

Mitigation measures aim to reduce the vulnerability of the system. It complements the disaster preparedness and response activities.

Other options:

Option A: Disaster response includes activities such as rescue and first aid, field care, triage, etc.

Option B: Disaster rehabilitation refers to measures that lead to the restoration of pre-disaster conditions. Some of these measures include water supply restoration, food safety, basic sanitation, personal hygiene, and vector control.

Option D: Disaster preparedness is a long-term plan with ongoing multisectoral activities, which include the development of policies or programs for disaster management, prevention, mitigation, preparedness, response, rehabilitation, and reconstruction. The measures taken will ensure that the country is well prepared to face any future disasters and effectively prevent or manage to reduce the impact.

Disaster management cycle:

questions.text: 42. A patient presented with blunt abdominal trauma due to a road traffic accident. On eFAST, liver trauma was suspected. The patient was stable and underwent a CECT abdomen for further evaluation. On scan, a subcapsular hematoma of 10% surface area was noticed. The patient was put under conservative management. What is the grade of liver trauma?
questions.solution:
A subcapsular hematoma of <10% surface area is noticed in grade 1 of liver injury.

Liver injury is most commonly seen after blunt abdominal trauma. Mechanisms of blunt liver injury include compression with direct parenchymal damage and shearing forces, which tear hepatic tissue and disrupt vascular and ligamentous attachments.

The American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Liver Injury scale is shown below:



A visual representation of Liver injury grade is shown below:



In an unstable patient, only eFAST is done, while in a stable patient, a CECT abdomen is done as part of the investigation. In cases of major bleeding, initial management involves perihepatic packing and resuscitation. If bleeding is controlled, damage control laparotomy, possible angioembolization, and ICU care are considered. If bleeding persists, a Pringle manoeuvre followed by selective vessel ligation and omental packing follows.

In minor bleeding, topical agents, suturing, or electrocautery are used; if ineffective, the Pringle manoeuvre is the next step. Continued bleeding after all interventions may require vascular isolation with a shunting procedure and ICU care.

questions.text: 43. Which of the following toxins affects the spinal cord?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Gelsemium acts on the spinal cord.

Gelsemium is a systemic toxin with neurotoxic effects specific to the spinal cord. It is an ergot-type alkaloid, which acts as a CNS depressant. It is often used in homeopathy, and in large doses, can cause paralysis and death from respiratory failure.

The given image shows flowers of Gelsemium:



Other options: 

Option A- Curare is a type of neurotoxic agent that affects the peripheral nervous system and causes muscle paralysis. It acts by blocking peripheral postsynaptic ACh receptors, causing progressive flaccid paralysis, ultimately leading to respiratory failure.

Option B - Ricin is an organic irritant poison. The main toxic element of the castor oil plant is ricin, a toxalbumin. It exerts its toxicity by entering cells and inhibiting protein synthesis, leading to diarrhea.

Option D- Oleander has its main toxic effect on the cardiovascular system. It acts like digitalis, which can produce malignant dysrhythmias and cardiac failure, cardiac arrest, and convulsions with a lethal dose.

The given image below shows the flowers of Pink oleander/Nerium oleander:



The given image shows a flower of Yellow Oleander/Cerebra thevetia:



Pearl PM2106: Plant poisons

Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed) : Flower and fruit are poisonous



Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

questions.text: 44. A 68-year-old man comes to the ER with complaints of dizziness and multiple episodes of syncope for the past 2 days. On examination, his heart rate is 38 beats per minute. His ECG shows complete AV dissociation. Which of the following JVPs corresponds to this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with bradycardia and ECG findings of complete atrioventricular dissociation is suggestive of complete heart block. The JVP in this scenario typically shows cannon A waves as depicted in image 4. 

Complete heart block (CHB) presents with clinical features directly related to bradycardia, such as syncope and fatigue, dizziness, worsening of heart failure, and angina. An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows no relation between QRS complexes and P waves, and P waves are more numerous than QRS complexes, indicating complete AV dissociation. Permanent pacing is the treatment of choice in CHB. 

Cannon a waves are seen in:

* Atrioventricular dissociation/complete heart block

* Right atrial contraction against a closed tricuspid valve 

Below are the images showing an ECG and JVP seen in complete heart block:





Other options: 

Option A: Graph 1 illustrates the JVP waves of constrictive pericarditis, characterized by rapid descent of both x and y waves.



Option B: Graph 2 illustrates the absent a waves seen in atrial fibrillation.



Option C: Graph 3 illustrates prominent v waves seen in tricuspid regurgitation.



Pearl PM2416: JVP waveform and the abnormalities



1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation


 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade


 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation


 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade


Pearl PM1204: Types of Heart block

questions.text: 45. Which vein is not involved in Mondor’s disease of the breast?
questions.solution:
The internal mammary vein is not involved in Mondor’s disease of the breast.

The veins frequently involved in Mondor’s disease are:

* The lateral thoracic vein

* The thoracoepigastric vein

* Superficial epigastric vein (least common)

Mondor’s disease is thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the anterior chest wall and breast. It is described as “string phlebitis” and is due to trauma or infection, or surgery of the anterior chest wall.

It presents as a tender, firm, cord-like structure over the anterior chest wall. When the skin over the breast is stretched by raising the arm, a narrow, shallow, subcutaneous groove alongside the cord is seen. It is a self-limiting disease, without any recurrence, complication or deformity. 

The clinical image of Mondor's disease is shown below:



Therapy for Mondor’s disease includes the liberal use of anti-inflammatory medications and application of warm compresses along the symptomatic vein. The process usually resolves within 4 to 6 weeks. When symptoms persist or are refractory to therapy, excision of the involved vein segment may be considered.

questions.text: 46. Which of the following effects of adrenaline would be blocked by phentolamine but not propranolol?
questions.solution:
Contraction of the dilator pupillae would be blocked by phentolamine but not propranolol.

The contraction of the dilator pupillae is mediated by α1 adrenergic receptors. Thus, propranolol, being a non-selective beta-blocker, has no inhibitory action on this effect of adrenaline. All the other options are mediated by β receptors, which can be blocked by propranolol.

questions.text: 47. A 17-year-old girl is evaluated for primary amenorrhea. She has normal breast development and pubic hair. On pelvic examination, no uterus is palpable. Ultrasound confirms uterine agenesis. Further workup reveals the presence of MURCS Syndrome. Which of the following is not typically associated with MURCS syndrome?
questions.solution:
Streak ovaries is not typically associated with MURCS (MÜllerian duct aplasia, Renal aplasia, Cervicothoracic Somite dysplasia) syndrome.

MURCS association is a variant of Mayer–Rokitansky–Küster–Hauser (MRKH) syndrome. It presents with primary amenorrhea, normal secondary sexual characteristics, absent uterus, and normal ovaries (46, XX karyotype)

MURCS association systemic anomalies typically include:

* Müllerian duct aplasia: absent uterus and upper vaginal agenesis, leading to primary amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characteristics (breasts, pubic hair). 

* Renal anomalies: unilateral renal agenesis, ectopic kidney, horseshoe kidney. (Option A)

* Cervicothoracic vertebral anomalies: fusion, scoliosis, Klippel–Feil. (Option B)

Short stature can be seen due to skeletal anomalies, scoliosis, or vertebral fusions. (Option C)

In MURCS, ovaries develop normally because they arise from the genital ridge, independent of Müllerian structures. Hence, patients show normal breast and pubic hair development.

 Streak ovaries is instead seen in Turner syndrome (45,XO) or Swyer syndrome (46,XY pure gonadal dysgenesis), where secondary sexual characteristics are absent due to estrogen deficiency.

questions.text: 48. You are performing a clinical test on a patient as depicted in the image. What part of the brain serves as a center for this function?
questions.solution:
This image shows a normal pupillary reflex. The centre for this reflex is the pretectal nucleus.

The pupillary light reflex pathway involves several components, with the pretectal nucleus in the midbrain serving as the central integrative centre for the reflex. When light is shone into one eye, it causes bilateral constriction of the pupils, a response known as the pupillary light reflex. This reflex has two components:

1) Direct light reflex: constriction of the pupil in the eye being illuminated. 2) Consensual light reflex: constriction of the pupil in the opposite eye.

Light is detected by retinal photoreceptors (rods and cones), and signals travel via the optic nerve (CN II) to the optic chiasma, where nasal fibres cross. These continue in the optic tract to the pretectal nucleus in the midbrain. Temporal fibres remain uncrossed and also reach the pretectal nucleus. The pretectal nucleus, which mediates the pupillary light reflex, sends bilateral signals to the motor nuclei.

From each pretectal nucleus, fibres are sent to both Edinger-Westphal nuclei (bilaterally). This bilateral connection ensures that shining light in one eye causes both pupils to constrict (direct and consensual response).

The Edinger-Westphal nucleus (part of the oculomotor nuclear complex) sends preganglionic parasympathetic fibres via the oculomotor nerve (CN III). These fibres synapse in the ciliary ganglion. Postganglionic fibres then travel through short ciliary nerves to innervate the sphincter pupillae muscle, causing pupillary constriction.

The image below depicts pupillary reflex pathway:

questions.text: 49. Discharge from the baroreceptors cause inhibition of:
questions.solution:
Baroreceptors causes inhibition of the rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM). 

Baroreceptor Reflex

* Increased BP→ stimulation of baroreceptors → stimulation of NTS → inhibition of RVLM → inhibition of sympathetic system

* Stimulation of NTS also stimulates CVC → parasympathetic stimulation

* Net effect = sympathetic inhibition and parasympathetic stimulation → decreased HR and BP

questions.text: 50. The biological value of a food substance is 800 and its digestibility coefficient is 12. Calculate its Net Protein Utilization and identify the food substance.
questions.solution:
96, and the food substance is an egg.

NPU = (Biological value of a food substance x Digestability coefficient) / 100 = (800x12) / 100 = 96. 

Eggs have the highest NPU value, and that is why it is considered a reference protein. 

A few important food substances whose NPU are to be remembered:

(Different books give different values; these values are mentioned considering Park's textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition)

* Egg - 100

* Cow milk - 75

* Meat - 80

* Rice - 65

* Groundnut/ pulses - 50

Net protein utilization is used to describe the percentage of nitrogen retained in the body compared to nitrogen intake.

Note: The NPU of the Indian diet is between 50 and 80.

Egg contains all nutrients except carbohydrates and vitamin C.

A 60 gm egg contains:

* 6 g Fat

* 6 g Protein

* 30 mg Calcium

* 1.5 mg Iron

* 70 Kcal Energy

The cholesterol content is 250 mg/ egg. Egg protein has all 9 Amino acids needed for the body in the right proportions and hence it is considered as "Reference Protein". A boiled egg is nutritionally superior to raw egg. Boiling destroys avidin, a substance that prevents the body from absorbing Biotin.

Pearl PM2154: Assessment of Protein

Protein quality: Assessed by comparing with reference protein i.e egg protein.

* Amino acid score:

* Net protein utilization

A) Amino acid score: It is a measure of the concentration of each essential amino acid in the protein to be tested, expressed as a percentage of that amino acid in the reference protein.



 Digestible indispensable amino acid score (DIAAS) is the best indicator of protein quality. It is defined as follows:



B) Net protein utilization: It is a product of digestibility coefficient and biological value divided by 100. 



Protein quantity: It is assessed by protein energy ratio.

questions.text: 51. Which of the following is a false statement concerning puerperal involution?

choices.text: Immediately after delivery, the fundus is just below the umbilicus
Total number of myocytes decreases drastically postpartum
Uterus becomes a pelvice organ by the end of 2 weeks postpartum
Sonographically, uterus returns to pregravid size by 8 weeks postpartum

questions.solution:
The total number of myocytes doesn't decrease drastically postpartum.

The total number of myocytes does not decrease appreciably; rather, their size decreases markedly during the postpartum period.

Changes occurring during puerperal involution:

* Immediately after delivery, the fundus is just below the umbilicus (20 weeks of gestational age).

* After 24 hours of delivery, the height of the uterus decreases by 1.25cm/day.

* The uterus becomes a pelvic organ by the end of 2 weeks.

* The uterus returns to its normal size (pre-pregnant size) by the end of 8 weeks.

* Involution occurs due to a decrease in the size of muscle fibres (not the number).

questions.text: 52. A term neonate is born to a mother with gestational diabetes. On examination the baby had tremors, cyanosis and a high-pitched cry. On temperature evaluation hypothermia was noted. Blood sample is collected by heel prick. The initial blood glucose was 35mg/dl. What is the next step in the management of this baby?
questions.solution:
In a symptomatic baby born to a mother with gestational diabetes, if the blood glucose is below 45mg/dl, a bolus of 2 mL/kg of 10% dextrose should be given immediately.

The WHO defines neonatal hypoglycemia as a blood glucose level of less than 45 mg/dl (2.2 mmol/L). According to the AIIMS NICU protocol 2019, a blood glucose level (BGL) of less than 40 mg/ dl (plasma glucose <45 mg/dl) has been taken as the operation threshold for intervention.

Newborns of diabetic mothers are at a high risk of developing neonatal hypoglycemia due to hyperinsulinemia, which increases glucose consumption, especially 2-3 hours after birth. If a heel prick blood sample shows blood glucose <45 mg/dL on a reagent strip, treatment for hypoglycemia should be initiated. However, due to the high false-positive rates of reagent strips, laboratory confirmation of hypoglycemia is recommended.

Clinical manifestations can range from asymptomatic to severe symptoms like stupor, tremors, cyanosis, convulsions, apneic spells, a weak and high-pitched cry, lethargy, feeding difficulties, sweating, sudden pallor, hypothermia, and, rarely, cardiac arrest.

Other options:

Option A: Frequent feeding alone is insufficient in a symptomatic neonate, as oral intake may not correct neuroglycopenia quickly.

Option C: IV glucose infusion without an initial bolus may delay correction in a symptomatic baby.

Option D: Glucose monitoring only is inappropriate because the neonate is already symptomatic and at risk of seizures, brain injury, or permanent neurological damage if hypoglycemia persists.

questions.text:
53. Which of the following are correct about the superantigen Toxic shock syndrome toxin-1?

* It does not require T-cells to cause hypergammaglobulinemia

* It nonspecifically bridges MHCs of APCs and T cells

* It triggers a cytokine storm

* It is produced by Staphylococcus aureus
questions.solution:
The correct statements about Toxic-shock syndrome toxin-1 are 2, 3, and 4.

Superantigens are antigens that act through the variable β region of the T cell receptors that activate T helper cells non-specifically. They do this by bridging the major histocompatibility complex (MHC-II) of antigen-presenting cells (APCs) and T-cells (statement-2).

This non-specific activation of T cells triggers a massive release of cytokines, referred to as a "cytokine storm," releasing inflammatory mediators like interferon γ, IL-1, IL-6, TNF-α, and TNF-β (statement-3).

These mediators, in turn, can lead to B-cell polyclonal activation, resulting in increased secretion of nonspecific antibodies/hypergammaglobulinemia. Toxic shock syndrome toxin-1, a superantigen produced by Staphylococcus aureus that causes toxic shock syndrome (statement-4).

T-independent antigens are certain antigens, such as bacterial capsules, flagella, and LPS (lipopolysaccharide), that do not require the assistance of T cells and APCs. They directly bind to immunoglobulin receptors on B cells, leading to polyclonal stimulation of B cells and an increased secretion of nonspecific antibodies/hypergammaglobulinemia (statement-1).

questions.text: 54. A 60-year-old patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Postoperatively, on day 3, bile was present in the drain, and a biliary duct injury was suspected. On further evaluation, the bilirubin is raised. The patient is presently in a debilitated state. What is the next best line of management?

choices.text: Repair of biliary tract over T-tube

questions.solution:
Percutaneous trans hepatic biliary drainage will be the best line of management in this case.

In case of an iatrogenic biliary duct injury identified post-operatively on day 3, presenting with bilious drainage into the subhepatic drain and raised bilirubin levels (possibly due to stricture formation), percutaneous trans hepatic biliary drainage will control the infection and reduce the inflammation. ERCP with stenting is done after this step.

An image showing percutaneous trans hepatic biliary drainage (PTBD) is given below:



Biliary duct injury can occur either due to laparoscopic or open cholecystectomy. They can be identified intraoperatively or postoperatively.

Management of bile duct injury is shown in the image below:



The Strasberg classification of bile duct injury is a widely used system to anatomically define these injuries by location.

questions.text: 55. A 56-year-old diabetic is admitted to the ICU for treatment of community-acquired pneumonia. Which of the following clinical examination findings is not likely to be associated with right lower lobe pneumonia?

choices.text: Dull note on percussion over the consolidation
Absent breath sounds over the consolidation
Increased vocal resonance over the consolidation

questions.solution:
Absent breath sounds over the consolidation is not likely to be associated with right lower lobe pneumonia.

In pneumonia, alveoli are filled with fluid (consolidation), allowing airway sounds to transmit more clearly to the chest wall. This results in louder, harsher bronchial breath sounds instead of the normal muffled vesicular sounds.

The following findings are seen in a consolidation:

* Dull percussion note (Option A)

* Bronchial breath sounds

* Increased vocal resonance (Option C)

* No mediastinal shift/Midline trachea (Option D)

questions.text: 56. A 55-year-old man presented with lethargy, weight loss, and massive splenomegaly. Investigations revealed pancytopenia. A haematological malignancy was suspected. A peripheral smear showed cells positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase. Identify the correct CD marker and the cell of origin of this malignancy.
questions.solution:
Hematological malignancy with tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase-positive cells is most likely to be hairy cell leukemia. The cell of origin of hairy cell leukemia is the memory B cell. 

The markers expressed in hairy cell leukemia include the usual B-cell markers- CD-19 and 20, and specific markers such as CD 11c, CD 25, CD103, and annexin A1.

Hairy cell leukemia is a distinctive B cell neoplasm, that predominantly affects middle-aged males. Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase is the cytochemical stain characteristically shown by leukemic hairy cells. These cells are called so because of the fine hair-like projections on their surface as shown below.

On peripheral blood smear, hairy cells have round or reniform nuclei and moderate amounts of pale blue cytoplasm with thread or bleb-like extension. In the bone marrow, these cells are usually trapped in a mesh of reticulin fibers and so it is difficult to aspirate and hence termed a dry tap. 

The classic hairy cells can be seen in the slide is shown below:



Patients commonly present with massive splenomegaly due to infiltration of the leukemic cells. Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement can also be seen. There can be atypical monocytopenia, due to which these patients experience an increased incidence of atypical mycobacterial infections. These tumors respond well to chemotherapy and BRAF (B-type Raf proto-oncogene) inhibitors, and they have an excellent prognosis.

Other options:

Options A and D: CD3 and CD5 are markers of T cells.

Option C: CD20 is found on most mature B cells, including naive and memory types. Naive B cells are linked to some lymphomas, like DLBCL and follicular lymphoma. Although Hairy cell leukemia cells express CD20, their key marker is CD25, and they originate from memory B cells.

questions.text: 57. A 40-year-old male working in animal husbandry presented in OPD with painful, edematous, and erythematous lesions on his hands and was diagnosed with Erysipeloid disease. The bacteria responsible for the disease show intrinsic resistance to which of the following antibiotics?
questions.solution:
Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae, the causative organism of erysipeloid, is intrinsically resistant to vancomycin. This resistance is unusual because most Gram-positive bacteria are vancomycin-sensitive.

Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae is a Gram-positive, non-spore-forming bacillus transmitted through direct inoculation into skin cuts of persons handling fish, meat, or animal products. It produces painful, erythematous, and edematous lesions typically localized to the hands and fingers. Lesions are typically well-demarcated, raised, and violaceous. Systemic spread is rare but may lead to endocarditis or arthritis.

The organism is highly sensitive to penicillin, which remains the drug of choice (Option B). For patients allergic to penicillin, erythromycin or cephalosporins are effective alternatives (Option A & D)

questions.text: 58. The translocation characteristic of follicular lymphoma is:
questions.solution:
The majority of the follicular lymphomas have a characteristic (14;18) translocation that fuses the BCL2 gene on chromosome 18 to the IgH locus on chromosome 14.

This chromosomal rearrangement results in the overexpression of the BCL2 protein, which is an inhibitor of apoptosis that contributes to cell survival.

Morphologically, the lymphoma shows a nodular or mixed nodular and diffuse pattern in lymph nodes, composed of small cleaved cells (centrocytes) and larger activated cells (centroblasts), with centrocytes being more common. 

Bone marrow involvement is commonly seen. The spleen and liver are often affected as well. Immunophenotypically, the tumor cells resemble germinal center B cells and express CD19, CD20, CD10, BCL6, surface immunoglobulin, and BCL2. 

Clinically, patients usually present with painless, widespread lymph node enlargement. Extranodal involvement is rare. Treatment is typically conservative and includes low-dose chemotherapy or immunotherapy when symptoms develop.

In 30% to 50% of cases, the follicular lymphoma can transform into a more aggressive diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, which carries a poor prognosis.

questions.text: 59. Identify the instrument shown.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown is salter scale.

It is accepted by UNICEF and the central govt. as a mechanical machine used for weighing children from age 1-5 yr. It is donated by UNICEF in various anganwadi centres of different states for weighing children and recording the growth monitoring chart.

questions.text: 60. A 50-year-old farmer, after mistakenly ingesting certain seeds on his farm, presented with multiple episodes of seizures. During the seizure episode, he arched his back, lying on the bed and gave a facial expression as shown in the image below. He was conscious and oriented between the episodes. The toxin extracted from this particular seed binds to which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of ingestion of some seeds with complaints of seizures and a typical facial expression (risus sardonicus), as shown in the image, is suggestive of strychnine poisoning, which binds to the glycine receptors.

Strychnine poisoning is caused by ingestion of strychnine seeds. Strychnine is a competitive antagonist of glycine at the postganglionic receptors in the motor neurons of the anterior horn of the spinal cord. This leads to release excitation and widespread convulsions all over the body. Patients typically present with risus sardonicus, which results from the contraction of the jaws and facial muscles.

Convulsions are clonic initially but eventually become tonic and are most marked in anti-gravity muscles so that the body typically arches in hyperextension, the posture known as opisthotonus. If the spasm involves the abdominal muscles, the body bends forward (emprosthotonos) or to the side (pleurosthotonus).

Patient remains conscious and lucid between the episodes. If death is preceded by a severe convulsion, it causes an increase in the body temperature known as postmortem caloricity.

The first step in the management is to control convulsions with benzodiazepines or barbiturates. Activated charcoal can be used to adsorb unabsorbed poison after a thorough stomach wash. Acidification of urine can be done to increase the excretion of strychnine.

Note: Ketamine inhibits the postsynaptic glutamate binding protein N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) receptor non-competitively and causes dissociative anaesthesia.

Pearl PM0900: Signs and Symptoms of Strychnine Poisoning

The clinical features of strychnine poisoning are:

* Convulsions - clonic-tonic type

* Reflex increased

* Awful taste

* Mind is conscious

* Pupils dilated

* Opisthotonos: arching back

* Emprosthotonos: arching forward

* Pleurothotonus: bending sideward

* Risus Sardonicus - fixed contraction of the facial muscles resulting in a peculiar distorted grin.

Strychnine poisoning case may resemble tetanus.

Although a poison, in relatively low doses it can be used as a medical stimulant for respiration.

Strychnine plant



Strychnine seeds

questions.text: 61. In a given population, total births in a year are 5100. 100 babies were still born and 250 neonates died within 28 days of life. What is the neonatal mortality rate in this population?
questions.solution:
Neonatal mortality rate = Number of deaths of children under 28 days of age in a year x 1000/Total live births in the same year

The total live births in this scenario are 5100 – 100 = 5000 live births

NMR = 250 x 1000/5000 = 50

Pearl PM1700: Neonatal Mortality Rate

* Neonatal deaths are those that occur during the neonatal period, commencing at birth and ending at 28 completed days after birth.

* NMR = Number of deaths of children under 28 days of age in a year x 1000/Total live births in the same year

* Main causes of neonatal death are prematurity (leading cause), birth asphyxia, intrapartum-related complications, sepsis, pneumonia, congenital anomalies, tetanus, diarrhea, etc.

* India’s NMR  is 20 per 1000 live births (SRS 2020)

questions.text: 62. A patient presented with complaints of vomiting and regurgitation of food. On thorough examination and investigation, she was diagnosed with a Hiatus hernia. Which among the following is not a type of Hiatal hernia?
questions.solution:
Spigelian hernia is not a type of hiatal hernia. 

Spigelian hernias are a ventral hernia of the abdomen that occur through a defect in the spigelian fascia (aponeurosis of transversus abdominis), often below the umbilicus near the rectus sheath. They may pass through the internal oblique and lie beneath the external oblique aponeurosis.

Hiatus hernia is the protrusion of any abdominal structure other than the esophagus into the thoracic cavity through a widening of the hiatus of the diaphragm.

Types:

1. Sliding (Type I) (Option A)

* Most common (~90%).

* The gastroesophageal junction (GEJ) and proximal stomach slide upward into the thorax.

* Associated strongly with GERD.

2. Rolling/True paraesophageal (Type II) (Option B)

* The GEJ remains in place, but the gastric fundus herniates alongside the esophagus.

* Risk of complications includes volvulus, strangulation, and bleeding.

3. Mixed (Type III) (Option C)

* Combination of sliding and rolling: both GEJ and part of the fundus herniate.

4. Type IV/Giant paraesophageal hernias: Other abdominal structures (colon, spleen, pancreas) herniate through the hiatus along with the stomach.

Note: Hiatal hernias from types 2 to 4 are also referred to as paraesophageal hernias and present with gastroesophageal obstructive symptoms.

questions.text: 63. On reading the CTG below, you would conclude that it shows:
questions.solution:
The given CTG shows prolonged deceleration.

Prolonged deceleration is the abrupt decrease in FHR of 15 beats or greater below the baseline, and it lasts > 2 min but < 10 min. If this is a decrease in FHR lasting > 10 min, then it is considered a baseline change.

In the tracing below, you can see around 30 small boxes from the beginning of the deceleration, which equates to 30x 10 = 300s, ie, 5 min. Normal fetal heart rate ranges between 110 and 160 bpm.



Types of decelerations:

* Early decelerations (Type I Dips): Onset, nadir, and recovery of deceleration coincide with the beginning, peak, and ending of uterine contraction, respectively. It suggests fetal head compression resulting in vagal nerve activation.



* Late decelerations (Type II Dips, option B): These begin after the onset of the uterine contraction. Usually, the onset, nadir, and recovery of the deceleration occur after the start, peak, and end of the uterine contraction, respectively. The peak occurs 20 seconds after the peak of the contraction, and FHR returns to normal after the contraction is over. It suggests uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.



* Variable deceleration (option A): It is associated with umbilical cord compression and may disappear with the change in position of the patient. It has an acceleration at the beginning and also at the end of the deceleration. These accelerations are described as the shoulders of the deceleration. It is the most common type of deceleration.





* Sinusoidal pattern: It has a stable baseline FHR with fixed or absent baseline variability lasting > 20 min, thus resembling a sine wave. Accelerations are absent. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal hypoxia (acidosis). It may occur when narcotics are given to the mother.



Pearl PM1825: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression



 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia



 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: 64. A 28-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of clonic jerky movement of the right side of his mouth which then progresses to involve his right arm. These episodes usually last for 2-3 minutes and the patient is wide awake during these episodes. Which area of the brain would show a lesion on imaging of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is most consistent with a focal seizure with intact awareness due to a lesion in the left lateral motor cortex.

The patient’s jerks begin in the mouth and then spread to the right arm, a pattern known as the Jacksonian march. This directly corresponds to the somatotopic arrangement of the motor homunculus; the face and mouth are represented on the most lateral portion of the precentral gyrus, with the upper limb located just superior to this region. Because seizures are contralateral, the right-sided motor involvement points to a lesion in the left hemisphere.



Other options:

Option A: The left medial motor cortex primarily controls movements of the contralateral lower limb and trunk, not the face and arm. Hence, a lesion here would typically cause leg-dominant symptoms, not oral or arm clonic jerks.

Option C: The supplementary motor cortex, located on the medial surface of the hemisphere, is involved in planning and initiating complex bilateral movements rather than producing focal clonic activity. Seizures here present more with tonic posturing or speech arrest, not a Jacksonian march starting in the mouth.

Option D: The temporal lobe is a key site for focal seizures, but its manifestations are different—they often involve automatisms, sensory auras and impaired awareness. Pure motor seizures confined to the mouth and arm without alteration in consciousness are not typical of temporal lobe epilepsy.

questions.text: 65. A patient complains of hair loss over the back of her head. On examination, a 2 cm area of complete, smooth, circular hair loss with distinct margins and exclamation mark hairs is seen without scaling or inflammation. On further examination, the nail finding is shown in the image below. Which of the following is false about the condition responsible for this finding?

choices.text: Condition can be associated with thyroiditis

questions.solution:
The image shows fine stippled pitting of nails, and the non-scarring type of hair loss associated with it is alopecia areata. The false statement about it is that non-pigmented hair is primarily affected.

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease that causes non-scarring hair loss. It is a T-cell-mediated inflammatory disease (option C). It is associated with several autoimmune diseases, including thyroiditis (option B), lupus erythematosus, vitiligo, and psoriasis.

It mainly affects the scalp, but can also affect the beard, eyebrows, and eyelashes. In some cases, this progresses to a total loss of scalp hair (alopecia totalis) or a loss of all hair on the body (alopecia universalis). The lesions of alopecia areata are characterized by a smooth, circumscribed patch of alopecia. Some broken hairs can be seen, which are called exclamation marks (option D). They are easily extractable. It preferentially affects pigmented hair and spares non-pigmented or white hair (option A).

A perifollicular and intrafollicular inflammatory cell infiltrate that is focused in and around the hair bulb can be seen in anagen follicles near the edges of growing regions of alopecia areata. The predominant component of the inflammatory infiltration is activated T lymphocytes, with predominant CD4 cells, macrophages, Langerhans cells, and cells that exhibit NK cell markers.

Spontaneous remission occurs in a majority of patients with hair loss that is patchy and is of shorter duration. Topical steroids like clobetasol can be useful in patchy alopecia areata. Intralesional steroids are the most effective treatment for patchy alopecia areata. 

Severe and long-standing alopecia areata requires oral corticosteroids.

The image below shows a clinical picture of alopecia areata with a patch of alopecia with a smooth surface of the scalp:

questions.text: 66. A child is brought to the doctor with severe agonizing, burning pain in the hands, feet, and proximal extremities. On examination, he has telangiectatic skin lesions, particularly between the umbilicus and knees. The ophthalmic examination also reveals corneal opacity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Fabry disease.

Fabry disease is an X-linked inborn error of glycosphingolipid metabolism because of deficient activity of α-galactosidase A enzyme. This enzyme deficiency leads to accumulations of neutral glycosphingolipids, primarily globotriaosylceramide, especially in the plasma and lysosomes of vascular endothelial and smooth muscle cells, cardiac myocytes, and renal podocytes. The features of Fabry disease include:

* Angiokeratomas- telangiectatic skin lesions characteristically seen densest between the umbilicus and knees called the bathing trunk area

* Hypohidrosis - decreased sweating

* Corneal and lenticular opacities (Cornea verticillata)

* Painful acroparesthesias 

* Fabry crises - severe agonizing pain in the hands, feet, and proximal extremities

* Urinary examination shows lipid inclusions with birefringent maltese cross

 Given below is the image of cornea verticillata.



Other options:

 

Option B: Niemann-Pick disease occurs due to the deficiency of sphingomyelinase. Affected children exhibit a combination of hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delay, reticular or nodular infiltration in the lungs, and retinal cherry-red spots.

 

Option C: Gaucher disease occurs due to the deficiency of β-glucosidase. It commonly has a combination of growth retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and Erlenmeyer flask deformity of the distal femur. Histology shows the presence of Gaucher cells, which have a characteristic wrinkled-paper appearance resulting from the presence of intracytoplasmic substrate inclusions. The intelligence of the child is normal.

The image below shows Gaucher cells.



Option D: Tay-Sachs disease occurs due to a deficiency of hexosaminidase A. Affected children present with seizures, developmental delay, increased startle response, macrocephaly, and cherry-red spots in the eye. Hepatosplenomegaly is rare.

Cherry red spots are commonly seen in Tay-Sachs disease, Sandhoff disease, generalized gangliosidoses, Niemann-Pick disease, metachromatic leukodystrophy, etc

The image below shows cherry red spot.

questions.text:
67. To plan blood transfusion in a patient, the medicine resident asks you to withdraw the patient's blood samples to send it to the IHBT department for blood grouping and cross-matching. The serum is needed for cross-matching and RBCs for blood grouping; considering this fact in mind, you will use which vacutainers?

Colors in the options indicate the caps of vacutainers

IHBT- immunohematology and blood transfusion
questions.solution:
Red and purple vacutainers are used for cross-matching and blood grouping.

Red vacutainer provides serum, which has got antibodies of the patient which will be required for cross-matching.

Purple vacutainer provides RBCs, which has got antigens of the patient which will be required for blood-grouping.



Pearl PM1867: Anticoagulants in Vacutainers and their Uses

questions.text:
68. Match the different enzymes involved in DNA replication with their action

1. DNA polymerases 

 a. ATP-driven DNA unwinding
2. Topoisomerases  b. DNA polymerization
3. DNA primase

c. Reduce torsional strain from helicase
4. Helicases d. Initiates synthesis of RNA primers
questions.solution:
The correct match of enzymes involved in DNA replication is 

Classes of enzymes involved in DNA replication:

Enzymes Function
1. DNA polymerases b. Deoxynucleotide polymerization
2. Topoisomerases c. Reduce torsional strain from helicase
3. DNA primase d. Initiates synthesis of RNA primers
4. Helicases  a. ATP-driven DNA unwinding


DNA polymerases are the enzymes responsible for synthesizing new DNA strands during replication. They add deoxynucleotides to the free 3’-OH end of a primer, using the template strand as a guide. Pol III (prokaryotes) and Pol δ/ε (eukaryotes) are the main replicative enzymes, with proofreading activity.

Unwinding of DNA by helicase creates positive supercoils ahead of the replication fork. Topoisomerases reduce this torsional strain. Topoisomerase I cuts a single strand of DNA, allowing it to rotate and relieve supercoiling without ATP. Topoisomerase II (including bacterial DNA gyrase) cuts both strands and passes another DNA segment through, requiring ATP.

DNA primase is a specialized RNA polymerase that synthesizes short RNA primers (~10 nucleotides) complementary to the DNA template. These primers provide the free 3’-OH group necessary for DNA polymerases to begin elongation. On the lagging strand, primase is essential for initiating each Okazaki fragment.

Helicases are motor proteins that unwind the double helix by breaking hydrogen bonds between complementary bases at the replication fork. They require ATP hydrolysis for energy and are critical for opening up the DNA so that replication machinery can proceed.

Pearl PM1060: Enzymes Involved in DNA Replication

Prokaryotic DNA replication enzymes and their function:

Enzyme Function
DNA Polymerase I (Pol I) Gap filling following DNA replication, repair, and recombination
DNA polymerase II (Pol II) DNA proofreading and repair
DNA polymerase III (Pol III)

Processive, leading strand synthesis, DNA proofreading
DnaG

Primase 
Helicase ATP-driven processive unwinding of DNA.
Primase Initiates synthesis of RNA primers.
Topoisomerase Relieve torsional strain that results from helicase-induced unwinding.
Single-strand binding proteins (SSBs) Prevents premature reannealing of dsDNA.
DNA ligase Seals the single strand nick between the nascent chain and Okazaki fragments on lagging strand.


 

Eukaryotic DNA polymerases:

Eukaryotic DNA Polymerases Functions Proofreading
α  Primase (initiates DNA synthesis) -
β DNA repair -

γ

 Mitochondrial DNA synthesis +
 δ  Processive, lagging strand synthesis(forms and elongates Okazaki fragments from primer) +
 ε  Processive, leading strand synthesis +

questions.text: 69. A 6-year-old boy was planned for strabismus surgery. Induction was uneventful. During the surgery, while grasping a muscle, the patient developed arrhythmia and bradycardia. Which of the following is the first step in the management of the above patient?
questions.solution:
The above condition describes the oculo-cardiac reflex. Cessation of surgical stimulation is the first step in managing the patient described above.

Management of the oculocardiac reflex includes :

* Cessation of surgical stimulation until the heart rate returns to normal.

* Confirmation of adequate ventilation, oxygenation, and depth of anaesthesia (Option B).

* Administration of intravenous glycopyrrolate or atropine (Option C). Epinephrine may be required to treat severe bradycardia or asystole (Option D).

* Infiltration of the rectus muscles with local anaesthetic.

Oculo-cardiac reflex is a trigeminovagal response leading to bradycardia or arrhythmias due to pressure on the eyeball or traction on extraocular muscles, especially the medial rectus. Oculocardiac reflex consists of a trigeminal (V1) afferent and a vagal efferent pathway. It is commonly seen in children during strabismus surgery. Opioids, hypoxia, and hypercapnia lead to its worsening. This reflex can be reduced with the use of atropine, glycopyrrolate, or certain anaesthetics, such as ketamine.

Pearl PM0485: High Yield Points in Pediatric Anesthesia

* The narrowest part of the larynx in the infant is at the cricoid level, in administering anesthesia this may lead to Laryngeal edema, trauma to sub epiglottic region, post-operative stridor.

* Neonatal circumcision is done under General anesthesia.

* Oculocardiac reflex:

* Trigemino-vagal-reflex

* Causes-strabismus surgery, cataract surgery, enucleation, ocular trauma, retinal detachment surgery.

* Manifestation-bradycardia (most common)

* Treatment-temporary cessation surgery until heart rate increases, IV Atropine.

* Duchenne muscular dystrophy :

* High risk for malignant hyperthermia so succinyl choline and halothane should be avoided

* Choice of anesthesia is propofol, nitrous oxide for maintenance.

questions.text: 70. A man presents with a closed globe injury to the eye after a cricket ball hit him in the eye. Which of the following is a potential complication that can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Iridodialysis is a potential complication that can be seen in this patient with blunt trauma to the globe.

Blunt trauma to the eye is associated with a direct blow to the eyeball by fist/ball, or accidental blunt trauma can also occur in road traffic accidents. It produces damage to the eyeball either by direct impact on the globe or by compression wave force. Blunt Trauma to the eye is associated with:

1) Iridodialysis: Iridodialysis occurs due to the dehiscence of the iris from the ciliary body at its root. The pupil becomes D-shaped. The following image shows iridodialysis.



2) Rosette cataract: It is the most typical form of a concussion cataract.



3) Vossius ring: It is a circular ring of brown pigment seen on the anterior capsule and occurs due to the striking of the contracted pupillary margin against the crystalline lens.



4) Commotio retinae (Berlin’s oedema): It manifests as milky white cloudiness involving a considerable area of the posterior pole. A cherry red spot is seen in the foveal region.



Other features that can be seen -

* Injury to the cornea and sclera

* Traumatic hyphema

* Angle recession

* Vitreous hemorrhage

* Choroidal hemorrhage

* Retinal tear and detachment

* Traumatic glaucoma and hypotonia

Other options:

Option A: Sunflower cataract is seen in patients with Wilson’s disease.

Option C: Coloboma is a developmental defect of the iris leading to a gap/hole in the iris.

The image showing a coloboma is given below:



Option D: A snowflake cataract is seen in patients with diabetes mellitus.

Pearl PM0897: Diseases and Associated Cataracts - Images

Wilson's Disease/Chalcosis: Sunflower Cataract



Diabetes mellitus:  Snowflake cataract



Blunt trauma: May present as rosette-shaped cataract



Myotonic dystrophy - Christmas tree cataract

questions.text: 71. What method of sterilisation is used to sterilise the following equipment?
questions.solution:
The above image shows an upper GI endoscope, which is sterilized using glutaraldehyde. 

Glutaraldehyde is a type of liquid chemical sterilization method. It has an action similar to formaldehyde. It is especially effective against tubercle bacilli, fungi, and viruses. It does not affect the lenses of optical instruments and bone cement. Hence, it is used to sterilize endoscopes, cystoscopes, bronchoscopes, and rubber anaesthetic tubes. It can also be used for metal instruments.

The Spaulding classification classifies endoscopes as semi-critical devices, as they come in contact with intact mucosa and hence need at least high-level disinfection. 

Other options:

Option B: Autoclave (steam under pressure at 121°C for 15–20 minutes) is suitable for surgical instruments, dressings, rubber materials, and most culture media, but would damage heat-sensitive endoscopes.

Option C: Gamma radiation is a type of ionizing radiation that is a low-temperature sterilizing method used to sterilize mass-manufactured and pre-packed single-use disposables like syringes, catheters, and IV sets, but it is not practical for reusable instruments. 

Option D: Inspissation, which involves heating at 80–85°C for 3 successive days, is used exclusively for sterilizing egg-based culture media such as Lowenstein–Jensen medium for Mycobacterium tuberculosis and has no role in instrument sterilization.

Pearl PM1764: Methods of sterilisation

Method of disinfection or sterilisation Material
Red Heat Inoculating wire loop, tip of forceps
Incineration Contaminated clothes, animal carcasses, plastics like polythene
Hot air oven Glasswares, scalpels, forceps, cutting instruments, test tubes
Inspissator Heat labile culture media containing egg, sugar or serum
Autoclave Culture media, dressings, gloves, aprons, all instruments except sharps, suture materials except catgut
Isopropyl alcohol Clinical thermometers, stethoscopes, probes
Methyl alcohol Fungal spores

Beta propiolactone/

formaldehyde

 Fumigation of operating theatres, wards and labs
2% gluteraldehyde Cystoscopes, bronchoscopes, fibre-optic endoscopes, plastic ETT, face masks
Plasma sterilisation Arthroscopes, urethroscopes
Ethylene oxide Heart lung machines, respirators, dental equipments, sutures, books, clothings
Filtration (Seitz filters) Bacterial vaccines, intravenous solutions
5% cresol, hot air oven Sharp instruments

Ionising radiation

(Cold air sterilization)

 Catgut, swabs, plastic, syringes, needles, gloves, catheters, grafts
Chlorhexidine Disinfecting surgeon’s hands prior to surgery
Iodophor Disinfecting surgical site prior to surgery
70% ethanol Disinfectant skin prior to venepuncture or immunisation
Thiomersal Preservative in vaccine
Silver sulfadiazine Cleanse burn wounds
Hypochlorite Cleanup of blood spill from a patient with hepatitis B or C
Hydrogen peroxide Cleanse wounds

questions.text: 72. A patient with a history of multiple abdominal surgeries is taken up for a laparoscopic procedure. Your senior resident asks you to insert the port at the Palmer's point. Where would you insert the Veress needle?

choices.text: 3 cm below the left costal margin at the mid-clavicular line
7 cm below the left costal margin at the mid-clavicular line
3 cm below the left costal margin at the mid-axillary line
7 cm below the right costal margin at the mid-clavicular line

questions.solution:
Palmer's point is 3 cm below the left costal margin at the mid-clavicular line.

Most common site of insertion of port for creation of pneumoperitoneum is infraumbilical. But in patients with multiple adhesions, this is not preferred due to suspected adhesions.

In routine laparoscopy, there are two methods for establishing abdominal access during laparoscopic surgeries. One is the direct puncture technique and the other is the direct peritoneal access technique. Veress needle is used in direct puncture laparoscopy.

Direct puncture laparoscopy, the abdominal wall is grasped with towel clips or fingers to elevate the abdominal wall away from the underlying structures. Then a small incision is made in the umbilicus and insufflation is done with a Veress needle. While introducing the Veress needle, two distinct pops can be felt as the needle pierces the abdominal wall fascia and the peritoneum.

The umbilicus is the preferred location for introducing a Veress needle because the abdominal wall is thin at this location. Laparoscopic surgeries can be done under general anesthesia or local anesthesia; however, general anesthesia is preferred. Carbon dioxide(CO2) gas is usually used, and the maximum pressure is in the range of 14-15 mm Hg. But N2O is used if the procedure is done under local anesthesia. Insufflation with N2O is stopped at a pressure of 10 mmHg or when 2L of gas is insufflated.

The direct peritoneal access technique (Hasson technique) is done only occasionally. It is preferred for patients who have undergone previous abdominal surgeries as the small bowel may be adherent to the undersurface of the abdominal wound in such cases.

questions.text: 73. Name the incision in the figure.
questions.solution:
The incision shown in the figure is the Mercedes-Benz incision. It is a modification of the bilateral subcostal (Chevron) incision, with a vertical midline extension added upwards.

It allows a wider range of access compared to the Kocher incision or Chevron incision. It is used in surgeries requiring access to the upper abdomen, like esophagectomy, gastrectomy, bilateral adrenalectomy, liver resection, liver transplantation, and duodenal or biliary surgeries. 

Other options:

Option A: The Chevron incision refers to a bilateral subcostal incision that meets in the midline, forming an inverted “V” or rooftop appearance. It does not include the vertical extension, which is the defining feature of the Mercedes-Benz incision. It is shown below.



Option B: Rocky-Davis incision is a right iliac fossa transverse muscle-splitting incision, classically used for open appendectomy.

Option C: Clamshell incision is a bilateral anterolateral thoracotomy across the chest, used mainly for bilateral lung transplantation and mediastinal exposure. 

The image below depicts these incisions.

questions.text: 74. A 68-year-old man with hypertension presents to the emergency department with a severe nosebleed that started an hour ago. He is actively swallowing blood, and a trickle is seen in his oropharynx. After achieving hemodynamic stability and placing an anterior nasal pack, the bleeding continues. What is the next appropriate step in management?

choices.text: Placement of a posterior nasal pack
External ligation of anterior & posterior ethmoidal artery

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is consistent with posterior epistaxis, and in this case, the most appropriate management is the placement of a posterior nasal pack after first aid has been administered. 

  Anterior Epistaxis Posterior Epistaxis
Incidence More common  Less common
Site Mostly from Little’s area or the anterior part of the lateral wall of the nasal cavity Mostly from the posterosuperior part of the nasal cavity; it is often difficult to localise the bleeding point
Age Mostly occurs in children or young adults After 40 years age
Cause Mostly trauma Spontaneous, often due to hypertension or arteriosclerosis
Bleeding Usually mild, can be controlled by local pressure or an anterior pack Bleeding is severe and requires hospitalisation; a postnasal pack is often required


 

Management of epistaxis: 

* Initial step: Pinch nostrils for 5–10 mins (Hippocratic/Trotter’s method).

* Position: Sit upright, lean forward, breathe through mouth, and spit out blood.

* Visible bleeding point: Use chemical (silver nitrate) or electrocautery.

* Persistent bleeding:

             Use anterior packing (anterior bleed)

             Use posterior packing (posterior bleed)

* If packing fails:

              Do sphenopalatine artery ligation (endoscopic)               Maxillary artery ligation               Lastly, external carotid artery ligation

* Bleeding above middle turbinate: Ligate anterior/posterior ethmoidal arteries



Other options:

Option A: Chemical cauterization with silver nitrate is useful in anterior epistaxis when the bleeding point has been located. 

Option B: Urgent referral for endovascular embolization is the last line of management, done by an interventional radiologist through a femoral artery access to the maxillary artery. Both sides may be required for unilateral epistaxis because of cross-circulation. 

Option D: External ligation of the anterior & posterior ethmoidal artery line of management is also useful when more initial options fail, and is useful to control only anterosuperior epistaxis above the middle turbinate, which is not controlled by packing.

questions.text: 75. Which of the following side effect of sirolimus increase with use of cyclosporine?
questions.solution:
Nephrotoxicity due to sirolimus increases with the use of cyclosporine. 

Sirolimus, an mTOR inhibitor, is an immunosuppressive agent and is particularly effective against cutaneous malignancies. It is often the preferred immunosuppressant for transplant recipients with a history of cancer due to its antineoplastic activity.

While sirolimus alone is not typically considered nephrotoxic, its combination with cyclosporine significantly increases the risk of impaired kidney function compared to cyclosporine alone. 

Sirolimus can also worsen proteinuria and should be used cautiously in patients with existing significant proteinuria or a glomerular filtration rate below 30%. Other reported adverse effects include anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, oral mucositis, hypokalemia, gastrointestinal issues, and impaired wound healing.

The given image shows the mechanism of action of Sirolimus:



Other options:

Option B and C: Dyslipidemia and lymphocele are well‑known sirolimus toxicities, but they’re not exacerbated by cyclosporine.

Option D: Hyperkalemia is a more typical side effect of calcineurin inhibitors themselves (cyclosporine, tacrolimus), not sirolimus.

questions.text: 76. Which of the following is an accessory muscle of expiration?
questions.solution:
The internal intercostal muscles are accessory muscles of expiration.

The internal intercostal muscle runs obliquely downwards and backwards between adjacent ribs and acts to pull the ribs downward and inward, thereby reducing thoracic volume and facilitating expiration.

In normal quiet breathing, expiration is passive, driven by the elastic recoil of the lungs and the chest wall. In forced expiration, there is active recruitment of internal intercostals and abdominal wall muscles (rectus abdominis, transversus abdominis, obliques, quadratus lumborum) that help expel air.

Below is the image showing internal and external intercostal mucles:



Other options:

Option A: Sternocleidomastoid is an accessory muscle of inspiration. It elevates the sternum and clavicle during deep inspiration, increasing thoracic volume.

Option C: The external intercostal muscles are also inspiratory in function; they run obliquely downward and forward, elevating the ribs and expanding the thoracic cavity during inspiration.

Option D: The scalene muscles (anterior, middle, and posterior) are accessory inspiratory muscles. They act by elevating the 1st and 2nd ribs and stabilizing the upper rib cage, particularly during labored inspiration.

Inspiration (rib elevators)

Expiration (rib depressors)

Quiet respiration

Diaphragm (chief muscle)

External intercostals

Passive

Levator costarum

Serratus posterior superior
