questions.text: 77. The procedure depicted below is done at the gestational age of?
questions.solution:
The given image represents amniocentesis, which is done after 15 weeks of pregnancy. 

Amniocentesis is an invasive procedure for prenatal diagnosis done under ultrasound guidance. Fetal fibroblasts are obtained and sent for cytogenetic analysis. Early amniocentesis (12–14 weeks) is not recommended. It is used for cytogenetic and biochemical testing.

Other invasive prenatal diagnostic procedures done are –

Chorionic Villus Sampling (CVS)- It enables early genetic diagnosis via transcervical (10–13 weeks) or transabdominal (from 10 weeks) routes under ultrasound and provides results in 24–48 hours.

Risks include 1–2% fetal loss, limb defects if done before 10 weeks, bleeding, and false positives from mosaicism or contamination. Rh-negative women receive 50 µg anti-D immunoglobulin post-procedure.

Cordocentesis/Percutaneous Umbilical Blood Sampling (PUBS)- It is performed from 18 weeks under Doppler ultrasound guidance using a spinal needle to collect fetal blood from the umbilical vein. It helps diagnose fetal anemia, infections, bleeding disorders, and allows for treatments like transfusions.

Risks include fetal loss (1–2%), bleeding, bradycardia, infection, and preterm labor. Rh-negative women should receive 100 µg anti-D immunoglobulin.

Procedure Time
Chorionic Villus Sampling

Transcervical - 10–13 weeks

Transabdominal - 10 weeks to term
Amniocentesis After 15 weeks
Cordocentesis 18–20 weeks


The image below shows amniocentesis.



Pearl PM0780: Prenatal screening for Down’s syndrome

* USG findings

* Intrauterine growth retardation (so decreased blood flow)

* Choroid plexus cysts

* Increased nuchal translucency >3 mm

* Hypoplastic nasal bone

* Congenital heart defects

* Increased intestinal echogenicity

* Duodenal atresia

* Maternal serum markers

* Decreased: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), unconjugated estriol, pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)

* Increased: Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG), inhibin, neutrophil alkaline phosphatase

* Amniocentesis: 14th-18th week of pregnancy

* Chorionic villus sampling

* 10th to 12th week of pregnancy: Gives the diagnosis in the first trimester

questions.text: 78. A 29-year-old woman presents with infertility of 2 years duration. Her partner's semen analysis is normal. She undergoes intrauterine insemination (IUI), and fertilization is successful. The reproductive endocrinologist explains that this technique bypasses the normal site of sperm capacitation. Which of the following is the primary anatomical site where sperm capacitation normally occurs in natural conception?
questions.solution:
The primary anatomical site for sperm capacitation in natural conception is the female reproductive tract. 

Capacitation is the functional maturation of sperm that occurs after ejaculation, within the female reproductive tract, primarily in the uterus and fallopian tubes. It involves membrane changes, such as cholesterol efflux, increased membrane permeability, and preparation for the acrosome reaction. Capacitated sperm can then bind to the zona pellucida and fertilize the oocyte.

Other options:

Option A: Epididymis is the site of sperm maturation and motility acquisition, not capacitation.

Option B: The vas deferens transports the sperm and has no role in capacitation.

Option C: Sperm mixes with seminal fluid in the ejaculatory duct. No capacitation occurs here.

questions.text: 79. A 40-year-old construction worker involves in work where he gets repeatedly exposed to the noise of around 100 dB at the construction site. This could lead to ____
questions.solution:
Repeated exposure to the sound of 100 dB can lead to permanent hearing loss.

Effects of Noise Exposure

* Auditory effects

* Auditory fatigue appears at 90 dB and is greatest at 4000 Hz. Whistling and buzzing in ear occurs with auditory fatigue.

* Temporary deafness or hearing loss occurs after a single exposure to noise, usually at a frequency range of 4000 – 6000 Hz. It disappears after 24 hours following noise exposure.

* Permanent hearing loss can result after continuous or repeated exposure to noises around 100 dB. It occurs commonly as occupational hearing loss.

* Exposure to noise above 160 dB may rupture the tympanic membrane and cause permanent hearing loss.

* Non-auditory effects

* Interference with speech occurs when the sound has a frequency of 300 – 500 Hz

* Annoyance is a psychological response to noise which can greatly affect efficiency and concentration

* Noise has also been known to cause some physiological changes like increased blood pressure, intracranial pressure, increased sweating, etc.

questions.text: 80. Project MONICA was managed under:
questions.solution:
WHO has completed a project known as MONICA, it is related to cardiovascular diseases. It stands for the multinational monitoring of trends and determinants in cardiovascular diseases. It was done to study the reasons for the changes in the trends of cardiovascular diseases in different countries. 26 countries were participating in this project, which was planned to continue for a 10 year period ending in 1994.

This project specifically focussed on trends in event rates for coronary heart attacks and strokes, and on trends in cardiovascular risk factors ( blood pressure, cigarette smoking and serum cholesterol) in men and women aged 25-64 in the same defined communities.

The WHO MONICA project has without any doubt significantly contributed to global prevention efforts. The MONICA methodology is increasingly used as a measurement tool for cardiovascular and non-communicable disease prevention and control programs.

questions.text: 81. What type of information is conveyed to the cerebellum through an afferent tract passing through the marked structure?

choices.text: Pain and temperature from the lower limbs
Proprioceptive impulses from the lower limbs
Fine touch from the lower limbs

questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the inferior cerebellar peduncle, which carries the dorsal spinocerebellar tract, responsible for transmitting unconscious proprioceptive impulses from the lower limbs and trunk to the cerebellum.

The afferent tracts passing through the inferior cerebellar peduncle include the following:

* Dorsal spinocerebellar Tract: Proprioceptive input from the lower limb and trunk

* Cuneocerebellar tract: Proprioceptive input from upper limb and upper thorax (via muscle spindles, Golgi tendon organs, and joint receptors)

* Olivocerebellar tract: Conveys proprioceptive signals from the entire body; involved in motor learning (via climbing fibres)

* Vestibulocerebellar tract: Transmits vestibular impulses from the inner ear, important for balance and eye movements

* Reticulocerebellar tract: Conveys inputs related to arousal and motor function from the reticular formation

Other options:

Option A: Pain and temperature sensations from the lower limbs are carried by the spinothalamic tract, which goes to the thalamus, not the cerebellum.

Option C: Fine touch from the upper limbs is carried by the dorsal column–medial lemniscus pathway to the somatosensory cortex, not the cerebellum.

Option D: Visual and auditory reflex coordination impulses are relayed via the tectocerebellar tracts, which transmit via the superior and inferior colliculi, respectively.

Pearl PM0917: Functions of principal afferent systems to cerebellum

Afferent Tracts Transmits
Vestibulocerebellar Vestibular impulses from labyrinths, direct and via vestibular nuclei
Dorsal spinocerebellar Proprioceptive and exteroceptive impulses from body
Ventral spinocerebellar Proprioceptive and exteroceptive impulses from body
Cuneocerebellar Proprioceptive impulses, especially from head and neck
Tectocerebellar Auditory and visual impulses via inferior and superior colliculi
Pontocerebellar Impulses from motor and other parts of cerebral cortex via pontine nuclei
Olivocerebellar Proprioceptive input from whole body via relay in inferior olive


Pearl PM0915: Functional divisions of the cerebellum

  Dorsal Spinocerebellum Ventral Spinocerebellum Cerebrocerebellum (neocerebellum) Vestibulocerebellum (flocculonodular lobe) 
Constituents Vermis (except the nodulus) The adjacent medial portion of the hemisphere The lateral portion of hemispheres Nodulus and flocculus 
Afferent (input) Somatosensory from the trunk, visual, auditory, and vestibular Somatosensory input from the limbs From the cerebral motor cortex, premotor, and somatosensory cortex  Vestibular input, visual input, somatosensory from the neck
Efferent (output) Via Fastigial nucleus to the medial descending system Via interposed nucleus to lateral corticospinal and rubrospinal systems Via dentate nucleus to motor, premotor and prefrontal cortex  To vestibular nuclei in the brain stem (direct projection)
Functions    

Maintains posture and helps in the execution of gross movements

It controls the interplay between agonist and antagonist group of muscles

 Controls the  distal muscles of the limbs (smoothens and coordinates movements) Planning the sequence of voluntary movements    

 Participates in maintaining equilibrium and posture

 

Controls ocular movements

It is responsible for regulating the stability of the head and body in space

questions.text: 82. An intern commits a negligent act in the hospital. You as his senior doctor will be held responsible for the negligent act as the intern is working under you. This is explained by _____.
questions.solution:
The senior doctor is responsible for the negligent act of a junior doctor, resident, intern, or assistant working under him by vicarious liability.

Vicarious liability is a principle by which the employer is responsible for his employees’ negligence if such an act occurs in the course of the employment and within its scope. It is by the principle of 'respondeat superior' (let the superior answer).

When two doctors practice as partners, they are both responsible for each other's negligent acts. When 2 or more doctors independently attend a patient, each may be held liable for the negligence of others that he observes or in the ordinary course should have observed and allows it to continue without objection.

Other Options:

Option A: When an employee is being borrowed, the lending employer temporarily loses control over this worker, and the borrowing employer temporarily assumes control. This is known as the borrowed servant doctrine. 

Option B: Res ipsa loquitur in Latin means "the thing speaks for itself". The negligent act is so obvious that the patient need not prove the negligence. He has to merely state what, according to him, was the negligent act. For example, prescribing high doses of NSAIDs in a patient with a history of a perforated peptic ulcer.

Option C: Contributory negligence is any unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care on the patient's part or from the attendant. This act, along with the negligent act of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. If there had been no contributory negligence, the injury would not have occurred.

In this case, the doctor's negligence is not the direct cause of the injury. E.g., refusal to take required treatment, getting discharged against the doctor's advice, etc.

questions.text: 83. A pregnant woman in her 30th week of pregnancy undergoes a pulmonary function test. Provided there is no respiratory abnormality, which of the following is likely to be seen physiologically?
questions.solution:
Physiologically, there is a decrease in 6, which is residual volume.

A decrease in residual volume occurs due to diaphragm elevation (approximately 4 cm), causing the lungs to get compressed, which would also lead to a decrease in: 

* Total lung capacity (sum of residual volume and vital capacity)

* Functional residual capacity (sum of residual volume and expiratory reserve volume)

(Mnemonic: TIMM increases in pregnancy)

questions.text:
84. Match the respective minerals to their associated deficiencies

Mineral Deficiency
1. Calcium a. Neurologic abnormalities
2. Chromium b. Osteoporosis
3. Molybednum c. Cardiomyopathy
4. Selenium d. Impaired glucose tolerance
questions.solution:
The correct match of minerals and their associated deficiencies is 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c

Minerals  Deficiency
1. Calcium b. Osteoporosis
2. Chromium d. Impaired glucose tolerance
3. Molybednum a. Neurologic abnormalities
4. Selenium c. Cardiomyopathy


Calcium deficiency leads to reduced bone mass and osteoporosis. 

Chromium deficiency leads to impaired glucose tolerance. Chromium potentiates the action of insulin and helps in diabetes for impaired glucose tolerance. Rich food sources include yeast, meat, and grain products. 

Molybdenum deficiency leads to severe neurologic abnormalities. It is necessary for xanthine oxidase and sulfite, and deficiency can lead to brain and skeletal lesions.  

Selenium deficiency causes cardiomyopathy, heart failure, and striated muscle degeneration. Selenium deficiency cardiomyopathy, known as Keshan disease. Rich dietary sources include seafood, muscle meat, and cereals.

questions.text: 85. During the calculation of Well's score in a patient with suspected DVT, the presence of hemoptysis would entail an addition of _____ to the score.
questions.solution:
Hemoptysis is given a score of 1 according to the Modified Wells criteria.

Modified Wells criteria for predicting pulmonary embolism:

Signs/symptoms Score
Clinical signs of DVT 3
Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5
Immobilization for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks 1.5
Past history of DVT/pulmonary embolism 1.5
Hemoptysis 1
Malignancy 1


Moses' sign, a clinical sign observed in patients with DVT, indicates calf pain or tenderness when direct pressure is applied over the calf muscles, as shown below:



Homans' sign - Passive forceful dorsiflexion of the foot with the knee extended will elicit tenderness in the calf in DVT. Gentle pressure directly on the calf muscles in the relaxed position will also elicit pain. 

Care must be taken to be gentle in manipulation lest it may dislodge a clot and cause a pulmonary embolism. The image is attached below:



Pearl PM2504: Two-level deep vein thrombosis (DVT) Wells score

Clinical features Points
Active cancer (treatment ongoing within 6 months or palliative) 1
paralysis, paresis, or recent plaster immobilization of the lower extremities  1
Recently bed ridden for 3 days or more or major surgery within 12 weeks requiring general or regional anaesthesia  1
Localised tenderness along the distribution of deep venous system 1
Entire leg swollen 1
calf swelling atleast 3 cm larger than asymptomatic side  1
Pitting edema confined to the symptomatic leg 1
Collateral superficial veins (Non varicose) 1
Previously documented DVT 1
An alternative diagnosis is atleast as likely as DVT -2
Clinical probability simplified score Points
DVT Likely 2 points or more
DVT Unlikely  1 points or less 


Pearl PM2392: Clinical prediction for pulmonary embolism: Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule out Criteria (PERC)

Signs/symptoms Score
Clinical signs of DVT 3
Diagnosis other than pulmonary embolism is less likely 3
Heart rate >100 bpm 1.5
Immobilization for >3 days or surgery in the last 4 weeks 1.5
Past history of DVT/pulmonary embolism 1.5
Hemoptysis 1
Malignancy 1


Three-level score probability:

Well's criteria Score
Low <2
Moderate 2-6
High >6


Two-level score probability:

Modified Well's criteria Score
Pulmonary embolism unlikely ≤4
Pulmonary embolism likely >4 


 

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

* Age <50 years

* Heart rate <100 bpm

* SpO2 ≥95%

* No unilateral leg swelling

* No hemoptysis

* No recent trauma or surgery

* No history of venous thromboembolism

* No use of hormonal therapy.

questions.text: 86. A 26-year-old woman presents with mild lower abdominal cramping and amenorrhea for 6 weeks. She has a positive urine pregnancy test. A transvaginal ultrasound is performed to evaluate the location and viability of the pregnancy. The sonographer reports a clearly visible intrauterine gestational sac with a double decidual sac sign. Which of the following best describes the clinical significance of the double decidual sign on early pregnancy ultrasound?

choices.text: It confirms a viable intrauterine pregnancy with a fetal pole
It confirms an intrauterine pregnancy but not necessarily viability
It is pathognomonic for molar pregnancy
It indicates an ectopic pregnancy with pseudo-sac formation

questions.solution:
The clinical significance of the double decidual sign on ultrasound is best described by its confirmation of intrauterine pregnancy, but not necessarily viability. 

The decidua capsularis (around the implanted embryo) and decidua parietalis (lining the rest of the uterus) form the double decidual sign, and this sign is a strong indicator of an intrauterine pregnancy.

Below is an image showing a double decidual sac sign:



Other options:

Option A: Viability is assessed by visualizing a fetal pole with cardiac activity, which typically appears at 6–6.5 weeks.

Option C: Molar pregnancy on ultrasound shows a snowstorm or honeycomb appearance due to multiple hydropic villi, not a double decidual sign.

Option D: A pseudo-sac may appear in the uterus in an ectopic pregnancy but typically lacks the double decidual layers, is centrally located, and lacks a yolk sac or fetal pole. The double decidual sign rules out a pseudo-sac.

Pearl PM2262: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.



 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.



 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.



 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.



 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.



 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 



 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.



 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 



 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.



 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.



 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.



 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: 87. A 5-year-old child with a history of daydreaming in class and a decrease in academic performance. His EEG shows a symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and EEG showing a 3 Hz spike and wave pattern point to the diagnosis of absence seizures.

Absence seizures are characterized by sudden, brief lapses of consciousness with preserved postural control and no post-ictal confusion. Usually, the seizure lasts only a few seconds. They are predominantly seen in children between four to ten years of age, with a decline in academic performance in school and unexplained 'daydreaming'. Hyperventilation can provoke these EEG discharges and seizures.

Ethosuximide and sodium valproate are used as first-line therapy for absence seizures. Lamotrigine is used as an alternative or add-on drug for absence seizures.

Drugs like oxcarbazepine, carbamazepine, phenytoin, phenobarbital, tiagabine, and vigabatrin may worsen absence seizures and should be avoided.

Pearl PM1695: First-line Agents in Different Types of Seizures

questions.text: 88. Circumcision is contraindicated in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Circumcision is contraindicated in hypospadias because the prepuce (foreskin) is often used as a flap material in the surgical repair of the urethral defect. If circumcision is done, valuable tissue is lost, making definitive repair more difficult.

Hypospadias is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra. It occurs due to the incomplete fusion of the urethral folds. It is characterized by: 

* A ventrally placed urethral meatus (underside of penis or perineum)

* Poor development of the ventral aspect of the prepuce (resulting in dorsally hooded foreskin)

* Ventral chordee (bending of the penis)

Hypospadias can be classified into the following types based on the meatal location:

* Glanular hypospadias: the meatus is placed on the glans penis

* Coronal hypospadias: the meatus is placed at the level of coronal sulcus

* Penile hypospadias: the meatus is on the underside of the penile shaft

* Penoscrotal hypospadias: the meatus is at the level of the penoscrotal junction

* Perineal hypospadias: the meatus is in the perineum

The image given below shows the classification of hypospadias.



The main principles of surgery in hypospadias include:

* Orthoplasty - Chordee correction

* Urethroplasty - To reposition the urethral opening and tubularize the urethra

* Glanuloplasty - Reconstruction of glans

* Skin cover and scrotoplasty

Complications of hypospadias surgery include:

* Urethrocutaneous fistula (most common)

* Recurrence of chordee

* Urethral stricture

* Meatal stenosis

* Infection

Tubularized incised plate (TIP) urethroplasty is the most commonly done procedure. It is done for distal hypospadias.

Other options:

Option A. Circumcision is the treatment of choice for pathological phimosis.

Option B. Paraphimosis is a urologic emergency requiring immediate reduction. Circumcision may be done later to prevent recurrence.

Option D. Circumcision may actually reduce the risk of recurrent UTIs, especially in children with vesicoureteral reflux or anatomical abnormalities.

questions.text: 89. A 21-year-old college girl reports feelings of low energy, lack of motivation, hopelessness, and worthlessness. After taking a thorough history, you plot the following graph representing her mood. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the given graph, points towards a diagnosis of Dysthymia.

As per the given graph, the patient has had a persistently depressed mood for the last 4 years (>2 years), which has not crossed the threshold for major depression. Throughout this entire period, there is no history of the patient experiencing a euthymic mood. 

Dysthymia is a persis­tent depressive disorder that is characterised by the presence of:

* Insidious onset

* Early: <21 years, more common

* Late: > 21 years

* Depressed mood that lasts most of the day, almost continuously.

* Associated feelings of inadequacy, guilt, irritability, and anger

* Withdrawal from society

* Loss of interest, inactiv­ity, lack of productivity

* Inertia, lethargy, and anhedonia are characteristi­cally worse in the morning

The disorder is more common in women and young people. It frequently coexists with other mental disorders, like major depressive disorder, anxiety disorders, substance abuse, and borderline personality disorder. 

The DSM-5 diagnosis criteria for dysthymia include:

* Presence of a depressed mood most of the time for at least 2 years (or 1 year for children and adolescents)

* Presence of 2 or more features of poor appetite/overeating, insomnia/hypersomnia, low energy, low self-esteem, feelings of hopelessness, or poor concentration.

* Should not have symptoms that are part of major depressive disorder, like disturbances in appetite and libido, psychomotor agitation or suicidal thoughts

* Absence of any other medical illness or substance use that can cause this condition.

Treatment includes:

* Cognitive therapy

* Behaviour therapy

* Insight-oriented psychoanalytic therapy

* Interpersonal therapy

* Family and group therapies

* Pharmacotherapy with SSRIs, venlafaxine, and bupropion

Other options:

Option A: Cyclothymia is a chronic, fluctuating mood disturbance with many periods of hypomania and depression.

Option B: Patients with minor depressive disorder have a euthymic mood in between the episodes, but patients with dysthymia have virtually no euthymic periods.

Option C: Double depression is a condition with the presence of major depressive disorder along with underlying dysthymia.

Pearl PM1983: Patterns of Mood Disorders

questions.text: 90. The following phenomenon seen in the cerebellar cortex is an example of:
questions.solution:
The phenomenon depicted in the image is an example of feed-forward inhibition.

In feed-forward inhibition, an excitatory neuron (granule cell) activates both a target neuron (Purkinje cell) and an inhibitory interneuron (basket cell) by releasing glutamate, and the interneuron, in turn, inhibits the target neuron (Purkinje cell) by releasing GABA or glycine.

In the cerebellar cortex, the stimulation of basket cells produces an IPSP (Inhibitory post-synaptic potential) in the Purkinje cells. Both cells are excited by the same parallel fibres. This helps in limiting the duration of excitation.

Other options:

Option A: Negative feedback inhibition occurs when an excitatory neuron(that releases glutamate) has a collateral branch that connects to an inhibitory interneuron, known as a Renshaw cell, which then synapses back onto the excitatory neuron's cell body. When the excitatory neuron fires an action potential, the interneuron generates an inhibitory signal using GABA or glycine that returns to the same neuron, modulating its activity.



Option C: Post-synaptic inhibition is a direct form of inhibition, which is caused by an IPSP that is directly produced in the postsynaptic neuron when inhibitory neurotransmitters (like GABA or Glycine) are released.



Option D: Presynaptic inhibition is an indirect form of inhibition where the inhibitory neuron terminates in the presynaptic nerve terminal. Here, the inhibitory neuron releases inhibitory neurotransmitters (GABA) and increases the Cl- and K+ conductance of the presynaptic terminal.

This reduces the magnitude of the action potential reaching the synapse. It also reduced the Ca2+ influx, thus decreasing the amount of neurotransmitter released into the synaptic cleft. As a result, there is minimal generation of excitatory potential in the postsynaptic neuron.



Pearl PM2255: Cerebellar Circuitry

Cerebellar circuitry includes:

Afferents- Climbing and mossy fibers

* Climbing fibers -

* Origin - contralateral inferior olivary nucleus in the medulla oblongata

* Terminates on - Purkinje cell

* Mossy fibers -

* Origin - multiple sources in the spinal cord and brainstem

* Terminates on - Granule cell

Intrinsic components

* Granule cell backward inhibition - done by Golgi cells- prevent transmission from mossy fibers to the granule cells

* Purkinje cells forward inhibition- done by stellate and basket cells

Efferents -

* The output from the cerebellar cortex - from Purkinje cells inhibitory output to the deep cerebellar nuclei

* The output from the cerebellum - from deep cerebellar nuclei

* Globose, emboliform, and dentate - via superior cerebellar peduncle

* Fastigial - via inferior cerebellar peduncle

questions.text: 91. A middle-aged female patient presented with dyspnea. She does not have hoarseness of voice or change in voice. She underwent total thyroidectomy 2 days back. Laryngoscopy reveals the vocal cords to be in paramedian position. All of the following can be done in the management of this patient except:
questions.solution:
All of the above management options can be done in this patient, except Thyroplasty type I, which is medialization of the vocal cords.

The above clinical scenario of breathing difficulty with a good voice (no hoarseness), history of total thyroidectomy, and the laryngoscopy revealing the vocal cords in the paramedian position are suggestive of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.

Thyroplasty type I is medialization of the vocal cord, which is done in cases of complete paralysis (recurrent and superior laryngeal nerve paralysis). This is achieved by Teflon paste injection lateral to the paralysed cord.

Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury, often acute, is primarily caused by neuritis or surgical trauma (especially thyroidectomy), with other causes including thyroid carcinoma, cervical lymphadenopathy, and oesophageal cancer.

Paralysis of all intrinsic laryngeal muscles, with unopposed cricothyroid action, positions the vocal cords in a median or paramedian position, leading to stridor and dyspnea, though voice quality remains good.

Emergency tracheostomy is often required. Definitive airway widening without permanent tracheostomy can be achieved through vocal cord lateralisation (Option B), type II thyroplasty, arytenoidopexy(fixing of the arytenoid in the lateral position), transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation)(Option D), partial arytenoidectomy (Option A), or reinnervation of the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle using a nerve-muscle pedicle from the ansa hypoglossi.

Pearl PM1093: Positions of the Vocal Cord



Position Distance from median Seen in
Median 0 During speech/ swallowing
Paramedian 1 mm Recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
Intermediate/ Cadaveric 3 mm Complete paralysis
Slight abduction 7 mm Normal respiration
Full abduction 9 mm Strained respiration


Pearl PM1094: Various Vocal Cord Palsies

Type of palsy U/L Abductor B/L Abductor U/L complete B/L complete
Nerve RLN (left) Both RLNs RLN+SLN (left) Both RLN+SLN
Cord position Paramedian   |\ Both in  Paramedian   || Cadaveric   [\ cadaveric (intermediate) position [[
Voice Hoarse Good Hoarse Aphonia
Dyspnea - + - -

questions.text:
92. A middle-aged man presents with increased hand and foot size, and the facial features depicted in the image. Insulin-like growth factor-I (IGF-1) levels are elevated. Which of the following confirms your diagnosis?

GH - Growth Hormone

choices.text: Suppressed growth hormone after oral glucose load
Elevated growth hormone after oral glucose load

questions.solution:
The clinical image of a man with mandibular enlargement, prognathism (protrusion of jaw), and jaw malocclusion with elevated IGF-1 suggests the diagnosis of acromegaly. Elevated growth hormone after oral glucose load confirms the diagnosis.

Acromegaly is a result of growth hormone hypersecretion due to a pituitary adenoma. It can also occur due to extra-pituitary lesions. If growth hormone hypersecretion occurs before the fusion of the growth plates at puberty, it leads to gigantism. 

75g of oral glucose load is administered to the patient. The growth hormone levels are measured within 1-2 hours after administration. Normally, GH should be suppressed to less than 0.4 ug/L after the oral glucose load. A failure of suppression of growth hormone confirms the diagnosis of acromegaly. In some patients, growth hormone levels may demonstrate a paradoxical rise. 

Acral bony overgrowth in acromegaly manifests as frontal bossing, increased hand and foot size, mandibular enlargement, prognathism, and widened space between incisors. Soft tissue swelling results in increased heel pad thickness, coarse facial features, and a large fleshy nose.

Generalized visceromegaly is seen, including cardiomegaly, macroglossia, thyroid enlargement, etc. Serious complications include diabetes mellitus, obstructive sleep apnoea, and increased risk of colonic polyps and cancer. 

Acromegaly can be treated by transsphenoidal resection of the tumor. It can also be managed medically by using octreotide (a somatostatin analog), pegvisomant (Growth Hormone receptor antagonist), dopamine agonists or radiation. 

Other options: 

Option A: Elevated random growth hormone levels would not help in diagnosis, as GH is secreted in a pulsatile fashion. In addition, the GH level does not correlate with severity. 

Option B: Suppressed growth hormone after an oral glucose load is seen in patients without acromegaly. 

Option D: Elevated random prolactin levels are seen in 25% of patients with acromegaly but are not used to confirm the diagnosis.

Pearl PM1525: Tests for Acromegaly

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

questions.text:
93. Match each Leopold maneuver with its corresponding clinical purpose.

Leopold Maneuver

 Clinical Purpose

1. First maneuver

 a. Determine fetal descent into the maternal pelvis
2. Second maneuver b.  Identify the fetal presenting part in the lower pole
3. Third maneuver c. Identify the part in the uterine fundus
4. Fourth maneuver d. Locate the fetal back and limbs
questions.solution:
The correct match is 

Leopold Maneuver Clinical Purpose
1. First maneuver (Fundal grip) c. Palpate fundus → identify fetal presentation (head vs. breech)
2. Second maneuver (Lateral grip) d. Palpate the sides of the uterus → locate the fetal back and limbs.

3. Third maneuver (Pawlik's grip)

 b. Palpate just above the symphysis → Identify the presenting part.
4. Fourth maneuver (Pelvic grip)

a. Use both hands, facing maternal feet → assess descent into pelvis.

questions.text: 94. An elderly male who is a known hypertensive presented with pain and swelling in his great toe. The aspirated synovial contents visualized under polarized light microscopy showed negatively birefringent monosodium urate crystals. What is the antihypertensive that is preferred in such patients?
questions.solution:
Losartan is the preferred antihypertensive in patients having gout, because of its uricosuric action.

Losartan inhibits active sites for reabsorption and secretion in the proximal renal tubule, hence the net reabsorption of uric acid in the proximal tubule is decreased. Similarly, calcium channel blockers like amlodipine and diltiazem are found to lower the risk of gout.

Gout is a hyperuricemic metabolic condition, typically manifested by episodic inflammatory arthritis due to crystal formation and deposition of monosodium urate (MSU) crystals within the joints and connective tissue.

Acute recurrent gout flare is characterized by painful, warm, red, tender, and substantially swollen joints. The metatarsophalangeal joint of the first toe is involved in 70–90% of cases (podagra), followed by tarsal joints, ankles, and knees. Triggers of gout flares include purine-rich food, alcohol, diuretic use, local trauma, and medical illnesses such as congestive heart failure and respiratory hypoxic conditions.

Diagnosis is made by synovial fluid examination, which may show needle-shaped monosodium urate crystals. These crystals show bright, negative birefringence under polarized light. WBC count may be increased in synovial fluid. Serum uric acid level is usually elevated in chronic gout patients, but it may remain normal or low during acute attacks, because of the uricosuric property of inflammatory cytokines.

Management of acute gout includes the application of ice packs, rest, NSAIDS, colchicine, and glucocorticoids. In patients with chronic hyperuricemia urate-lowering agents like xanthine oxidase inhibitors(eg. allopurinol and febuxostat) or uricosuric drugs (e.g. probenecid) can be used.

Other options:

Options A and D: Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors like captopril are associated with an increased risk of incident gout among patients with hypertension. β-blockers such as propranolol, atenolol, metoprolol, timolol, and alprenolol, also have been shown to increase serum uric acid levels. 

Option B: Hydrochlorothiazides inhibit renal Ca2+ excretion, causing hypercalcemia and may precipitate gout. Hence, hydrochlorothiazides are not used to treat hypertension in gout patients.

questions.text:
95. A thalassemia patient was undergoing splenectomy. Which of the following ligaments need to be carefully divided and ligated before mobilisation to avoid vascular injury?

* Gastrosplenic

* Lienorenal

* Splenophrenic

* Splenocolic
questions.solution:
During splenectomy, the gastrosplenic and lienorenal ligaments of the spleen need to be carefully divided and ligated before mobilisation to avoid vascular injury.

In patients without portal hypertension, the splenophrenic and splenocolic ligaments are relatively avascular. The gastrosplenic ligament carries the short gastric vessels and the left gastroepiploic vessel. The splenorenal (lienorenal) ligament carries the splenic artery and vein as well as the tail of the pancreas.

The spleen is an intraperitoneal organ and is suspended in the peritoneal cavity by multiple peritoneal reflections, also referred to as ligaments. At the diaphragmatic surface is the splenophrenic ligament, and at the visceral surface are the gastrosplenic, splenorenal, and splenocolic ligaments.

A table showing splenic ligaments with their attachments and contents is as follows:

Splenic ligament Attachments  Contents
Phrenicocolic ligament Diaphragm to the splenic flexure of the colon  
Splenophrenic ligament The undersurface of the diaphragm to the spleen

 
Splenorenal (lienorenal) ligament Hilum of the spleen to the anterior surface of the left kidney

Tail of the pancreas

Splenic artery and vein
Gastrosplenic ligament The greater curvature of the stomach to the upper pole of the spleen

Short gastric vessels

Left gastroepiploic artery


An image showing the positions of the splenic ligaments is given below:

questions.text:
96. A 25-year-old male patient presented in the medicine OPD with complaints of shortness of breath and cough with seasonal variation and symptoms often triggered with exercise. A provisional diagnosis of asthma is made. Which of the following criteria indicates reversibility in this patient after bronchodilator therapy?

PEF: Peak Expiratory Flow Rate

choices.text: PEF increases by more than or equal to 20%
PEF increases by more than or equal to 50%
PEF decrease by more than or equal to 20%
PEF decreases by more than or equal to 50%

questions.solution:
Peak expiratory flow rate increases by more than or equal to 20% after bronchodilator therapy, indicating reversibility in the patient. 

Asthma is a chronic respiratory disease, usually characterised by airway inflammation leading to an effective reduction of the airway lumen, causing increased resistance to airflow. This can be detected as a reduction in expiratory airflow during forced expiratory maneuvers. Symptoms include shortness of breath, wheezing, chest tightness, and cough. Symptoms vary in intensity and are more during night. 

Spirometry: It is a non-invasive investigation that can be used to approximate lung volumes. This shows an obstructive pattern

* Decreased FEV1

* Decreased or normal FVC

* Decreased FEV1/FVC

Bronchodilator reversibility: Spirometry is performed both before and after inhalation of a short-acting bronchodilator (400 mcg of β2 agonist or 160 mcg of anticholinergic). A 12% and 200 mL increase in FEV1 compared to the pre-bronchodilator baseline value is diagnostic of asthma in adults. 

Peak expiratory flow (PEF): PEF increases by more than or equal to 20% after bronchodilator therapy in asthma in adults. It is less reliable than spirometry for the diagnosis of asthma.

Pearl PM2453: Treatment of Asthma based on severity of symptoms (GINA-2025)

Asthma management - GINA 2025

questions.text: 97. A middle-aged unidentified woman was brought to the ER by the police personnel. Her cognitive functions were markedly reduced and was showing irregular movements of her limbs. She passed away in the ER and an autopsy was done. Coronal sectioning revealed dilation of the cerebral ventricles bilaterally and marked bilateral atrophy of the caudate nuclei. Which trinucleotide repeat disorder causes these changes in the brain?
questions.solution:
The neuropathological finding described as bilateral caudate nucleus atrophy with resultant dilation of the lateral ventricles is classic for Huntington’s disease (HD).

It is a CAG trinucleotide repeat expansion disorder in the HTT gene on chromosome 4, inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion.

In HD, degeneration is most prominent in the striatum (caudate and putamen), particularly affecting the medium spiny GABAergic neurons. As the caudate atrophies, the frontal horns of the lateral ventricles appear enlarged (ventriculomegaly). This results in loss of inhibitory input to the thalamus and produces the characteristic chorea (irregular, jerky, dance-like limb movements). Progressive involvement leads to cognitive decline, psychiatric symptoms (depression, irritability, and psychosis), and dementia.

Other options:

Option A: Fragile X syndrome is the most common genetic cause of intellectual disability in males. It occurs due to CGG repeats in the untranslated regions (UTR) of the FMR1 gene. The patient presents with intellectual disability, a long face, large everted ears, macroorchidism, and autistic behaviors. Neuropathology involves dendritic spine abnormalities, not basal ganglia atrophy.

Option C: Friedreich ataxia is due to GAA repeat sequences in the introns of the frataxin gene. It results in difficulty in walking, loss of sensation in the upper and lower limbs, and impairment of speech. Pathology affects the spinal cord and cerebellum, not the caudate.

Option D: Myotonic dystrophy results from an abnormal increase in CTG triplet repeats located in the noncoding region of the DMPK (myotonic dystrophy protein kinase) gene. It is associated with skeletal muscle weakness, cataracts, endocrinopathy, and cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: 98. Which of the following maternal positions is most commonly favoured during delivery, which facilitates pushing and reduces aortocaval compression?

choices.text: Dorsal position with 15° left lateral tilt

questions.solution:
The dorsal position with a 15-degree left lateral tilt is commonly favoured during delivery.  

Dorsal position with a 15-degree left lateral tilt minimises aortocaval compression (compression of the aorta and inferior vena cava by the gravid uterus), which can otherwise lead to maternal hypotension and decreased uteroplacental perfusion. Additionally, this position supports effective bearing-down efforts during the second stage of labour. Other positions, like squatting or lateral, may also be used, but are less commonly the standard in institutional settings. A completely supine or lithotomy position without tilt or Trendelenburg's position is discouraged due to the risk of supine hypotension syndrome. 

Other Options: 

Option A: In a complete supine position, the mother lies flat on her back, which can cause aortocaval compression, leading to low maternal blood pressure and reduced oxygen to the baby; hence, it is not recommended.

Option B: In a lithotomy position without tilt, the mother lies on her back with legs in stirrups. Due to the absence of tilt, it also risks aortocaval compression and reduced blood flow.

Option D: In Trendelenburg's position, the mother’s head is lower than her feet. This position is not suitable for labour as it worsens aortocaval compression and makes pushing ineffective.

questions.text: 99. An elderly patient who was brought to the emergency with a sudden onset headache underwent CT angiography of the head and neck vessels. Following this, he developed anuria, and on serial laboratory investigation, there was a rise in serum creatinine of 0.7 mg/dL within the span of 48 hours following the scan. What is the likely cause of his condition?

choices.text: Physiological increase in creatinine post contrast imaging

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of anuria and a rise in serum creatinine of 0.7 mg/dL within the span of 48 hours following a CT angiography is suggestive of contrast-induced nephropathy.

Contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) is defined as a rise in serum creatinine of at least 0.5 mg/dL or 25% above baseline within 48 hours of contrast administration. The renal insufficiency should be acute, occurring within 2-3 days, and should not be attributable to any other identifiable cause.

Risk factors for contrast nephropathy include age (>80 years), pre-existing renal disease (serum creatinine exceeding 2 mg/dL), solitary kidney, diabetes mellitus, heart failure, ST-elevation myocardial infarction, dehydration, anaemia, paraproteinemia, concurrent use of nephrotoxic medication or chemotherapeutic agents, and high contrast dose.

Preventive measures include IV hydration with 0.9% saline (1–1.5 mL/kg/h) starting 3–12 hours before and continuing 6–24 hours after the procedure. Sodium bicarbonate may be used as an alternative with similar benefits. Using low or iso-osmolar contrast and limiting the contrast volume to under 50 mL also helps reduce risk.

In diabetic patients on metformin, the drug should be stopped 24 hours before and resumed 48 hours after the procedure to prevent lactic acidosis.

Other Options: 

Option B: Allergic hypersensitivity reactions following IV contrast media occur through several mechanisms, and signs are seen immediately. The reaction severity can range from mild hives to bronchospasm and death. 

Option C: Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (NSF) is a rare but serious condition characterised by skin thickening and fibrosis, primarily affecting individuals with impaired kidney function who have been exposed to gadolinium-based contrast agents used in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).

Option D: An Increase in creatinine post-contrast imaging is not a normal physiological response. The elevation indicates an iatrogenic (medically caused) acute kidney injury (AKI).

questions.text: 100. A 25-year-old male presented in the OPD with chief complaints of intermittent diarrhoea and flushing, with symptoms of niacin deficiency. His urine analysis showed a raised level of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid. Which amino acid is responsible for the formation of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid?
questions.solution:
Tryptophan is responsible for the formation of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid.

The given clinical picture of intermittent diarrhoea, flushing, with symptoms of niacin deficiency, and a raised level of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid in urine, is suggestive of carcinoid syndrome. 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid is a breakdown product of serotonin, which itself is a derivative of tryptophan. 

Serotonin is produced by argentaffin cells of the gastrointestinal tract, which is necessary for GIT motility. These cells may grow into locally malignant argentaffinomas, otherwise known as carcinoid tumours. The most common site is the appendix, followed by the ileum and rectum. A tumour with liver metastasis is likely to produce carcinoid syndrome.

Clinical features include flushing, sweating, and intermittent diarrhoea. Normally, about 1% tryptophan molecules are channelled to serotonin synthesis. But in carcinoid syndrome, up to 60% is diverted to serotonin. Therefore, niacin deficiency (pellagra) may also be seen in carcinoid syndrome. Principal normal urinary catabolites of tryptophan are 5-hydroxyindoeacetate and indole-3-acetate.

Note: Glycine is a non-essential, glucogenic amino acid. It has a role in the formation of the purine ring, synthesis of glutathione(with glutamate and cysteine), heme synthesis, and synthesis of creatine(with arginine and methionine).

Pearl PM1155: Conditions Associated with Pellagra-like Symptoms

Overproduction of serotonin that causes diversion of  tryptophan from NAD+ Pathway

Maize rich diet

Niacin is in unavailable niacytin form

Clinical importance:

5-HIAA testing is a 24-hour urine test that is specific to carcinoid tumors. This test is the most common biochemical test for carcinoid tumors associated with carcinoid syndrome.

Symptoms like secretory diarrhoea and valvular heart disease in carcinoid syndrome are due to serotonin.

questions.text: 101. A young man is diagnosed with acute rheumatic fever. On examination, a Carey-Coombs murmur is heard. What among the following contributes to the development of this murmur?
questions.solution:
Carey-Coombs murmur in acute rheumatic fever is due to an edematous mitral valve. 

The Carey-Coombs murmur is a mid-diastolic murmur heard over the left ventricular (LV) impulse in cases of acute rheumatic fever. This murmur is thought to be caused by an edematous mitral valve/acute mitral valvulitis. Another factor leading to this murmur is the atrial contraction during the filling of the ventricles, resulting in increased blood flow through the valve.

Other options: 

Option A: Tricuspid regurgitation produces a holosystolic murmur and occurs in severe pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure. It does not contribute to the Carey-Coombs murmur, which arises from mitral valve inflammation in acute rheumatic fever. 

Option B: Delayed aortic valve closure causes paradoxical wide splitting of S2 and is seen in aortic stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and left bundle branch block. Carey Coomb murmur occurs due to mitral valve disease, not due to the aortic valve. 

Option D: Pulmonary regurgitation causes a high-pitched decrescendo diastolic murmur, often due to pulmonary hypertension from mitral stenosis. Carey Coombs murmur, by contrast, is a mid-diastolic murmur in acute rheumatic fever due to mitral valvulitis.

questions.text: 102. A nulliparous female with a history of infertility presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea and sudden onset of acute abdominal pain. Her serum hCG is 2500 IU. A diagnosis of ruptured ectopic pregnancy is made. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Since the patient has a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, it should be managed immediately by surgery, and the most appropriate management is salpingectomy.

In salpingectomy, the fallopian tube, which has ruptured, is removed from its uterine attachment with bipolar cautery. It can be done for both ruptured and unruptured ectopic pregnancy. But linear salpingostomy can be done only in case of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy(Option A). Here, the products of conception are removed through a small incision on the antimesenteric border of the fallopian tube, and it is left unsutured.

Management of unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy includes expectant, medical, and surgical management options(Option C, D).

Expectant management - Observation with serum β-HCG monitoring is done. Indications include:

* Initial serum hCG level < 1,500 IU/L, and the subsequent levels are falling.

* Gestational sac size is less than 4 cm.

* No fetal heartbeat on TVS 

* No evidence of bleeding or rupture on TVS

* Hemodynamically stable

Medical management - Drugs like methotrexate (50 mg/m^2 single dose intramuscularly), potassium chloride, prostaglandin, hyperosmolar glucose, and actinomycin are used. Regular monitoring of serum β-HCG is done. Indications include:

* The patient is hemodynamically stable

* Serum hCG level less than 5,000 IU/L

* Tubal diameter less than 4 cm without any fetal cardiac activity

* Absence of any intra-abdominal haemorrhage

Surgical management - Include laparoscopic salpingostomy/ salpingectomy, microsurgical laparotomy. Indications are:

* Cases that don't fit the medical therapy criteria

* Serum β-HCG levels are elevated despite medical therapy

* Persistence of fetal cardiac activity

Estimation of serum β-HCG should be done weekly till the value becomes less than 5.0 mlU/mL, following conservative surgery or medical treatment.

questions.text: 103. Which of the following is not a cause of the positive Trendelenburg's sign?
questions.solution:
The Trendelenburg's sign is not positive in inferior gluteal nerve injury, as it supplies only the gluteus maximus.

The main abductors of the hip are gluteus medius and gluteus minimus, which are supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. Injury to the superior gluteal nerve results in the pelvis falling towards the unsupported side, which leads to a positive Trendelenburg sign. 

Inferior gluteal nerve palsy results in weakness of the gluteus maximus, leading to impaired hip extension.

Trendelenburg sign

This sign is demonstrated by asking the patient to stand on one limb. When the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis of the opposite side drops. Causes of a positive Trendelenburg sign can be divided into three categories:

* Problem with the motor component - Abductor muscle weakness, superior gluteal nerve injury.  

* Problem with the lever arm -  Shortening of the femur neck, non-union fracture neck of femur (Option B), malunited intertrochanteric fracture, abductor tendon rupture (Option C)

* Problem with the fulcrum -  Posterior hip dislocation, developmental dysplasia of the hip (Option D), and an intra-articular hip pathology.



Pearl PM2401: Eponyms named after Friedrich Trendelenburg

* Trendelenburg sign: This sign is demonstrated by asking the patient to stand on one limb. When the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis severely drops over the swing limb. This is seen in the paralysis of gluteus medius and minimus, dislocated hip, fracture neck of femur

* Trendelenburg gait: This gait is seen in patients with Trendelenburg sign. The body swings to the opposite side every time when the weight is borne on the same side. 

* Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's head is lower than his feet (head-down position)

* Reverse Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's feet are lower than his head (head-up position)

* Brodie Trendelenburg test: It is a test for presence of incompetent valves in lower limb.

questions.text:
104. A 60-year-old female diagnosed with atrophic gastritis presents with tingling in her extremities, cognitive decline, positive Romberg sign, and loss of proprioception and vibration sense.
Which of the following best explains her neurological findings?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario indicates autoimmune gastritis, which causes destruction of parietal cells and consequently leads to reduced intrinsic factor secretion, resulting in vitamin B12 deficiency and associated neurological symptoms.

Autoimmune gastritis refers to a chronic, diffuse inflammatory disease of the stomach that is restricted to the body and fundus. This disorder typically features diffuse atrophic gastritis, antibodies to parietal cells and the intrinsic factor, and increased serum gastrin due to G-cell hyperplasia. It causes diffuse mucosal damage of the acid-producing mucosa within the body, and fundus  CD4+T cells directed against parietal cell components, including the H+, K+ - ATPase, are considered to be the principal agents of injury in autoimmune gastritis.

Other characteristic features seen in autoimmune gastritis:

* Antibodies to parietal cells and intrinsic factor

* Reduced serum pepsinogen I concentration

* Hypergastrinemia

* Endocrine cell hyperplasia → Carcinoid tumors

* Vitamin B12 deficiency (pernicious anemia)

* Defective gastric acid secretion (achlorhydria)

Neurologic manifestations in vitamin B12 deficiency include bilateral peripheral neuropathy (tingling sensations) or degeneration of the posterior and pyramidal tracts of the spinal cord and positive romberg's sign.

The following image shows vitamin B12 absorption:



Other options:

Option A: Loss of G cells, located in the gastric antrum, and subsequent decreased gastrin secretion leads to reduced gastric acid secretion, impaired pepsinogen activation, decreased gastric motility, diminished gastric mucosal growth, and increased risk of gastrointestinal infections. This can be seen in cases of antrectomy.

Option B: Destruction of chief cells leads to reduced pepsinogen secretion, impairing protein digestion, but it does not explain the neurological findings.

Option D: Destruction of parietal cells can lead to absent acid secretion, also known as achlorhydria. Acidic pH is very important for the activation of pepsinogen to pepsin, which is important for protein digestion. So achlorhydria is mainly responsible for protein malabsorption and not vitamin B12 malabsorption.

questions.text: 105. A patient was brought to the casualty after sustaining an electric injury. All of the following lesions may be noted on the body during clinical examination except?
questions.solution:
The presence of wax drippings (or bone pearls) is not a clinical finding, but rather a radiological finding.

Joule burns, spark lesions, and crocodile skin effects can be seen clinically in cases of electric injury on examination. The heat generated by the current in electrical injuries may melt the calcium phosphate in bones. This is radiologically seen as typical round dense foci known as bone pearls or wax drippings.

Lesions seen in electrical burns or electrocution are:

1) Joule burns - Specific and diagnostic of contact with electricity. These are found at the point of entry of the current. They are round or oval shallow craters, one to three centimetres in diameter.

The image given below shows a Joule burn:



2) Spark lesions - seen when contact is less firm or a narrow air gap exists between the skin and the conductor. They occur due to outer skin keratin melting over a small area, which, on cooling, fuses into a hard brownish nodule, usually raised above the surrounding surface. 

3) Crocodile skin effect is caused by high-tension current burns, causing multiple spark lesions. The image given below shows a crocodile skin effect:



The image below shows the various electrical marks:

questions.text: 106. A patient with degenerative high axial myopia was found to have an outward curvature of a part of the globe when indirect ophthalmoscopy was performed. Which among the following is likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
The most common staphyloma to be associated with a degenerative high axial myopia is Posterior staphyloma.

Staphyloma refers to ectasia of the outer coats of the eye- cornea or sclera or both, as a result of the weakening of the eyewall due to inflammation or degenerative diseases. The staphyloma is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak cornea or sclera.

Types of Staphyloma:

* Posterior staphyloma: Ectasia of the posterior pole of the eye and is lined by the choroid. The ectatic portion is detected by fundoscopy and B-scan ultrasonography. Indirect ophthalmoscopy shows a posterior outward curvature of the globe seen as a crescentic shadow in the macular region. The retinal vessels dip down into the region. The staphylomatous area appears pale due to degeneration of the retina, pigment epithelium, and occasionally the choroid. The most common cause is degenerative high axial myopia.

* Anterior staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of the pseudo-cornea, which occurs after the total sloughing of the cornea. It is lined internally by the iris and externally by the newly formed epithelium. The most common cause is a perforated sloughing corneal ulcer.

* Intercalary staphyloma: This is located at the limbus and is lined by the root of the iris and the anterior-most part of the ciliary body. Common causes include:

* perforating injuries and ulcers of the peripheral cornea

* anterior scleritis

* scleromalacia perforans

* poor wound apposition after complicated cataract surgery

* secondary glaucoma

* Ciliary staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body. This affects the ciliary zone, which includes the region up to 8 mm behind the limbus. Causes include:

* Developmental glaucoma, end-stage primary or secondary glaucoma

* Scleritis

* Ciliary trauma

* Equatorial staphyloma: This occurs at the equatorial region up to 14 mm behind the limbus of the eye. Causes include:

* Scleritis

* Degenerative myopia

* Chronic uncontrolled glaucoma

Treatment involves local excision and repair with a corneal and scleral patch graft. Enucleation and replacement with an implant can be done for disfigured and blind eyes. Degenerative diseases responsible should be treated early to prevent secondary glaucoma and staphyloma formation.

questions.text: 107. A sober young businessman was eating and laughing when he suddenly stood up to catch his breath. He called for help in a hoarse voice, fell down, and was struggling to breathe. He was brought dead to the hospital. On autopsy, a bolus of meat was found at the pharynx. What type of suffocation is seen here?
questions.solution:
The type of suffocation seen in this scenario is choking.

Choking refers to the blockage of internal airways usually between the pharynx and the bifurcation of the trachea. The individual develops a sore throat, hoarseness, and respiratory distress. Choking can be accidental, suicidal, or homicidal. The cause of death is choking is asphyxia, laryngospasm, and reflex vagal inhibition, causing cardiac arrest.

Treatment is by the Heimlich manoeuvre (abdominal thrusts), a blow on the back or on the sternum may cause coughing and expel the foreign body. 

Other options:

Option A: Gagging is a form of asphyxia resulting from forcing a cloth into the mouth or due to closure of the mouth and nose by a cloth that is tied around the head.

Option B: Overlaying is a form of asphyxia that results due to compression of the chest so as to prevent breathing.

Option C: In café coronary, the victim is usually healthy but grossly intoxicated who dies suddenly and unexpectedly during a meal with no signs of respiratory distress or of asphyxia. The autopsy reveals a bolus of food lodged in the pharynx or larynx. The cause of death in these patients is mechanical asphyxia, leading to vasovagal reflex causing reflex cardiac inhibition. The mode of death is clearly cardiac arrest (not the cause of death), presumably from parasympathetic overactivity due to stimulation of the laryngeal or pharyngeal mucosa. The clinical signs of choking are absent because of the high blood alcohol content, which anaesthetises the gag reflex.

questions.text:
108. A woman is brought to the casualty in an unconscious state. Her arterial blood gas analysis report reveals the following values. Among the given conditions, which of the following can lead to this clinical scenario?

* pH- 7.32

* pCO2- 36 mm Hg

* HCO3- - 18 mEq/L

* Sodium levels- 136 mEq/L

* Chloride levels- 109 mEq/L
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the underlying disorder in this patient is metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap. Among the given options, diarrhoea will lead to this scenario as diarrhoea causes loss of bicarbonates.

The diagnosis can be arrived at by the following steps:

Step 1: A pH of 7.32 indicates acidosis.

Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 18 mmol/L

Step 3: Arterial pCO2 is within the normal range.

Therefore, the patient has metabolic acidosis.

Step 4: Calculate the anion gap. 

Anion gap = Na+-(Cl-+HCO3-)

                  = 136-(109+18)

                  = 9, which is a normal anion gap.

Causes of normal anion gap acidosis (NAGMA) are:

* Diarrhea

* External pancreatic or small-bowel drainage

* Ureterosigmoidostomy, jejunal loop, ileal loop

* Drugs- Calcium chloride, magnesium sulfate, cholestyramine

* Proximal and distal renal tubular acidosis

* Potassium-sparing diuretics

* Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers

Causes of high anionic gap acidosis (HAGMA) are:

* Methanol poisoning

* Uremia- renal failure

* Diabetic ketoacidosis

* Starvation

* Propylene glycol

* Lactic acidosis

* Ethanol poisoning

* Salicylate poisoning

Other options:

Options A, C, and D: This will give rise to metabolic acidosis with a high anion gap.

Pearl PM2409: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  


Pearl PM2098: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis
Acute

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Acute

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2


Pearl PM1341: Causes of Acid-Base Disorders

questions.text: 109. A researcher is studying a virus transmitted by an arthropod vector, which affects neonates as shown below. Which of the following is a feature of this virus?
questions.solution:
The image represents microcephaly and is associated with congenital zika virus infection. The Zika virus is an enveloped ssRNA virus. 

Zika virus is a flavivirus acquired mainly through the bite of an infected female Aedes aegypti mosquito. However, transmission can also occur perinatally and through sexual contact with an infected individual, breastfeeding, and blood transfusion.

Congenital transmission of the Zika virus leads to fetal microcephaly. Zika virus infection during pregnancy may also lead to other malformations, including limb contractures, high muscle tone, eye abnormalities, and hearing loss, known as congenital Zika syndrome.

Influenza-like clinical signs, including fever, headache, and malaise, characterise Zika virus infection. An itchy, maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, myalgia, and arthralgia usually accompany or follow those manifestations

The complications of the Zika virus infection include Guillain-Barré syndrome, encephalitis, meningoencephalitis, peripheral neuropathies, and neurological birth defects. Other complications of pregnancy include preterm birth and miscarriage.

Other Options:

Option A: Naked ssRNA viruses include the family picornaviridae(poliovirus, enterovirus, coxsackie virus),calciviridae(norovirus, hepatitis E virus), and astroviridae.

Option B: Naked ssDNA virus- only example is parvovirus B19.

Option D: Enveloped dsDNA viruses include the family herpesviridae(HSV-1,2, EBV, CMV, VZV, HSV-6,7,8) and hepadnaviridae(Hepatitis B virus).

Pearl PM2006: Enveloped and non-enveloped viruses

questions.text: 110. Process of “Complete extension” in a family cycle refers to time period between:

choices.text: Marriage and birth of first child
Birth of first child and birth of last child
Birth of last child and first child leaving home
First child leaving home and last child leaving parental home

questions.solution:
Complete extension in family cycle refers to time period between birth of last child and first child leaving home.

Pearl PM0845: The Family as a Social Organization

* A family is a group of biologically related individuals living together under the same roof and eating from a common kitchen.

* It is the most primary and basic unit of all societies.

* The basic and arbitrary model of a family cycle has six phases:

 

Phase

Beginning

End

1

Formation

Marriage

Birth of 1st child

2

Extension

Birth of 1st child

Birth of last child

3

Complete extension

Birth of last child

1st child leaves home

4

Contraction

1st child leaves home

Last child leaves parental home

5

Completed contraction

Last child leaves parental home

Death of 1st spouse

6

Dissolution

Death of 1st spouse

Death of survivor


* Types of families:

* A nuclear family or elementary family consists of only the married couple and their offspring while they are dependants.

* The term new family is applied when nuclear families are younger than 10 years and consist of parents and children.

* A joint family or extended family consists of a number of married couples and their children who live together in the same household with usually the men being related by blood. All property in joint families is held in common with the family income going into a common pocket. A senior male member is usually the head of the family who makes decisions.

* A three generation family is one where there are representatives from three different generations in one house.

* A communal family is one in which all the members play a part in its management.

* Functions of the family:

* Residence (patrilocal and matrilocal)

* Division of labour

* Reproduction and raising children

* Socialization and social care

* Economic functions

* Problems families are those that lag behind the rest of the community in terms of standard and quality of life of its members.

* Broken families are those in which the parental or family system has been disrupted by separation, divorce or death.

questions.text: 111. A researcher focussing on genodermatology was studying the anomalies of DNA repair mechanisms and the associated diseases. He was evaluating an 8-year-old girl with the following lesions who was undergoing treatment for squamous cell carcinoma of the skin. What is the underlying defect in this case?

choices.text: Inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV radiation
Defect in Nonhomologous End Joining of chromosomes
Defect in the functioning of DNA helicase

questions.solution:
The following image shows an eight-year-old girl with xeroderma pigmentosum. Xeroderma pigmentosum is an example of defective DNA nucleotide excision repair, where there is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure.

The image shows large hyperkeratotic lesions on her face, with some induration, suggestive of actinic keratosis and early squamous cell carcinoma. There are also multiple hyperpigmented lentigos and xerosis on the entire front of the face. Marked corneal scarring can also be seen.

UV radiation leads to pyrimidine dimerisation in DNA strands, preventing further replication by DNA polymerase. The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects the dimer formation in DNA. There is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure.

Other option:

Option B: Defect in Nonhomologous End Joining of chromosomes is seen in Ataxia-Telangiectasia, which is linked to immunodeficiency and radiation sensitivity. Nonhomologous End Joining (NHEJ) is a DNA repair mechanism that fixes double-strand breaks by directly ligating the broken DNA ends without needing a homologous template. 

Option C: Radiation-induced immunodeficiency syndrome is related to ionizing radiation.

Option D: Patients with Werner syndrome show premature ageing, which is a disease of defective Homologous Repair. The defective gene product is DNA helicase, a protein involved in DNA replication, repair, and other functions that require DNA unwinding. The defect causes the rapid accumulation of chromosomal damage that may mimic injury that normally accumulates during cellular ageing.

Pearl PM1064: Human Diseases of DNA Damage Repair

Nijmegen breakage syndrome (NBS)

Bloom syndrome (BS)

Werner syndrome (WS)

Defective DNA Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER)

Defective DNA Base Excision Repair (BER)
