questions.text: 112. A 35-year-old male is brought to a psychiatrist with persistent delusions that different individuals are the same person in disguise. He exhibits paranoia and anxiety. What is your most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this case is Fregoli syndrome. It is a disorder in which a person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Other options:

Option A: de Clerambault syndrome/erotomania is when a person falsely believes that another person is in love with them. It is commonly a woman who believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her. It is also known as the delusion of love. 

Option B: Capgras' syndrome is a delusion disorder in which a patient believes that a familiar person is replaced by an imposter or that other persons are no longer real. 

Option D: Persecutory type delusion is when the patient is convinced that they are being harmed by an individual, organization, or other groups.

Pearl PM0264: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: 113. As an orthopaedic intern, you are assisting a shoulder arthroscopy case in the operation theatre, where you are being explained about the rotator cuff. Which of the following muscles does not participate in the formation of the same?
questions.solution:
Teres major is not a part of the rotator cuff muscles. 

The rotator cuff is a group of 4 muscles (SITS) that stabilise the shoulder joint:

* Supraspinatus

* Infraspinatus

* Teres minor

* Subscapularis

Rotator cuff syndrome includes at least following four conditions that are possible causes of pain around the shoulder: 

* Supraspinatus impingement and tendinitis

* Tears of the rotator cuff

* Acute calcific tendinitis

* Biceps tendinitis/rupture

Rotator cuff pain presents with abduction and medial rotation of the shoulder joint, typically in the anterior and lateral aspects of the shoulder, with tenderness at the anterior part of the acromion.



Pearl PM2203: Important tests and signs to assess the function of rotator cuff muscles

Tests Muscles tested

Empty can test

  Supraspinatus
Resisted external rotation  Infraspinatus

Lift-off test

Belly press test

  Subscapularis

Abduction paradox

Drop arm sign

  Seen in the complete   rupture of rotator cuff
 Lag sign  Seen in tear of   supraspinatus or   infraspinatus
 Drop sign  Seen in the tear in the   infraspinatus and the   posterior part of the   rotator cuff

questions.text: 114. A 28-year-old female comes to the PHC, where she is prescribed the contraceptive pill strip shown in the image below. What is the mechanism of action of this form of contraception?

choices.text: Prevents ovulation by preventing LH surge
Spermicidal action on the uterine cavity
Prevents fertilization by decreasing sperm motility

questions.solution:
The contraceptive pill that the woman has is Chhaya, which has 30 mg of centchroman. Centchroman is a synthetic nonsteroidal contraceptive that does not prevent ovulation but prevents implantation through endometrial changes.

It is started on the first day of menses and taken twice weekly for 12 weeks and weekly thereafter.

To begin the use of Chhaya, the woman is advised to take the first pill on the first day of her period and the second pill three days later. This pattern of days is repeated throughout the first 3 months.

Starting from the fourth month, the pill is to be taken once a week on the first pill day and should be continued on the weekly schedule regardless of her menstrual cycle.

Effects:

* It does not prevent ovulation but prevents implantation through endometrial changes.

* It exhibits a strong antiestrogenic and a weak oestrogenic action peripherally at the receptor level.

* The return of fertility occurs soon after the stoppage of the drug (within 6 months).

Centchroman is not teratogenic or carcinogenic and exerts no pharmacological effect on other organs. The drug can also be used as a postcoital pill, given in a 60 mg dose within 24 h of coitus (two tablets repeated 12 h later with a failure rate of 1%). 

Side effects include Gain in weight, some delay in the return of fertility (up to 6 months). It does not protect against HIV and STDs. Prolonged use can result in hyperplasia and atypical endometrium.

Contraindications include PCOD, hepatic dysfunction, cervical dysplasia, and allergy to the drug.

Update: Saheli is renamed as Chhaya and is now available in two packages: ASHA supply (for home distribution) and free supply (for distribution at health facilities).

Pearl PM2328: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

* Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)

* Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate

* Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)

* Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women

* Norethisterone 350 μg

* Norgestrel 75 μg

* Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg

* Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results

* Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone

* Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia

* Post-coital pills or interceptive

* Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart

* Mifepristone 10-600 mg

* Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse

* Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse

* GnRH agonists  

* CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

* Progesterone only injectables

* DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months

* NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months

* Combined injectables

* Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg

* Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

* Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg

* Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

* Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day

* Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week

* Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: 115. A 65-year-old man presented with anorexia, weight loss, and anemia. Endoscopy revealed a gastric ulcer. Which of the following barium study finding in this patient is suggestive of a malignant gastric ulcer?

choices.text: Folds around the ulcer are smooth and even

questions.solution:
The Carman meniscus sign is suggestive of a malignant gastric ulcer.

It is seen in the setting of a large, flat, malignant ulcer with healed-up edges. These edges trap the barium, which gives a convex formation towards the lumen of the stomach. In benign ulcers, it forms a concave shape towards the lumen of the stomach.

The Kirklin complex is a combination of the Carman meniscus sign associated with a radiolucent semi-circular zone surrounding the elevated ridge of the ulcer. This complex is seen in cases of gastric adenocarcinoma in barium studies.

Differences between benign and malignant gastric ulcers:

Barium swallow findings Benign Malignant
Hampton’s line Present Absent
Extends beyond the gastric wall Yes No
Folds Smooth, even Irregular, nodular, may fuse
Carman meniscus Absent Present
Ulcer shape Round, oval, linear Irregular

questions.text: 116. A 40 year old farmer presented with an hour glass shaped, soft, fluctuant swelling in palmar aspect of right wrist which was painless and slowly growing in size as shown in image below. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this case is a compound palmar ganglion. The hallmark clinical feature is the “hourglass-shaped” swelling at the palmar aspect of the wrist, caused by swelling both above and below the flexor retinaculum.

A compound palmar ganglion is a condition affecting the flexor tendons of fingers, especially the ulnar bursa. It occurs mainly due to chronic tuberculosis. The effusion in the common sheath of the flexor tendon distends above and below the flexor retinaculum due to chronic inflammation. It is usually painless in nature. It may sometimes cause paresthesia due to compression of the median nerve. 

The swelling is of an hourglass or dumbbell shape with positive cross-fluctuation due to the continuation of the common flexor sheath below the flexor retinaculum. The tendons may eventually fray and rupture. 

The mainstay is anti-tubercular therapy (ATT). In cases with significant swelling or impaired movement, surgical synovectomy or debridement may be needed.

Other options:

Option A: A Ganglion cyst is usually a painless, fluctuant swelling presenting most commonly on the dorsal aspect of the wrist, usually caused due to leakage of synovial fluid from the wrist joint or tendon sheath.  

Option C: Synovial sarcoma is a malignant soft tissue tumor that can arise around joints and tendons. It presents as a firm to hard, often painful, progressively enlarging mass. Malignancy is unlikely in this case, given the painless, fluctuant nature and the classical hourglass shape. 

Option D: Carpometacarpal boss is a firm, round swelling over the back of the second and third carpometacarpal joints that is sometimes seen in a young adult. Treatment involves reassurance, and the lump can be excised, but if it recurs, the underlying joint should be fused.

questions.text: 117. A 24-year-old patient with multiple sexual partners presents with lower abdominal pain and dyspareunia. She had an IUCD inserted 6 months back. On examination, there was cervical tenderness, uterine tenderness, and an adnexal mass. Ultrasound shows a tubo ovarian mass. The urine pregnancy test was negative. Which of the following statements regarding her treatment is false?

choices.text: Cefotetan 2g IV BD + Doxycycline 100 mg oral BD is the first-line treatment
Partners should be investigated and treated
Minimally invasive surgery is indicated if the tubo ovarian mass fails to respond to antibiotics
Remove IUCD irrespective of antibiotic response

questions.solution:
The given clinical features point to a diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). There is no need to remove IUCD if the woman responds to antibiotics; failed response for 48-72 calls for its removal.

Management of PID:

* Rest

* IV fluids in the presence of dehydration and vomiting

* Analgesics once the diagnosis confirmed

* Antibiotics: Because of the damaging effect of gonococci and chlamydia on the fallopian tubes and polymicrobial nature of the infection, it is mandatory to start antibiotic therapy at the earliest and not wait for the culture results.

* First-line therapies: Cefoxitin (2 gm intravenously every 6 hours) or cefotetan (2 gm IV every 12 hours) plus doxycycline (100 mg orally every 12 hours).

* Placentrex (aqueous extract of the fresh placenta) 1 mL intramuscularly daily or alternate days (total of 10 injec­tions) has multipronged anti-inflammatory action. It also causes tissue regeneration, wound healing, and has signifi­cant immunotropic action involving both humoral and cellular immunity however it is outdated and not used currently.

* Partners should be investigated and treated.

* Percutaneous abscess drainage (PAD) under CT/ultrasound guidance of abdominal mass and pyoperitoneum yields 50% success and reduces the need for major surgery, with its associated mortality and morbidity.

questions.text: 118. A patient being evaluated for chronic diarrhea has a history of prior major abdominal surgery, but no records are available. After administration of 25 g of D-xylose, its urinary excretion is found to be less than 4.5 g. Which of the following surgeries was most likely performed?
questions.solution:
In a patient with urinary excretion of D-xylose less than 4.5 g, the most likely surgical procedure would be an extensive small bowel resection.

The D-xylose urinary test measures carbohydrate absorption, specifically assessing proximal small-bowel absorptive function. This is because D-xylose, a pentose, is almost exclusively absorbed in the proximal small intestine without undergoing enzymatic digestion and subsequently excreted in urine.

The standard procedure involves administering 25g of d-xylose orally and collecting urine over 5 hours. An excretion of less than 4.5g (abnormal) primarily indicates duodenal/jejunal mucosal disease.

The D-xylose test distinguishes between mucosal malabsorption (abnormal D-xylose test result) and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency (normal D-xylose test result). As D-xylose uptake is pancreas-independent, the disorders that remove or damage proximal small-intestine mucosa lead to low urinary D-xylose.

However, the test's use has declined due to the availability of small intestine mucosal biopsies via endoscopy and the d-xylose test's notable false-negative rate.

A positive (abnormal) D-xylose test is seen in:

* Celiac disease

* Whipple’s disease

* Tropical sprue

* Short bowel syndrome

* Crohn’s disease

The D-xylose test may yield abnormal results in patients experiencing delayed gastric emptying, impaired renal function, or fluid sequestration within a third space (e.g., ascites, pleural fluid).

Other options:

Option A. In a subtotal gastrectomy, a large part of the stomach is removed, but the duodenum and jejunum remain intact. While patients may develop nutritional deficiencies (iron, vitamin B12, folate) due to altered gastric acid secretion, reduced intrinsic factor, or rapid intestinal transit (dumping syndrome), the absorption of D-xylose is unaffected. Therefore, urinary D-xylose excretion after an oral load is usually normal, making this option unlikely.

Option B. A hemicolectomy involves the removal of a portion of the large intestine (right or left colon). Since the colon is not a major site of carbohydrate or monosaccharide absorption, its resection does not alter the results of the D-xylose test.

Option D. In a total pancreatectomy, the exocrine pancreas is removed, causing severe maldigestion of fats, proteins, and complex carbohydrates, resulting in steatorrhea and protein-energy malnutrition. However, because D-xylose does not require pancreatic enzymes for digestion or absorption, its uptake by the small intestinal mucosa remains normal. Thus, urinary D-xylose excretion after the test is not decreased, distinguishing pancreatic insufficiency from mucosal disease or resection.

questions.text: 119. A 40-year-old man presents to the OPD with palpitations and tremors. He mentions that he has had similar episodes for the past 2 months and feels better after eating food. He gives a history of a recent change in his diabetic medication. The blood sugar level is measured to be 60mg/dL. What is the cause of these symptoms in this case?

choices.text: Inhibition of reabsorption of glucose from PCT
Blocking of ATP sensitive potassium channels

questions.solution:
The given scenario of a diabetic patient experiencing episodes of palpitations and tremors following a recent change in medication and blood glucose levels of 60mg/dL suggests hypoglycemic episodes occurring as a side effect of sulfonylureas. Blocking of ATP-sensitive potassium channels is the cause of the symptoms in this case.

Sulfonylureas act by closing the ATP-sensitive K+ channels in the beta-cells of the pancreas. This closure causes cell membrane depolarisation and the release of insulin. They are readily absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and therefore can be given orally. Important sulfonylureas are glimepiride, glipizide, glyburide, etc.

Important adverse effects are hypoglycemia, vomiting, cholestatic jaundice, agranulocytosis, and aplastic and hemolytic anaemias. They can also cause a disulfiram-like reaction. They should be used with caution in pregnancy, lactation, and significant hepatic or renal insufficiency (for the older forms).

Other options:

Option A: Acarbose is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor. It reduces the intestinal absorption of glucose by inhibiting the intestinal brush border enzyme, alpha-glucosidase. They reduce post-prandial glucose levels and thus don't cause hypoglycemia.

Option B: Sodium-glucose transporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitors such as canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin act by inhibiting the SGLT-2 transporter present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule. The common side effects include urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to the high glucose content of the urine. 

Option D: Metformin is a biguanide that acts by activating AMP-dependent protein kinase. It mediates a series of actions that help in reducing hepatic gluconeogenesis. It does not affect the blood glucose levels in normoglycemic states and hence does not cause hypoglycemia.

questions.text: 120. The symbol shown in the image depicts:
questions.solution:
The logo given above represents biohazard waste.

The biohazard logo features overlapping circular shapes forming a trefoil, symbolising biological danger due to the presence of materials that pose a threat to human health, such as infectious agents. It alerts to the need for protective measures and proper disposal to prevent contamination.

Other Options:

Option A: The cytotoxic symbol typically shows a black cross or hazard sign with the word "cytotoxic," indicating toxic effects on cells. It highlights the need for careful handling to avoid harm to healthcare workers and patients.

Option C: The radiation hazard symbol consists of a central circle with three black blades on a yellow background, representing ionising radiation risk. This symbol is used to let everyone be aware of the hazard in an area where there is a source of radiation. This indicates the need for precautionary measures to avoid contamination.

The other logos representing cytotoxic waste and biohazard are given in the image below.

questions.text: 121. Which of the following tests is useful for detecting bile salts in urine?
questions.solution:
Hay's test is used for the detection of bile salts in urine. 

Normally, bile salts (sodium salts of taurocholic acid and glycocholic acid) are not present in urine. Thus, a positive Hay's test indicates an obstructive pathology in the biliary system, leading to the backflow of bile into the circulation. This obstruction may be associated with either obstructive jaundice or hepatic jaundice.

Fouchet's test is used for detecting the presence of bile pigments in urine. Here, urine is heated with barium sulfate, which adsorbs bilirubin. Ferric chloride is added, which oxidizes the adsorbed bilirubin to biliverdin, which produces a green color. Principle for all tests to detect bile pigments: Oxidizing agents readily oxidize bilirubin to biliverdin to form a green color. (Option C)



Ehrlich's test is used to determine urinary and fecal urobilinogen. Porphobilinogens form a red aldehyde compound with Ehrlich reagent, which is insoluble in chloroform. A red color remaining after chloroform extraction is indicative of porphobilinogens. This test is positive in acute intermittent porphyria and hemolytic jaundice. It is negative in hepatic jaundice (later stages) and obstructive jaundice. The earliest sign of recovery in obstructive jaundice is the reappearance of urobilinogen in urine. (Option A)

Rothera’s test by nitroprusside reagent is a specific test used to detect whether acetone or acetoacetate is present in the given sample of urine. A purple ring at the junction of two liquids indicates a positive test. Rothera's test does not detect β-hydroxybutyrate.  (Option D)

The other test used for the purpose of detecting acetoacetate only is the ferric chloride test. It shows a burgundy red color that is graded from +1 to +4. False-positive results occur with drugs like salicylates and phenols. 

The image below shows the purple ring formed by a positive Rothera test.



Pearl PM0736: Rothera's Test Procedure



Rothera's test, positive for ketone bodies.

Pearl PM1877: Color of urine in different conditions

Normal color of urine is pale straw due to presence of urochrome.

Abnormality Cause
Smokey or cloudy
  • AGN
  • Nephrotic syndrome
Gross blood
  • Urological causes     
  • Nephro causes
  • Hematological causes, e.g. PNH
Red without blood [brownish tinge]
  • Rhabdomyolysis   
  • Beetroot ingestion 
Tea- or cola-colored urine Hemoglobinuria
High-colored urine Bilirubinuria
Darkens on standing Alkaptonuria


 

 Due to Drugs: 

Abnormality  Drugs

  • Rifamycins (rifampicin, rifabutin, rifapentine)
  • B-complex

questions.text: 122. A 15-year-old boy presents with complaints of nasal blockage and bleeding from the nose. On evaluation, he was diagnosed with a nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. Which of the following is true regarding the disease?

choices.text: Blood supply is from the internal maxillary artery
Biopsy is the investigation of choice
Arises from the medial wall of the nasal cavity

questions.solution:
The blood supply of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is most commonly from the ipsilateral internal maxillary artery. 

Angiofibroma is the most common benign tumor of the nasopharynx, commonly affecting young males. (Option B)

It originates from the fibrovascular stroma on the posterolateral wall of the nasal cavity close to the area of the sphenopalatine foramen and the pterygoid base. (Option D)

It is a histologically benign but locally aggressive tumor that grows at the back of the nasal cavity. Blood supply is most commonly from the ipsilateral internal maxillary artery or sphenopalatine artery. It encroaches by expanding into surrounding areas like the nasal cavity, sphenoidal sinus, pterygopalatine fossa, maxillary sinus, orbit, and cranial cavity.

Clinical features include:

* Difficulty breathing through the nose

* Epistaxis

* Rhinolalia clausa (hyponasal speech)

* Bulging of the soft palate 

* Underdeveloped secondary sexual characters

Tumour diagnosis is based on the characteristic findings on CT, MRI, and angiography. CECT is the investigation of choice. Anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus, often called antral sign or Holman-Miller sign, is pathognomonic of angiofibroma.



Biopsy should not be undertaken as it is a highly vascular tumour and can lead to severe bleeding. (Option C)

Endoscopic resection is preferred in tumours that are limited to the nasal cavity, nasopharynx, sphenoid sinus, and pterygopalatine fossa.

Further extensions are managed with excision of the tumor by: 

* Wilson’s trans-palatal approach

* Lateral rhinotomy

Radiation can be used in cases of intracranial extension.

questions.text: 123. A woman who underwent dilatation and curettage for a molar pregnancy 6 months ago presents with persistent symptoms of abdominal pain and distension. On further evaluation, the beta-hCG levels were persistently elevated, and cannonball foci were found on the chest x-ray. Which of the following is true regarding staging and management in this case?

choices.text: Calculate the WHO prognostic score to decide on management
It is FIGO Stage IV disease
Always treat with combination chemotherapy - EMACO regimen

questions.solution:
The true statement about the management in this case is to calculate the WHO prognostic score and classify it as a low or high-risk case to decide on management. (Option A)

This woman with a history of dilatation and curettage for molar pregnancy, presenting with abdominal pain, distension, and persistently elevated beta HCG levels, has gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN).

The presence of cannonball foci on the chest x-ray suggests metastasis to the lung, which falls under Stage III of FIGO classification. (Option B)

Management of a case of GTN is based on the WHO prognostic scoring system that classifies it as low or high-risk GTN.

* Low-risk GTN (score <7): Single-agent chemotherapy with methotrexate (MTX) or dactinomycin (less commonly used). Methotrexate is supplemented with folinic acid on alternate days as it is a folic acid antagonist.

* High-risk GTN (score ≥7): Combination chemotherapy is the treatment of choice, as such patients are likely to develop drug resistance to single-agent chemotherapy. The preferred multiple-agent chemotherapy regimen is the EMACO regimen. (Option C)

* E-Etoposide

* M-Methotrexate

* A-Dactinomycin (Actinomycin D)

* C-Cyclophosphamide

* O-Vincristine (Oncovin)

Patients with stage I disease infrequently have a high-risk score, while those with stage IV disease invariably have a high-risk score.

Radiotherapy may only be required as a part of aggressive multimodality therapy in cases with metastasis to the brain (Option D).

Scoring is based on the WHO prognostic scoring system, as adapted by FIGO. It is as follows.

 Prognostic Factor Score
0 1 2 4
Age < 40  >40 - -
Antecedent gestation Mole Abortion Term -
Interval in months <4 4-6 7-12 >12
Pretreatment serum hCG (IU/L) < 103 103 to < 104 104 to < 105 > 105
Largest tumor size (including uterus) <3 3-4 ≥ 5  -
Site of metastases Lung Spleen, kidney GI tract Brain, liver
Number of metastases - 1-4 5-8 >8
Previously failed chemotherapy  - - single drug ≥ 2 drugs
  • Low-risk GTN: Score <=6
  • High-risk GTN: Score >=7


 

FIGO Anatomic Staging of GTN is shown in the image below.



Pearl PM0945: Risk factors and FIGO staging of Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia

Risk factors

* Older age

* β-hCG levels > 100,000 mIU/mL

* Uterine size that is large-forgestational age

* Theca-lutein cysts > 6 cm

* Slow decline in β-hCG levels

* Postevacuation uterine sonographic surveillance showing myometrial nodules or hypervascularity may be a predictor of subsequent neoplasia.

FIGO staging:

Stage I Disease confined to the uterus
Stage II GTD extends outside of the uterus but is limited to the genital structure
Stage III Lung metastasis with or without genital tract involvement
Stage IV Other metastasis

questions.text: 124. Which of the following monoclonal antibodies is approved for use in familial hypercholesterolemia?
questions.solution:
Alirocumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits PCSK9 and is used in familial hypercholesterolemia.

PCSK9 is a serine protease that causes lysosomal degradation of the LDL receptors present on the surface of the hepatocytes. Monoclonal antibodies directed against PCSK9, such as alirocumab and evolocumab, counter this and cause the persistence of LDL receptors on hepatocytes. This leads to more LDL uptake from the circulation, bringing down the LDL-cholesterol levels in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia.

PCSK9 inhibitors are indicated only as adjunctive therapy in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease who have elevated LDL-cholesterol levels despite being on maximum statin therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against IgE. It is approved for use in patients with asthma with elevated levels of circulating IgE.

Option C: Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody against VEGF. It is approved for use in patients with metastatic colorectal cancers and wet age-related macular degeneration (intravitreal administration).

Option D: Natalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against α4 integrin. It prevents α4β1 interaction with VCAM-1, thus restricting T-cell diapedesis into the brain. It is approved for use in multiple sclerosis. The use of natalizumab in a patient requires checking for antibodies against the JC virus. The presence of these antibodies indicates a latent infection and is a contraindication to the use of natalizumab. Natalizumab can cause JC-virus antibody-positive patients to develop multifocal leukoencephalopathy. 

Note: Vedolizumab is a monoclonal antibody that prevents only α4β7 interaction and is approved for use in Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: 125. A 65-year-old woman presents with a history of fever, malaise, headache, macular rash on the trunk sparing the face, palms, and soles, with no eschar. She has a history of hospitalisation for a “typhus” infection many years ago. Which of the following is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Brill-Zinsser disease. It is classically seen in epidemic typhus caused by Rickettsia prowazekii.

R. prowazekii is transmitted by the faeces of the human body louse. It starts as fever, chills, and a characteristic rash appearing on the fourth- fifth day, starting on the trunk and spreading over the limbs but sparing the face, palms, and soles. 

In some patients who recover from epidemic typhus, the rickettsiae may remain latent in the lymphoid tissues or organs for years. Such a latent infection may, at times, be reactivated, leading to recrudescent typhus known as Brill-Zinsser disease/recrudescent typhus. 

Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction, wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain Proteus strains—Proteus vulgaris - OX 19 and OX 2, and Proteus mirabilis OX K. The basis of the test is sharing an alkali-stable carbohydrate antigen by some Rickettsiae and by some strains of Proteus. 

Inference of Agglutination Pattern in Weil-Felix Reaction:

 DISEASE    OX 19 OX 2 OX K
Epidemic typhus +++ + -
Endemic typhus +++ +/- -
RMSF ++ ++ -
Scrub typhus - -  +++


Other options:

Option A: Orientia tsutsugamushi causes scrub typhus, which usually presents as an eschar at the site of bite, maculopapular rash, and regional lymphadenopathy. It is transmitted by the bite of an infected trombiculid mite. 

Option C: Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF) caused by Rickettsia rickettsii, transmitted through the bite of Dermacentor tick (hard tick). Patients present with fever, headache, myalgia, and centripetally distributed rashes over the palms and soles. 

Option D: Rickettsia akari is the causative agent for rickettsial pox caused by the gamasid mite as a vector. It presents as vesicular lesions, regional lymphadenopathy, and painless eschar at the site of bite.

Pearl PM0143: Human diseases caused by the Rickettsia and Orientia species

questions.text: 126. Which of the following is not a component of systemic inflammatory response syndrome?
questions.solution:
Systolic blood pressure <90 mm Hg is not a component of Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome.

Components involved in Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome(SIRS) are-

* Body temperature >38 or <36 degrees Celsius (Option A)

* Heart rate >90 beats per minute (Option B)

* Tachypnea with respiratory rate >20/minute or PaCO2 <32mmHg

* WBC count >12,000/mm3 or <4000/mm3 or >10% immature neutrophils (Option D)

Blood pressure measurements are not taken into account while calculating SIRS (Option C).

Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS) is primarily driven by the innate immune system in response to triggers such as infection, tissue damage, or ischemia-reperfusion injury. These triggers activate systemic inflammation, leading to events such as vasodilation, thrombosis, capillary leakage, and disruption of cellular function. Mediators like histamine and bradykinin cause vasodilation and, along with chemokines, promote immune cell migration into tissues, resulting in oedema.

A large release of cytokines, known as a cytokine storm, occurs due to ongoing stimulation and positive feedback loops. As inflammation escalates, microthrombi form around the affected area to limit the spread of pathogens and inflammatory mediators. If the local response fails or the trigger is too severe, systemic effects quickly develop.

These effects can include reduced cardiac afterload, pulmonary oedema, muscle weakness (myopathy), delirium, acute kidney injury, liver dysfunction, and ultimately, multisystem organ failure.

Sepsis is defined as SIRS with a documented source of infection.



According to the Sepsis-3 guidelines, sepsis is now defined as life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection.

Pearl PM1636: SOFA and qSOFA Scores

Sepsis is defined as a state of life-threatening organ dysfunction that occurs due to an unregulated host immune response to an infection. To objectively define the beginning of organ dysfunction, sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) scoring is used. The variables in the SOFA score include:

* Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors and platelet count

* Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation

* Mentation - Glasgow coma score (GCS)

* Hepatic function - Bilirubin

* Renal function - Creatinine

Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (SOFA) score
  0 1 2 3 4

Cardiovascular

Hypotension

 No hypotension

MAP <70 mmHg

Dopamine <5 or epi/norepi ≤0.1¤ 

 Dopamine >5 or epi/norepi ≤0.1¤ Dopamine >15 or epi/norepi >0.1¤ 

Coagulation

Platelets (×103 per μL)

 >150 ≤150 ≤100 ≤50  ≤20

Respiration

(PaO2/FIO2) (mm Hg)

 >400 ≤400 ≤300 ≤200 with respiratory support ≤100 with respiratory support

Mentation

GCS

 15 13–14 10–12 6–9 <6

Liver

Bilirubin(μmol/L)

 <20 20–32 33–101 102–204 >204

Kidney

Creatinine (μmol/L) or urine output

 <110 110–170 171–299 300–440 or <500 mL/day  >440 or <200 mL/day

MAP = mean arterial pressure. Epi = epinephrine. Nonrepi = norepinephrine. ¤ = Adrenergic agents administered for at least 1 h (doses in μg/kg per min).


 

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

A simplified version, recommended by the 'Sepsis 3' taskforce, is known as the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score. It includes:

* Systolic BP ≤100 mmHg

* Respiratory rate ≥ 22/min

* Altered mentation/sensorium

Each criterion carries 1 point. A qSOFA score of ≥ 2 is associated with increased mortality due to sepsis.

SOFA vs qSOFA:

* SOFA is a more comprehensive and accurate scoring system that is particularly superior to qSOFA in the ICU setting.

* qSOFA is a simplified derivative of SOFA for bedside assessment that is particularly useful outside the ICU setting (i.e. ward/emergency department).

Thereby, the best description of sepsis would be :

* Suspected or documented infection with SOFA score ≥ 2 OR

* Suspected or documented infection with qSOFA score ≥ 2

However, note that these scores were originally designed as a predictive tool that calculates the risk of death from sepsis rather than a diagnostic tool.

questions.text: 127. In emergency trauma, an intraosseous line was secured for resuscitation. Which of the following is not a complication of an intraosseous route?
questions.solution:
Accidental arterial cannulation is not a complication of an intraosseous route, but rather a complication of intravenous route.

Complications of the intraosseous route include: 

* Extravasation or subperiosteal infusion

* Through-and-through bone penetration

* Cellulitis (Option A)

* Osteomyelitis (Option C)

* Compartment syndrome (Option B)

* Fracture

* Fat and bone microemboli (rare)

Complications of the intravenous route include:

* Thrombophlebitis/infection 

* Extravasation injury

* Needle stick injury

* Accidental arterial cannulation (Option D)

Note: In emergency trauma, if peripheral intravenous access cannot be achieved, central venous access and intraosseous route should be considered.

questions.text: 128. The following image shows:
questions.solution:
The following image shows the Swirl sign. It is an area of low attenuation within an extraaxial hyperattenuating fluid collection.

The term "swirl sign" describes the appearance on a non-contrast CT scan when fresh blood leaks into a hematoma, such as in intracerebral, extradural, or subdural hematomas. This indicates the presence of unclotted blood, which appears lighter than the surrounding clotted blood.

Other options:

Option B: Mount Fuji sign - This sign is present in case of pneumocephalus. Gas is present between the tips of the frontal lobes with a heaped-up appearance, giving a silhouette-like appearance.



Option C: Ice cream cone sign-it represents the normal appearance of the malleus and incus on HRCT. The ball of the ice cream is formed by the head of the malleus. The cone is formed by the body of the incus. The tapering conical point is formed by the short process pointing towards the aditus ad antrum. If this normal appearance is not seen, it indicates ossicular chain disruption. It can be seen in Acoustic neuroma.



Option D: Accordion sign/concertina sign is a non-specific sign related to a thickened, edematous large bowel wall usually seen in the CT abdomen of patients with pseudomembranous colitis. It refers to the thickened, edematous bowel appearing similar to the folds of an accordion, as shown below.

questions.text: 129. Which of the following cranial nerves does not originate from the pons?
questions.solution:
The trochlear nerve arises from the posterior midbrain and does not arise from the pons. 

The trochlear nerve emerges from the midbrain and immediately decussates with the nerve of the opposite side, passing forward in the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus and entering the orbit through the superior orbital fissure. The nerve supplies the superior oblique muscle of the eyeball. 

Other options: 

Option B: The trigeminal nerve, while having four nuclei, leaves through the anterior aspect of the pons as a small motor and large sensory root, passing out fo the posterior cranial fossa and resting on the upper surface of the petrous part of the temporal bone. The sensory root forms the trigeminal ganglion, while the motor fibers join the mandibular nerve and supply muscles of mastication. 

Option C: The abducens nerve passes through the pons and emerges in the groove between the lower border of the pons and the medulla oblongata. The nerve then enters the orbit through the superior orbital fissure after passing through the cavernous sinus along with the internal carotid artery.

Option D: For the facial nerve, the motor root fibers travel posteriorly around the abducens nucleus, beneath the colliculus facialis in the floor of the fourth ventricle, and pass anteriorly, joining the sensory fibers to emerge from the anterior surface of the brain between the pons and the medulla oblongata.

questions.text: 130. A 45-year-old alcoholic male, admitted for a femur fracture, developed increasing anxiety, tremors, altered mental status, and tactile hallucinations on the third day, leading to a diagnosis of delirium tremens. Which side effect primarily contraindicates the use of clozapine in this patient?
questions.solution:
Out of all the side effects of clozapine, the most important reason for avoiding it in the management of delirium tremens is its dose-dependent potential to lower seizure threshold, which may place the patient at a greater risk for developing alcohol-withdrawal seizures.

Antipsychotics are used to manage the psychotic symptoms in cases of delirium, but in cases of delirium associated with alcohol withdrawal, the use of antipsychotics is not recommended.

Delirium tremens is the most severe form of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. It usually occurs within 3–4 days of alcohol withdrawal.

Characteristic features of delirium tremens:

* Clouding of consciousness, with disorientation to time and place

* Poor attention and distractibility

* Visual hallucinations and illusions, which are often vivid and very frightening

* Autonomic disturbances like tachycardia, fever, hypertension, diaphoresis, and pupillary dilatation

* Psychomotor agitation and ataxia

Benzodiazepines such as diazepam (intravenously) or chlordiazepoxide (orally every 4 hours) are given. It is also recommended to administer thiamine in patients with alcohol-related disorders to prevent Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

Note- Agranulocytosis (option A), metabolic side effects (option C), and myocarditis (option D) are adverse effects of clozapine, but these are not the primary concern in a patient with delirium tremens.

questions.text: 131. A 3-month-old baby is brought to the clinic as he turns blue every time he cries. On evaluation, the baby was diagnosed with cyanotic congenital heart disease with increased pulmonary blood flow. Which of the following characteristic X-ray cardiac appearances can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, only a baby with truncus arteriosus would be cyanotic with increased pulmonary blood flow, which is characterized by the sitting duck appearance of the heart on X-ray.

Truncus arteriosus is a cyanotic congenital heart anomaly. The embryonic common truncus arteriosus fails to divide and gives rise to a single great artery. This single trunk supplies both the pulmonary and systemic circulation, instead of a separate aorta and a pulmonary trunk. A child with truncus arteriosus can present with minimal cyanosis at birth and moderate cyanosis in 1-2months.

On X-ray, pulmonary plethora is seen in this condition, as opposed to pulmonary oligemia in conditions with decreased pulmonary blood flow. This is because the pulmonary artery originates from the truncus, which is part of the systemic circulation.

Other options:

Option B: A box-shaped heart is seen in Ebstein's anomaly.

Option C: Boot shaped heart is seen in children with Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

Option D: “Figure-of-3” appearance of aorta is seen in Coarctation of aorta, which is an acyanotic congenital heart disease.

questions.text: 132. Which of the following is not true about Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease?

choices.text: It is an example of prion disease
It is associated with fever and leukocytosis

questions.solution:
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) does not show an inflammatory response, so fever and leukocytosis are characteristically absent.

CJD is a prion disease. The term prion refers to an infectious particle composed of proteins without any nucleic acids. They are misfolded proteins that are resistant to degradation and can induce similar misfolding in other proteins. Normal PrPC protein (predominant α-helix) gets converted to pathogenic PrPSc protein (predominant β-structure).

Most cases of CJD are sporadic in origin. Acquired CJD includes iatrogenic and variant subtypes. Iatrogenic CJD occurs due to dura mater grafts or therapy with contaminated growth hormone, while the variant subtype is acquired following ingestion of tainted beef. Familial cases of CJD are known to occur, but are rare. 

Patients present with non-specific symptoms such as headache, anxiety, and weight loss initially. This is followed by a rapidly evolving loss of higher cortical function leading to dementia. Important associated symptoms include psychosis and visual hallucinations, apathy, insomnia, and depression. Majority of the patients with CJD develop myoclonus which persists when the patient is asleep. Startle myoclonus can be elicited by loud sounds.

Sporadic CJD is characterized by increased intensity of basal ganglia and cortical ribboning on the FLAIR sequence of MRI as shown in the image below.



EEG shows generalized high-voltage triphasic waves, but they are usually transient as shown below.



The patient does not have a fever, raised ESR, leukocytosis, or increased CSF cell counts. The presence of these should prompt a diagnosis other than CJD. There is no effective treatment for CJD, and most patients succumb within 12 months of the onset of the symptoms.

* Parkinson’s disease

* Dementia with Lewy bodies

* REM behavioral disorder

Tauopathies:

* Alzheimer’s disease

* Down syndrome

* Progressive supranuclear palsy

* Corticobasal degeneration

* Pick’s disease/frontotemporal dementia

* Chronic traumatic encephalopathy/punch drunk syndrome/dementia pugilistica

* Postencephalitic parkinsonism

* Pantothenate kinase-associated degeneration

* Niemann Pick disease type C

* Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis

questions.text: 133. A 19-year-old female presents with persistent mild pain in the right thigh for 2 months. There has been no history of trauma. Radiographs show a well defined, expansile, osteolytic, intramedullary lesion in the diaphysis of the proximal femur with a hazy ground-glass matrix and no periosteal reaction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests a likely diagnosis of fibrous dysplasia.

Fibrous dysplasia presents with features of mild persistent pain in a long bone, with x-ray showing a well-defined, expansile, osteolytic, intramedullary lesion in the diaphysis of the femur with a hazy ground-glass matrix and no periosteal reaction, usually in the second decade of life. 

Fibrous dysplasia affects bone development and involves the replacement of bone with fibrous tissue. It is of two types

* Monostotic - Involvement of a single bone. 

* Polyostotic - Association with McCune Albright syndrome, and involvement of multiple bones. 

In fibrous dysplasia, the normal mineralisation and maturation into lamellar bone are prevented by the production of disorganised fibrous material. Patients often present in the second decade of life with non-specific bone pain, swelling, tenderness, progressive limb deformity, or following a fracture through a previously asymptomatic lesion. Proximal femur, tibia, pelvis, and foot are frequently involved, but ribs, skull, and bones of the upper limbs are also affected.

Proximal femur expansion with significant varus often causes a "shepherd's crook" deformity. If an X-ray is inconclusive, an open biopsy may be performed. Bisphosphonates can be prescribed for bone pain. Surgery might be needed for progressive deformity or pathological fractures.





Other options: 

Option A: Osteosarcoma is usually seen in the second decade of life, with X-Ray showing sunburst appearance and periosteal elevation (Codman's triangle) in the metaphysis of a long bone, most commonly the distal femur, proximal tibia, or proximal humerus.



Option B: Giant cell tumor commonly affects the age group is 20-40 years with a slight female preponderance. The distal end of the femur is the most common location, followed by the proximal tibia and distal radius. Radiographic findings include an eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis with a soap bubble appearance and a lack of periosteal reaction.



Option D: Aneurysmal bone cyst (ABC) is a benign tumour that usually affects the metaphysis of long bones (femur and tibia) and the posterior elements of vertebral bodies. Patients typically present with pain, swelling, and pathological fractures. Radiographically, ABC is seen as an eccentric, expansile, lytic lesion with a well-defined margin.

questions.text: 134. Which of the following substrate gets accumulated in mutation of VHL gene and leads to tumour growth?
questions.solution:
HIF-1α (Hypoxia-inducible factor 1α) accumulates in VHL gene mutations and drives tumor growth.

Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome is an autosomal dominant disease affecting several organ systems. It is characterized by a germline loss-of-function mutation of the VHL gene on chromosome 3p. The VHL gene encodes a protein that is part of the E3 ubiquitin ligase complex, which attaches ubiquitin chains to protein substrates, promoting their degradation. 

Under normal oxygen conditions (normoxia), VHL binds to hydroxylated HIF-1α and targets it for proteasomal degradation.

When the VHL gene is mutated, this degradation pathway is lost, leading to stabilization and accumulation of HIF-1α even in the presence of normal oxygen. The accumulated HIF-1α then translocates to the nucleus, dimerizes with HIF-1β, and activates transcription of genes promoting:

* Angiogenesis (↑ VEGF)

* Cell proliferation (↑ PDGF, TGF-α)

* Glycolysis (↑ glucose transporters, glycolytic enzymes)

These pathways contribute to tumor development in VHL syndrome, such as hemangioblastomas, clear cell renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytoma.

Other options:

Option A: The WNT signaling pathway is a fundamental developmental pathway involved in regulating cell fate, proliferation, and migration. Abnormal activation of WNT signaling is strongly implicated in cancers like colorectal carcinoma due to mutations in APC or β-catenin.

Option B: MYC encodes a transcription factor that regulates genes controlling cell cycle progression, metabolism, and apoptosis. Oncogenic activation of MYC, such as by translocation in Burkitt lymphoma (t(8;14)), contributes to malignancy.

Option D: AMPK (AMP-activated protein kinase) is a metabolic regulator that senses cellular energy status (AMP/ATP ratio). It promotes catabolic pathways and suppresses anabolic processes to maintain energy homeostasis. Loss-of-function mutations in STK11, as seen in Peutz–Jeghers syndrome, lead to impaired AMPK activation, resulting in uncontrolled cell growth, metabolic dysregulation, and increased tumor risk, including gastrointestinal polyps and pancreatic and breast cancers.

questions.text: 135. Among the given women, the best candidate for the role of accredited social health activist (ASHA) is a 25–45-year-old woman who is ______.

choices.text: Unmarried with education up to the 10th standard
Married with education up to the 5th standard
Unmarried with education up to the 5th standard
A widow with education up to the 10th standard

questions.solution:
The correct answer is option D, woman who is a widow with education up to the 10th standard.

An ASHA is a trained female community health activist and a resident woman of the village with a formal education of at least up to 8th grade. She should preferably be in the age group of 25 to 45 years (married/divorced/widow) and have qualities such as good communication skills and leadership skills. The general norm of selection recommends having one ASHA for 1000 population, but in tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm could be relaxed to one ASHA per habitation.

 Roles of ASHA:

* To create awareness and provide information to the community on determinants of health such as nutrition, basic sanitation, and hygienic practices

* To counsel women on birth preparedness, the importance of safe delivery, breast-feeding and complementary feeding, immunization, and contraception

* To counsel women on the prevention of common infections including reproductive tract infection/sexually transmitted infection 

* To mobilize the community and help them in accessing health and health-related services.

* To arrange and escort pregnant women and children requiring treatment/admission to the nearest pre-identified health facility

* To inform sub-center/primary health center about the births and deaths in her village and any unusual health problems/disease outbreaks in the community

* To promote the construction of household toilets under the total sanitation campaign.

Pearl PM0156: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

* Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow

* Must be a resident of that village

* Formal education of up to 10th standard 

* If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard

* At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 

* In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

* Health education and awareness

* Reproductive and child health and family planning

* Facilitate the access to health services

* Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction

* Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments

* Provider of DOTS

* Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.

* Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres

* Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

* 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)

* 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

* A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).

* ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: 136. To compare the LDL cholesterol reduction of three statins (X, Y, Z), a total of 150 patients with hypercholesterolemia were randomized to receive one of three drugs for 12 weeks. Which statistical test best determines if there's a significant difference in mean LDL reduction among the three drug groups?
questions.solution:
Analysis of variance (ANOVA) would be most appropriate to determine if there is a significant difference in the mean LDL cholesterol reduction among the three drug groups.

For comparing means within independent and identically distributed samples across more than two groups, the analysis of variance (ANOVA) is most appropriate. An analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is a parametric test that is used to compare the means among two or more groups. Therefore, it is used for quantitative variables.

Tests of significance are used to check for a significant association between two or more variables. Examples are the Student's t-test, paired t-test, Chi-square test, ANOVA, and Fisher's test.

Other options:

Option A: An unpaired t-test is a parametric statistical test determining whether a statistically significant difference exists between the means in two unrelated (independent) groups.

Option B: The paired t-test is a parametric test and compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group.

Option C: Pearson correlation coefficient is used to measure the strength and direction of a linear relationship between two continuous variables. It does not apply to comparing group means.



Pearl PM1104: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

* See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?

* If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.

* If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .

* If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.

* If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

* Unpaired t tests

* Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.

* It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.

* Paired t tests

* "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"

* So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 

* Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.

* It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.

* It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.

* T scores 

* The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.

* The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

* The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

* The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.

* It is a test of proportions and associations.

* A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.

* If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: 137. A mother is advised that the baby should be allowed to empty one breast completely before switching over to the other for optimum growth. All the following are reasons for this, except ____.

choices.text: Foremilk is rich in  sugar and vitamins

questions.solution:
Hindmilk is rich in proteins is incorrect.

While breastfeeding, the mother should allow complete emptying of one breast before switching over to the other. It is because the baby needs both fore-milk and hind-milk for optimum growth. Hind milk is rich in fats that provide more energy.

Foremilk is the milk that is secreted during the initial feed. It is watery and quenches the thirst of the baby. It is rich in proteins, sugar, vitamins, minerals, and water. Hindmilk is rich in fat and provides energy. It gives a sense of satiety to the baby. Hindmilk comes towards the end of the feed. 

The composition of breast milk varies at different time points of lactation to suit the needs of the baby.

* Colostrum is secreted in small quantities during the first 3 to 4 days. It is thick, and yellow and contains a large number of antibodies, immune-competent cells, and vitamins A, D, E, and K. 

* Transitional milk is the one that is seen after 3-4 days until 2 weeks and has an increased fat and sugar content while the protein and immunoglobulin content reduces.

* Mature milk is secreted after transitional milk. It is essential for the optimum growth of the baby as it contains all the nutrients. It is thinner and more watery.

* A mother who delivers before 37 weeks secretes preterm milk that contains proteins, sodium, iron, immunoglobulin, and calories as needed by the preterm infant.

Components of breast milk and diseases they protect against:

Components of breast milk Protection against
Lysozyme
  • Escherichia coli, Salmonella
  • Entamoeba histolytica
Lactoferrin
  • E. coli, Shigella, Salmonella
  • E. histolytica, Giardia lamblia
  • Plasmodium falciparum
  • Rotavirus
Bifidus factor E. coli, Shigella, Salmonella
Low levels of para-aminobenzoic acid Plasmodium

questions.text:
138. A 6-year-old girl is brought with a history of impaired vision. On examination, she has light hair, light skin color, and pale blue iris. The child has a normal IQ. Which of the following are not derived from the precursor amino acid, whose metabolism is impaired in this child?

DOPA- dihydroxyphenylalanine, GABA- Gamma-aminobutyric acid
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of albinism, which is a disorder of tyrosine metabolism where there is a defect in melanin synthesis. GABA (Gamma-aminobutyric acid) is not derived from tyrosine. It is synthesized from glutamate through the action of glutamate decarboxylase (with pyridoxal phosphate as a cofactor).

Tyrosine is a precursor of melanin, thyroxine, epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA).

* Formation of DOPA: Tyrosine is hydroxylated by tyrosinase to form dihydroxyphenylalanine or DOPA. Tyrosinase is a monooxygenase that contains copper. (Option B)

* Formation of melanin: Tyrosinase acts on DOPA to form dopaquinone, which is then converted to indolequinone. The indolequinone is polymerized to form melanin.

* Formation of catecholamines: Epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine. They are produced by the adrenal medulla and sympathetic ganglia. (Option A)

* Formation of thyroid hormones: Tyrosine residues are iodinated to form 3-mono-iodo-tyrosine (MIT) and 3,5-di-iodo-tyrosine (DIT). These are coupled to give rise to triiodothyronine (T3) and tetraiodothyronine (thyroxine or T4). (Option C)

The series of reactions involving the production of catecholamines is shown in the image below.



Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes, leading to hypopigmentation. It is either due to defective melanosomes or defective proteins involved in the formation and transfer of melanin.

 

There are 7 types of nonsyndromic albinism (OCA1 to OCA7). OCA type 1 is characterized by reduced or absent tyrosinase activity. Clinical features include white hair, white skin, and iris appearing blue-grey in oblique light. Ocular manifestations include photophobia, nystagmus, and decreased visual acuity. The IQ of the child will be normal.

questions.text: 139. A 26-year-old male presented to the emergency ward after a history of a road traffic accident with pain in his right knee with a high-stepping gait. The X-ray of the right knee is shown below. As an intern working in the emergency ward, injury to which of the following structures should be anticipated in such injuries?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and X-ray suggest a proximal fibula fracture in which the common peroneal nerve is commonly injured.

Injury to the fibular neck/proximal fibula and knee fractures may cause injury to the common peroneal nerve that winds around the neck of the fibula, travelling from the posterior to the lateral compartment of the leg, further dividing into the deep and superficial peroneal nerves, and result in a high-stepping gait, and foot drop. 

The common peroneal nerve supplies the extensors and evertors of the foot. Injury to the same leads to the following features:

* Foot drop

* High-stepping gait

* Loss of sensation over the front and outer half of the leg, with the dorsum of the foot 

Isolated Injury to the superficial peroneal nerve causes:

* Loss of eversion as it gives motor nerve supply to  to peroneus longus and brevis

* Loss of sensation over most of the dorsal foot, except the 1st web space and anterolateral aspect of the distal leg

Isolated Injury to the deep peroneal nerve is very rare due to direct trauma. However, iatrogenic injuries can be seen in certain surgeries performed around the knee joint. Isolated injury to the deep peroneal nerve leads to:

* Foot drop

* Loss of sensation in the 1st web space 

Below are the images showing the route of the common peroneal nerve and cutaneous innervation of foot:





Other Options:

Option A: Tibial nerve splits from the sciatic nerve in the distal thigh, passing through the popliteal fossa and descending into the posterior compartment of the leg. Injury to the same causes loss of ankle and toe plantarflexion, weakened foot inversion, and sensory loss to the plantar aspect of the foot.

Option B: The Posterior tibial artery, situated in the posterior compartment of the leg, it runs alongside the tibial nerve and the posterior tibial vein. From the popliteal fossa, it goes down to the medial malleolus of the ankle, after which it continues to the plantar aspect of the foot. Due to its anatomical course, injury to this artery is infrequent in isolated fibula fractures.

Option D: Injury to the patellar tendon presents with a history of a jumping event with sudden quadriceps contraction with the knee in a flexed position. Injury to the patellar tendon causes infrapatellar pain, with immediate swelling and difficulty bearing weight. Clinical examination will reveal a high-riding patella, with a palpable gap below its inferior pole.

questions.text: 140. All of the following are the components of the Human Development Index (HDI) except _____
questions.solution:
Infant Mortality rate is a component of the physical quality of life index. (PQLI)

The Human Development Index (HDI) is a comprehensive measure that examines three fundamental aspects of human development. These include the length and quality of life, represented by life expectancy at birth, educational attainment, measured by the average years of schooling and expected years of schooling, and economic well-being, assessed by gross national income per capita.

Pearl PM0134: HDI vs. PQLI

 

Human Development Index (HDI)

 Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI)
Components

Longevity (Life expectancy at birth)

A decent standard of living (Real GNI per capita in PPP US$)

Knowledge (mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling)

Life expectancy at 1 year of age 

Infant Mortality rate

Literacy rate
Range 0 to +1 0 to 100

questions.text:
141. A 35-year-old woman presents to the OPD with amenorrhea for the last 8 months. She complains of a loss of libido and problems with intercourse with her partner. There is a previous history of chronic radiation exposure. Investigations are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

FSH: 55 IU/L  Prolactin: 20 ng/mL  Pregnancy test: Negative
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a history of amenorrhea and loss of libido with chronic radiation exposure and elevated FSH levels (> 40 IU/L) in a 35-year-old female point toward the diagnosis of premature ovarian failure.

Premature ovarian failure is defined as ovarian failure occurring before the age of 40 years. Clinically, it presents as secondary amenorrhoea for at least 3 months with raised FSH, raised FSH/LH ratio, and low estrogen.

Causes of POF

* Lesser migration of germ cells from the yolk sac.

* Germ cell apoptosis due to

* Chromosomal abnormalities

* Autoimmune diseases - hypothyroidism, Addison's disease, etc

* Genital TB

* Smoking

* Radiation and chemotherapy

* Hysterectomy

* Prolonged GnRH therapy

* Induction of multiple ovulation.

Clinical features include amenorrhea, hot flashes, sweating, diminished libido, vaginal dryness, and urinary symptoms.

Management:

* Treatment of the cause

* If not interested in pregnancy:

* Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) - Libido improves with estrogen therapy

* If interested in pregnancy:

* Ovulation induction (if an ovarian reserve is present) or donor eggs for in vitro fertilization.

Other options:

Option B: Patients with androgen insensitivity syndrome would have presented with primary amenorrhea. Karyotyping would reveal a 46XY karyotype. LH is raised, but FSH is normal. 

Option C: A prolactinoma would present with elevated prolactin levels.

Option D: In polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS), there are features like menstrual abnormalities, obesity, and hyperandrogenism. LH level is raised, FSH level remains normal, but FSH/LH ratio falls. Estrogen levels increase.

questions.text: 142. A 55-year-old female patient presents with dry eyes, dry mouth, and difficulty swallowing solid food. Examination reveals enlargement of the parotid glands and dryness of the buccal mucosa. Laboratory examination shows the presence of both SS-A and SS-B antibodies. The histopathological image of the salivary gland is given below. All are true about this condition, except ______.

choices.text: About 75% of patients have rheumatoid factor
Patients are at high risk for development of B-cell lymphomas
Lacrimal and salivary glands are mainly involved

questions.solution:
A 55-year-old woman with dry eyes, dry mouth, dysphagia, enlarged parotid glands, and positive SS-A/SS-B antibodies with a salivary gland biopsy showing lymphoplasmacytic infiltration is likely to have Sjögren's syndrome, and glomerular lesions are not common in this condition.

Sjögren's syndrome is a chronic disease wherein the lacrimal and salivary glands undergo immunologically mediated destruction. (Option C) This leads to the characteristic features of dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia).

It can manifest as primary or secondary. Primary is an isolated form known as sicca syndrome. It is characterized by decreased tears and saliva. The salivary glands and lacrimal glands get infiltrated with lymphocytes and undergo fibrosis. The secondary form is associated with other autoimmune disorders. 

Clinically, it is more common in women between 50 and 60 years. They present with a blurring of vision, burning, itching of the eyes, difficulty swallowing solid foods, dryness of the buccal mucosa, and parotid gland enlargement. 

Antibodies directed against two ribonucleoprotein antigens- SS-A (Ro) and SS-B (La) are detected in almost all patients with Sjogren's syndrome. Rheumatoid factor is seen in about 75% of the patients (Option D). ANA is also often detected on an immunofluorescence assay.

A labial biopsy is useful, and histology of salivary glands shows lymphocytic infiltration. Patients are at high risk for the development of B-cell lymphomas. (Option B)

Pearl PM1935: Extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome

The extraglandular manifestations of Sjögren’s syndrome are as follows:

* Non-specific

* Arthralgia or arthritis - It is the most common extraglandular manifestation. It is usually non-erosive and leads to Jacoud’s arthropathy

* Raynaud’s phenomenon

* Accumulation of peri-epithelial lymphocytes

* Interstitial lung disease - Most common type is non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)

* Renal tubular acidosis - Distal (type 1) RTA

* Primary biliary cirrhosis

* Immune complex-mediated

* Small vessel vasculitis - Presents as cutaneous palpable purpura

* Glomerulonephritis with cryoglobulinemia

* Peripheral neuropathy

* Lymphoma

* Extranodal marginal zone B cell lymphoma of mucosal-associated lymphoid tissue (MALToma).

questions.text: 143. A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and mucus, with a history of similar episodes in the past. Colonoscopic biopsy findings have previously revealed granularity and crypt abscesses. Which of the following biochemical parameters will be raised?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of active disease of ulcerative colitis, which elevates the positive acute phase reactant. Among the given options, haptoglobin is a positive acute-phase reactant that will be elevated in this patient.

Acute phase reactants are plasma proteins, mostly synthesized in the liver, whose plasma concentrations may increase or decrease manyfold as part of the response to inflammatory stimuli. Ulcerative colitis is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease. In active disease, the liver increases production of acute-phase reactants, while synthesis of some negative acute-phase proteins falls.

Examples of positive acute phase reactants-

* C-reactive protein (CRP)

* Fibrinogen

* Ferritin

* Hepcidin

* Haptoglobin

* Ceruloplasmin

* Complement proteins C3/C4

* Serum amyloid A (SAA)

Examples of negative acute phase reactants include:

* Albumin 

* Retinol-binding protein 

* Transthyretin (Prealbumin) (option B)

* Transferrin (option A)

* Antithrombin (option C)

Pearl PM0393: Acute phase reactants and their functions

"Positive" acute-phase proteins:

Opsonin on microbes

Serum amyloid P component

Opsonin

Serum amyloid A

Recruitment of immune cells to inflammatory sites

Induction of enzymes that degrade extracellular matrix

Complement factors

Opsonization, lysis, and clumping of target cells; Chemotaxis

Mannan-binding lectin

Mannan-binding lectin pathway of complement activation

Fibrinogen, prothrombin, factor VIII,
von Willebrand factor

Coagulation factors, trapping invading microbes in blood clots.
Some cause chemotaxis, Fibrinogen binds to red cells and induce rouleaux formation

Plasminogen activator inhibitor-1 (PAI-1)

Prevents the degradation of blood clots by inhibiting plasminogen 

Alpha 2-macroglobulin

Inhibitor of coagulation by inhibiting thrombin

Inhibitor of fibrinolysis by inhibiting plasmin

Ferritin

Hepcidin

Stimulates the internalization of ferroportin, preventing release of iron bound by ferritin within intestinal enterocytes and macrophages

Ceruloplasmin

Oxidizes iron, facilitating for ferritin, inhibiting microbe iron uptake

Haptoglobin

Binds hemoglobin, inhibiting microbe iron uptake

(Alpha-1-acid glycoprotein, AGP)

Alpha 1-antichymotrypsin

Serpin, downregulates inflammation

questions.text: 144. A full-term infant who was initially normal and then exhibited progressive lethargy, hypothermia, and apnea. Her biochemical examination reveals hyperornithinemia, hyperammonemia, and homocitrullinemia. Identify the enzyme deficient.
questions.solution:
This given clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of urea cycle disorder, HHH syndrome (hyperornithinemia, hyperammonemia, and homocitrullinuria), in which the enzyme ornithine permease is deficient. 

HHH (hyperornithinemia, hyperammonemia, and homocitrullinuria) syndrome results from a mutation in the ORC1 gene, which is responsible for coding the mitochondrial membrane ornithine carrier/ornithine permease. This genetic defect does not allow the transport of cytosolic ornithine into the mitochondrial matrix, disrupting the urea cycle. Consequently, this leads to an accumulation of cytosolic ornithine (hyperornithinemia) and hyperammonemia.

Additionally, in the absence of ornithine, mitochondrial carbamoyl phosphate reacts with lysine to form homocitrulline, causing homocitrullinuria.

Other options: 

Option A: Hyperargininemia is caused by an arginase enzyme defect, presenting between the ages of 2 and 4. It's characterised by elevated arginine in blood and CSF, and often lysine-cystinuria in urine due to competitive renal reabsorption

Option B: Ornithine transcarbamoylase deficiency is an X-linked genetic disorder that leads to hyperammonemia type 2. Affected mothers may experience hyperammonemia and avoid high-protein foods. Increased ammonia levels result in higher glutamine levels in the blood, cerebrospinal fluid, and urine

Option D: Argininosuccinate lyase deficiency manifests as argininosuccinic aciduria, characterised by elevated levels of argininosuccinate in blood, cerebrospinal fluid, and urine. This condition is often associated with developmental delays and brittle hair, known as trichorrhexis nodosa.

Pearl PM0573: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text:
145. Match the type of collagen with the associated collagen defect disorder.

Types of collagen Collagen defect disorders
1. Type I A- Stickler syndrome
2. Type II B- Alport syndrome
3. Type III C- Ehler-Danlos syndrome
4. Type IV D- Osteogenesis imperfecta
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-D, 2-A, 3-C, 4-B.

Types of collagen Collagen defect disorders

1. Type I

 D- Osteogenesis imperfecta

2. Type II

 A- Stickler syndrome

3. Type III

C- Ehler-Danlos syndrome

4. Type IV

 B- Alport syndrome


Osteogenesis imperfecta is inherited as a dominant trait. It is the result of a mutation that results in the replacement of a single glycine residue by cysteine in type I collagen. The result is brittle bones leading to multiple fractures and skeletal deformities.

Stickler syndrome results from a defect in type II collagen and is characterized by skeletal changes, orofacial abnormalities, and auditory abnormalities.

Ehler-Danlos syndrome is due to defective type III collagen formation due to defective lysyl oxidase or lysyl hydroxylase. It is characterized by the weakening of collagen, loose skin, and hypermobile and lax joints. Hyperextensibility of skin and joints are the hallmark of this condition.

Alport syndrome is due to a defect in type IV collagen. It is characterized by sensorineural hearing loss, anterior lenticonus, and renal insufficiency.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
