questions.text: 146. A 60-year-old man presented with fever, chills, and dysuria. On per rectal examination, his prostate was tender and boggy. His PSA level was 7.4 ng/dL. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute bacterial prostatitis and should be managed with antibiotics.

A rigorous and prolonged treatment for 2-6 weeks with an antibiotic that penetrates the prostate wall is indicated (trimethoprim or ciprofloxacin). Incomplete infection eradication leads to recurrent attacks and chronic prostatitis.

Acute bacterial prostatitis is usually caused by an ascending urinary tract infection (UTI) or reflux of infected urine into prostatic ducts. The most common organism is Escherichia coli. An associated increase in levels of PSA (>4 ng/mL) may be present due to prostate inflammation. 

Symptoms include fever, chills, malaise, painful micturition, perineal heaviness, rectal irritation, and pain on defecation. Urinary frequency may occur if the infection involves the bladder.

A repeat PSA (Option A) in this scenario will be done after completion of treatment with antibiotics for 4-6 weeks. Catheterisation and prostatic massage are contraindicated (Option B) in patients with suspected acute prostatitis, as they increase the chance of bacteremia and sepsis.

Instead, a suprapubic tap should be performed to alleviate retention. If PSA levels remain elevated even after adequate antibiotics, only then is a biopsy indicated. (Option C)

questions.text: 147. You should perform a shake test prior to using all of the following vaccines, except ________.
questions.solution:
Oral polio vaccine (OPV) is a heat-sensitive vaccine, not freeze-sensitive. Hence, a shake test is not relevant for OPV.

The shake test is done to check for damage to vaccines that are sensitive to freezing temperatures.

Steps to perform the shake test:

* A frozen vaccine is used as a control vial, and the vial suspected to be damaged by freezing is taken as the test vial.

* Both are shaken after thawing, and the rate of sedimentation is compared.

* If the rate of sedimentation in the test vial is slower than that in the control vial, then it is usable and has not been damaged.



Some of the most widely used vaccines are freeze-sensitive:

* Hep B (Option D)

* Pentavalent

* DPT (Option C)

* TT (Option B)

* PCV

* IPV

Vaccines like OPV and rotavirus vaccines do not lose their potency and efficacy on freezing. Hence, these vaccines can be used again once they liquefy.

NOTE- Though IPV is a freeze-sensitive vaccine, the shake test does not apply to it, and the IPV vaccine needs to be discarded if doubt about the vaccine getting frozen.

Pearl PM0693: Temperature Sensitivity of Vaccines

B Influenza
C

IPV

Measles, mumps, rubella
D

Cholera

DTaP

Pentavalent

Rotavirus

Yellow fever

Measles

Rubella
E

BCG

HPV

Japanese encephalitis(inactivated)

Tetanus, TD, Td
F

Hepatitis B

Hib(freeze-dried)

Meningococcal A

Pneumococcal


Vaccine sensitivity to freezing:

Rotavirus(liquid)< T,DT,dT< IPV < Hib(liquid)< HepB < Pentavalent
Vaccines not damaged by freezing:

* Hib

* Japanese encephalitis(live and inactivated)

* Measles, mumps, rubella

questions.text: 148. A 45-year-old man diagnosed with hyperlipoproteinemia due to deficiency of lipoprotein lipase was following strict restriction of fat intake in his diet. While enjoying the get-together party with his childhood friends, he accidentally consumes fatty meal. Which of the following lipoproteins will be elevated in this case?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, after a fatty meal, chylomicrons are elevated in lipoprotein lipase deficiency.

Chylomicrons transport dietary lipids from the intestine to the peripheral tissues. They are synthesized in the intestine by assembling apo B-48 with lipids (mainly triacylglycerols).

This is called a nascent chylomicron, which upon receiving apo C-II and apo E from HDL, is remodeled into a mature chylomicron.

Apo C-II activates lipoprotein lipase present on the endothelium. Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is the key enzyme responsible for hydrolyzing triglycerides (TGs) present in chylomicrons (dietary origin) and VLDL (hepatic origin) into free fatty acids, which can then be taken up by tissues.

Familial hyperchylomicronemia (Type I Hyperlipoproteinemia) is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the LPL gene or APOC2 gene. It typically presents early in life with the following features:

* Severe fasting hypertriglyceridemia.

* Recurrent abdominal pain and pancreatitis (classic feature).

* Eruptive xanthomas (yellow papules on extensor surfaces, buttocks, and shoulders).

* Lipemia retinalis and hepatosplenomegaly.

* Plasma appears milky.

Importantly, despite severe lipid elevations, there is no increased risk of premature atherosclerosis, distinguishing it from LDL-related disorders.

Other options:

Option A: Elevated LDL is the hallmark of Familial Hypercholesterolemia (Type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia), usually caused by mutations in the LDL receptor, ApoB100, or PCSK9. Clinically, this condition presents with tendon xanthomas, corneal arcus, and premature coronary artery disease.

Option C: Elevation of VLDL is the hallmark of Type IV hyperlipoproteinemia (Familial Hypertriglyceridemia), due to VLDL overproduction or impaired clearance. It usually presents in adults, is linked with obesity, diabetes, and metabolic syndrome, and carries an increased risk of premature atherosclerosis.

Option D: HDL is involved in reverse cholesterol transport, shuttling excess cholesterol from tissues back to the liver. Low levels are seen in metabolic syndrome, which increases the risk of atherosclerosis.

Pearl PM2169: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, VLDL, TG  Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and eruptive xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and tendon xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL  Atherosclerosis, palmar and tuberoeruptive xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: 149. Which of the following EEG findings in a patient would warrant treatment with ACTH?
questions.solution:
ACTH is used in the management of children with infantile spasms. The EEG in image 4 shows the characteristic hypsarrhythmic pattern - high voltage waves with a chaotic background, that is typically seen in infantile spasms. 

Disease Typical EEG feature
 West syndrome

Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background)

(Image 4)
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)

Periodic biphasic or triphasic sharp-wave complexes seen as spikes.

(Image 1)
Absence seizures

3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern)

(Image 2)
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy

4-5 Hz spike

(Image 3)
Lennox-Gastaut syndrome
  • 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves
  • polyspike bursts in sleep
  • slow background in wakefulness


 

Infantile epileptic spasm is an age-specific seizure disorder that predominantly occurs before the age of one.

Diagnosis may get delayed as the condition can be mistaken for hyperirritability, exaggerated startle responses, or colic.

Clinical features

* Spasms involve the axial and limb muscles, which are symmetric and simultaneous.

* Involves sudden, brief contractions of various muscle groups, followed by a tonic contraction phase that is less intense and lasts up to 10 secs.

* Motor arrest or a period of attenuated responsiveness may occur following the contraction and lasts up to 90 seconds

* Deviation of the eyes, nystagmus and change in respiratory pattern may be seen in some patients

* Most patients develop neurodevelopmental delay

* West syndrome is characterized by a combination of spasms, halted psychomotor development, and hypsarrhythmia.

Diagnosis:

* EEG

* Interictal: Hypsarrhythmia—high-voltage, random slow waves and spikes across the brain, often seen before spasms.

* Ictal: During a spasm, brief high-voltage slow waves are followed by widespread EEG suppression.

* Electrodecremental response: General drop in EEG activity, with or without visible seizures.

* Neuroimaging with CT/MRI is recommended in all patients

* Metabolic and genetic testing may be done to identify the etiology

* EMG reveals a characteristic rhomboid pattern, which may help to distinguish between brief tonic and myoclonic seizures

The major options for the treatment are:

* Hormonal therapy - ACTH

* Antiseizure medication - vigabatrin, usually



CJD is a spongiform encephalopathy caused by a prion. It presents as rapidly progressive dementia and is fatal within 1 year of onset of symptoms. The EEG shows periodic biphasic or triphasic sharp-wave complexes seen as spikes.

Patients present with myoclonus, akinetic mutism, cerebellar or visual disturbances and pyramidal/extrapyramidal dysfunction (hypokinesia). Insomnia, apathy and other behavioral abnormalities may be seen.

Four types of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease have been described:

* Sporadic (sCJD): Accounts for 85-90% of cases

* MRI shows cortical ribbon sign

* Variant (vCJD): mad cow disease, Kuru

* MRI shows hockey stick sign

* Familial (fCJD): 10% of cases (these individuals carry a PRPc mutation)

* Iatrogenic

CSF analysis shows a positive assay for 14-3-3 protein. Management is mainly supportive.



Absence seizures are characterised by a sudden, brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control and no post-ictal confusion is seen in Absence seizures. Usually, the seizure lasts only a few seconds.

They are predominantly seen in children between four to ten years of age, with a decline in academic performance in school and unexplained 'daydreaming'.

The following subtle motor signs may accompany the episodes

* Rapid blinking of the eyelids

* Chewing movements

* Small-amplitude clonic movement of the hands

EEG shows generalised symmetric 3 Hz spike and wave pattern. Hyperventilation can provokes these EEG discharges and seizures.

MRI appears normal hence not routinely recommended. Laboratory investigations are not specifically useful.

Ethosuximide is the drug of choice for uncomplicated typical absence seizure

Sodium valproate is the first-line therapy for absence seizures in cases associated with secondary GTCS and atypical absence

Drugs like carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine and phenytoin can worsen the absence, myoclonic, tonic and atonic seizures and are therefore avoided



Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is also known as Janz syndrome. This disorder typically first manifests itself between the ages of 12 and 18. It presents with brief episodes of involuntary muscle twitching occurring early in the morning after awakening. They can be provoked by sleep deprivation. Most patients also have generalized seizures that affect the entire brain and many also have absence seizures. Myoclonic seizures are characterized by:

* Preserved consciousness

* Preserved postural control

* Lack of postictal confusion

The EEG shows a bilaterally synchronous spike (4-5 Hz polyspike ) and slow-wave discharges. The drug of choice for juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is valproate (Sodium and calcium channel blocker). Lamotrigine is also useful.

EEG Waves

Location where it is best-recorded

Reactivity

8-13

50-100

Parieto-occipital regions

Adults at rest- awake but relaxed with eyes closed, wandering mind

13-30

5-10

<200

In adults who are in deep relaxation and meditation;

questions.text: 150. A middle-aged female with a history of mitral valve replacement 6 months back presents with fever and a new-onset murmur. Echocardiography revealed cardiac vegetation. Blood culture colonies show catalase-positive, coagulase-negative, Gram-positive cocci, sensitive to novobiocin. Which of the following best describes the pathogenic mechanism of the causative agent?

choices.text: Biofilm production gives resistance to antibiotics

questions.solution:
The pathogenic mechanism of the causative agent is best described by biofilm production leading to resistance to antibiotics.

The clinical scenario of a middle-aged female with a history of mitral valve replacement, with an Echo suggestive of cardiac vegetation, and Blood culture colonies showing catalase-positive, coagulase-negative, Gram-positive cocci, sensitive to novobiocin, is suggestive of Staphylococcus epidermidis infection leading to Bacterial Endocarditis. Biofilm production forms its major pathogenic mechanism.

Staphylococcus epidermidis is present as a commensal on human skin. It preferably grows on shunts, artificial cardiac valves, implants, and prosthetic devices, causing bacteremia. It is a novobiocin-sensitive, coagulase-negative, non-pigmented, non-hemolytic coccus. It also doesn't ferment mannitol. 

Biofilm production acts as a major virulence factor for the pathogen. Biofilm refers to an extracellular polysaccharide matrix that helps in colonisation and imparts resistance against antibiotics. Coagulase-negative Staphylococci are a part of normal human flora, and they include S. saprophyticus, S. haemolyticus, and S. lugdunensis, apart from Staphylococcus epidermidis. 

An approach to Gram-positive cocci is summarised below :



Other options:

Option A: Protein A-mediated anti-phagocytic effect forms a pathogenic mechanism of Staphylococcus aureus. Protein A is anti-phagocytic and anti-complementary.

Option B: Panton-Valentine Leucocidin-mediated effect is another pathogenic mechanism of Staphylococcus aureus. It has cytolytic action.

Option D: Capsular polysaccharide preventing opsonisation from the pathogenic mechanism of Streptococcus pneumoniae. Capsule also imparts an antigenic property to the pathogen.

questions.text: 151. A microbiologist cultured a urine sample of a paraplegic patient with a Foley's catheter in situ, with a history of fever and lower abdominal pain. He found the following type of colonies on blood agar. Which of the following is the most probable organism isolated from this culture?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history is suggestive of a patient suffering from a urinary tract infection with a Foley's catheter in situ, and the image showing swarming on blood agar with discrete colonies is suggestive of infection by Proteus mirabilis, which is commonly responsible for urinary tract infections in patients undergoing long-term catheterisation.

Here, the ​​actively motile cells spread on the surface of the plate in successive waves to form a thin, filmy layer in concentric circles. 

Genus Proteus is a non-lactose-fermenting, facultatively anaerobic, motile, Gram-negative bacillus that is oxidase-negative and catalase-positive. They are usually capable of utilising citrate as their sole carbon source and exhibit swarming on nutrient and blood agar.

The flagella of Proteus mirabilis enable its movement. The bacteria break down urea, releasing ammonia that raises urine pH, creating an alkaline environment that encourages kidney stone formation.

Other organisms exhibiting swarming growth in culture media are:

Gram-positive bacilli

* Clostridium septicum

* Bacillus cereus

Gram-negative bacilli

* Vibrio alginolyticus

* Proteus vulgaris

* Proteus mirabilis

Pearl PM1732: Types of motility of microorganisms

Motility Microorganism
Darting/vibratory motility  Vibrio,Campylobacter
Swarming motility Cl. septicum, B.cereus, Proteus, some Vibrio sp
Tumbling motility  Listeria monocytogenes
Stately motility Clostridia
Spinning motility Fusobacterium gyrans
Cork-screw motility  Treponema pallidum
Falling leaf motility Giardia
Twitching motility Eikenella corrodens
Differential motility (Motility varies at different temperatures) Yersinia enterocolitica & Listeria monocytogenes
Jerky motility  Trichomonas vaginalis
Gliding motility Mycoplasma, Entamoeba
Lashing motility  Saprophytic spirochetes

questions.text: 152. Antigenic variation is most commonly seen with:

choices.text: Type A and B influenza virus

questions.solution:
Antigenic variation is most commonly seen with the Type A influenza virus.

Influenza is caused by orthomyxovirus type A, B, and C. Type A is the most common, associated with pandemics, outbreaks and is responsible for most of the antigenic variation. 

Antigenic shift is a major and drastic change caused by genetic reassortment between human, swine, and avian influenza viruses, which results in the emergence of a new subtype of virus. It is seen in influenza A virus and absent in B and C, as only a few related viruses are present in animals. It is a unique property of the influenza virus because of its segmented genome.

Antigenic drift is a gradual change caused by the accumulation of point mutations in protein-encoding genes. All 3 types of influenza virus exhibit antigenic drift.

Antigenic shift Antigenic drift
Occur in type A Occurs in type A and to a lesser extent in type B
Results in pandemics and major epidemics Results in periodic epidemic and sporadic cases
Due to genetic reassortment Due to a point mutation
Occurs every 20-30 years Occurs every 2-3 years

questions.text: 153. A 27-year-old woman at 28 weeks of gestation presented with a 5-day history of severe, sharp, and constant abdominal pain. An ultrasound scan showed a healthy fetus and several large fibroids. A subsequent MRI revealed changes in the fibroid as given below. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: The fibroid has a purple red colour and a fishy odour.
This degeneration has a "womb-stones’ in graveyards" appearance.
Appendicitis in pregnancy is an important differential diagnosis
It is managed conservatively with analgesics.

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of red degeneration of the fibroid. The "womb-stones’ in graveyards' appearance is seen in calcareous degeneration, due to the deposition of phosphates and carbonates of lime.

Red degeneration is a complication (secondary change) of fibroids that often develops during pregnancy or after the age of 40. The myoma becomes tense and causes severe abdominal pain with constitutional upset and fever. The fibroid assumes a peculiar purple-red colour and a fishy odour. (Option A)

It needs to be differentiated from appendicitis, twisted ovarian cyst, pyelitis and accidental haemorrhage. (Option C)

It is managed conservatively with analgesics. (Option D)

Myomectomy at caesarean section carries the risk of uncontrolled bleeding and hence is not done except in the case of a pedunculated fibroid.

Hyaline degeneration is the most common type of secondary change, whereas sarcomatous change is the least common.

Pearl PM0994: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

* Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy

* Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration

* Red degeneration

* Sarcomatous change

* Torsion, hemorrhage

* Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp

* Inversion of the uterus

* Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma

* Endometrial and myohyperplasia

* Accompanying adenomyosis

* Parasitic fibroid

Pearl PM1004: Indications for treatment in an asymptomatic fibroid

* Infertility caused by a cornual fibroid blocking the tube, or a submucous fibroid causing habitual abortions.

* Any fibroid of more than 12 weeks size

* A pedunculated fibroid which can undergo torsion

* A fibroid causing pressure on the ureter/ bladder, leaving residual urine and causing a urinary infection.

* Rapidly growing fibromyoma in a menopausal woman implying impending malignancy

* When the nature of the tumor cannot be ascertained clinically (laparotomy is needed on this occasion).

questions.text: 154. A person arrested with charges of burglary shows dramatic gestures, waving of hands, sings loudly, and rants incoherently. He has similar episodes in the presence of prison guards and court officials. However, he tends to collapse and nap when not under scrutiny. History taking with relatives revealed no such previous episodes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of feigned insanity.

Feigned insanity is seen in a person who is arrested for certain charges and wants to escape criminal charges based on psychological unwellness. The behavior occurs only when the individual is aware of being observed and is characterized by inconsistent, exaggerated reactions that are intentional.

Feigned illness cannot persist for long; the patient sleeps well after a day or two and cannot handle exertion for more than a few days before breaking down. They maintain personal hygiene and appear normal, but they resent their situation due to a fear of detection.

Trait Real Mental Illness Feigned Mental Illness
1. Onset Gradual Sudden
2. Motive Absent Present (e.g., crime)
3. Predisposing Often present (e.g., family history) Absent
4. Symptoms Consistent, even when unobserved Vary with observation; exaggerated
5. Mood Fluctuating Overacted
6. Expression Vacant or fixed Voluntary, exaggerated
7. Insomnia Persistent Sleeps well after 1–2 days
8. Habits Dirty/filthy Clean
9. Exams Cooperative Avoids (fear of detection)


Other options: 

Option A: Manic disorder can be triggered without any external stimulus and can happen anywhere or anytime, which is not the case in this question, hence ruling out this option. 

Option  C: Conversion disorder/functional neurological symptom disorder is the presence of involuntary, neurologic symptoms (e.g., paralysis, mutism) which is not intentionally produced and are different from the known neurological diseases. It is often triggered by stress, with no obvious external motivation, and may have a history of child abuse or any other adverse event.

Option D: Factitious disorder/Munchausen syndrome involves patients feigning an illness to receive medical care. Patient presents themselves as ill to others to gain attention or cope with stress and falsify physical and psychiatric symptoms even in the absence of lab work. Additionally, deceptive behavior persists even when no external rewards are present, unlike feigned insanity.

questions.text: 155. A young woman presents with complaints of a painless ulcer in the genital area. It is associated with non-tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. The patient does not have a history of penicillin allergy. Which colour-coded kit can be provided to this patient??
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a painless ulcer and non-tender lymphadenopathy is suggestive of primary syphilis. Since the patient isn't allergic to Penicillin, syndromic management is done by prescribing a white kit to the patient.

The white kit, or kit number 3, is for non-herpetic genital ulcers that include syphilis and chancroid. It contains injection Benzathine penicillin G and tablet Azithromycin. The key component of the white Kit for syphilis is Benzathine penicillin, which is administered as a single intramuscular injection. Tablet Azithromycin is given as a single 1g dose to target Hemophilus ducreyi, which causes chancroid. Partner treatment is also done in both cases.

Other options: 

Option A: The green kit is used when there is abnormal vaginal discharge, burning while passing urine, increased frequency of micturition, or lower backache. It contains the drugs Secnidazole and Fluconazole

Option C: The blue kit is also used for syphilitic ulcers, but is for those who are allergic to Penicillin. It has 100 mg of Doxycycline instead of Penicillin. 

Option D: The red kit is used for herpetic genital ulcers, which present as painful vesicular-ulcerative lesions. It contains Acyclovir 400 mg to be taken orally TID for 7 days. No partner treatment is required.

Pearl PM0008: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

  Genital herpes  Syphilitic chancre (Hard chancre) Donovanosis/ granuloma inguinale Chancroid (soft chancre) LGV
Incubation period 2-7 days

10-90 days 

Average: 21days

 7-84 days 1-14 days 3 days - 6 weeks
Causative agent HSV-2>HSV-1 Treponema pallidum Klebsiella granulomatis Hemophilus ducreyi

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1,L2,L3
Clinical presentation

Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base.

Painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy

Single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border.

Painless lymphadenopathy

Painless papule or nodule erodes into beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges.

No lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen

Painful ulcer (ducreyi makes you cry).

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

Painless genital ulcer.

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy
Diagnosis  Tzanck preparation shows multinucleated giant cells, PCR Clinical diagnosis Donovan bodies on biopsy Clinical diagnosis Nucleic acid amplification tests
Treatment Acyclovir/famcyclovir or valacyclovir Penicillin/Ceftriaxone

Azithromycin/Doxycycline

 Azithromycin/ceftriaxone  Doxycycline/Azithromycin


Pearl PM2456: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

* It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.

* The ulcers are painful.



 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

* It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.

* The ulcers are usually painless.

* Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 

* Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:



 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

* Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.

* The ulcer is painful.

* Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.

* It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 

* Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance



 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

* It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.

* The ulcer is painless.

* Causes painless lymphadenopathy.

* Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.



 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

* It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.

* The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.

* Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:





 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

* It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.

* It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.

* The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:



Pearl PM2024: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections



Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: 156. Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in a patient with aortic stenosis?

choices.text: Rapidly rising pulse with sudden collapse
Lateral displacement of the apical impulse

questions.solution:
Aortic stenosis (AS) shows a slow-rising pulse with a delayed peak — this is known as pulsus parvus et tardus. Rapidly rising pulse with sudden collapse (option B) is seen in aortic regurgitation (AR) — this is known as water hammer pulse.

Other examination findings in patients with AS include:

* A thrill may be palpable on the carotid arteries, more often on the left side.

* Ejection systolic murmur which increases in intensity to reach a peak towards the middle of ejection (known as crescendo-decrescendo pattern), and ends right before aortic valve closure. (Option A)

* Aortic valve closure occurs after pulmonary valve closure, leading to paradoxical splitting of S2 — splitting of S2 in expiration, not in inspiration. (Option C)

* Lateral displacement of the apical impulse (option D).

The given phonocardiogram shows the character of normal and abnormal heart sounds:



Pearl PM1194: Grading of Aortic Stenosis

Grading of stenosis

Area of aortic valve

Mild

1.5 – 2 sq cm

Moderate

1 – 1.5 sq cm

Severe

< 1 sq cm

questions.text: 157. A 50-year-old female complains of lower backache. The radiographic image of her lumbosacral spine is given below. Her bone mineral density is measured and the T-score is found to be -2.6. The senior resident is apprehensive of a risk of vertebral fracture and started her on a recombinant preparation of parathyroid hormone. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this drug?

choices.text: Continuous administration of this drug promotes bone growth
It has to be administered subcutaneously
It  can increase the risk of osteosarcoma

questions.solution:
Teriparatide is a recombinant preparation of parathyroid hormone. Teriparatide increases bone formation, especially when given in low doses and intermittently. Continuous administration of PTH or high-circulating PTH levels can cause bone demineralization and osteopenia.

The given clinical scenario with low back pain, a T-score of -2.6, and the above image depicting the ballooning of disc spaces leading to the biconcave shape of the vertebral body known as ‘Codfish appearance’, are suggestive of osteoporosis. Teriparatide can be used in this condition.

Pharmacokinetics and systemic actions of teriparatide on mineral metabolism are the same as for PTH.

Teriparatide increases bone formation (option D), especially when given in low doses and intermittently (option A).

Although it may be more effective than bisphosphonates and estrogen, it has to be administered subcutaneously (option B) every day. Hence, it is indicated mostly in severe osteoporosis.

Teriparatide can increase the risk of osteosarcoma (option C) and it is contraindicated in conditions such as:

* Paget disease

* Young adults with open epiphysis

* Prior h/o of radiotherapy

* Unexplained elevated ALP

* Hypercalcemia

Osteoporosis most commonly occurs in postmenopausal women and in old age.

The secondary causes of osteoporosis are:

* Hypogonadal states: Turner's and Klinefelter's syndrome, Hyperprolactinemia

* Endocrine disorders: Cushing's syndrome, hyperparathyroidism and hyperthyroidism, diabetes mellitus

* Haematological disorders: Multiple myeloma, lymphoma and leukaemia, haemophilia, thalassemia

* Nutritional and gastrointestinal disorders: Malnutrition, parenteral nutrition, malabsorption syndrome, gastrectomy, pernicious anaemia

* Rheumatologic disorders: Rheumatoid arthritis and ankylosing spondylitis

* Inherited disorders: 

* Osteogenesis imperfecta

* Marfan's syndrome

* Ehler's Danlos syndrome

* Hypophosphatasia

* Prolonged immobilization

* Pregnancy and lactation

Investigations:

The X-ray would depict ballooning of disc spaces leading to the biconcave shape of the vertebral body known as ‘Codfish appearance’, classically seen in osteoporosis. 

It is caused due to the reduction in the strength of the bone that leads to an increased risk of fractures. WHO defines osteoporosis as a T score of less than -2.5. It is the gold standard to assess bone mineral density.

Other radiological features of osteoporosis:

* Loss of vertical height of vertebra due to collapse

* Ground glass appearance of bones especially in the bones like the pelvis

* Loss of cortical bone (picture frame vertebrae) and trabecular bone (ghost vertebrae)

* Loss of trabeculae in proximal femur area.

The investigation of choice for the diagnosis of osteoporosis is DEXA - dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry. A T-score <–2.5 in the lumbar spine, femoral neck, or total hip has been defined as osteoporosis.

DEXA measures the bone mineral density of an individual. These measurements are made at the lumbar spine, femoral neck, or hip. In the DEXA technique, two x-ray energies are used to estimate the area of mineralized tissue, and the mineral content is divided by bone area, which partially corrects for body and bone size. But since the method is two dimensional, the correction is not adequate and the BMD(Bone Mineral Density) of small slim people tend to be lower than average BMD. Also, bone spurs, tend to falsely increase bone density especially of the spine and are a particular problem in measuring spine BMD in older individuals with osteoarthritis.

Chemical tests like serum calcium, phosphorus and alkaline phosphatase levels are usually normal. But, osteoblastic and osteoclastic markers in urine & blood can help in diagnosing and monitoring treatment.

Pearl PM1958: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

* Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.

* Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.

* Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: 158. Flumazenil can be used as a reversal agent for which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Flumazenil can also be used as a reversal agent for chloral hydrate.

Flumazenil is a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine binding site on the GABA-A receptor complex. It is primarily used to reverse the sedative, respiratory depressant, and cognitive effects of benzodiazepines. However, chloral hydrate, which is metabolized to trichloroethanol, also exerts its sedative-hypnotic effect through the benzodiazepine receptor site on the GABA-A receptor. This makes flumazenil effective as a reversal agent for chloral hydrate as well.

Flumazenil is used as a reversal agent for the following:

* Benzodiazepines like midazolam, diazepam, lorazepam, remimazolam, and flunitrazepam.

* Chloral hydrate

* Cannabis intoxication

* Carbamazepine overdose

* Alcohol overdose

Other options:

Option A. Propofol acts on GABA-A receptors but at a site different from benzodiazepines, so its CNS depressant effects cannot be reversed by flumazenil, and management of overdose is supportive.

Option B. Ketamine produces dissociative anesthesia through NMDA receptor antagonism and has no interaction with benzodiazepine binding sites, making flumazenil ineffective; overdose is treated with supportive measures.

Option D. Fentanyl is a μ-opioid receptor agonist, and its CNS and respiratory depressant effects are specifically reversed by naloxone, not flumazenil.

questions.text: 159. What is the extent of the danger space?

choices.text: Base of skull to tracheal bifurcation
Base of skull to hyoid bone

questions.solution:
The danger space extends from the base of the skull to the diaphragm.

It lies between the alar fascia anteriorly and the prevertebral fascia posteriorly. It is just posterior to the retropharyngeal space. Infection from this space can spread to the mediastinum, and hence it is named the danger space.

Other options:

Option A: The prevertebral space extends from the base of the skull to the coccyx.

Option B: Retropharyngeal space extends from the base of the skull to the tracheal bifurcation.

Option C: Parapharyngeal space extends from the base of the skull to the hyoid bone and submandibular gland.

questions.text: 160. Identify the disorder associated with the type of cataract shown in the given image.
questions.solution:
Image shows shield-like dense anterior subcapsular plaque that wrinkles the anterior capsule which is characteristic of cataract seen in atopic dermatitis.

Option A: Classic diabetic cataract, which is actually rare, consists of snowflake cortical opacities occurring in the young diabetic; it may mature within a few days or resolve spontaneously. Age-related cataract occurs earlier in diabetes mellitus. Nuclear opacities are common and tend to progress rapidly.

The image showing the snowflake cataract is given below:



Option B: About 90% of patients with myotonic dystrophy develop fine iridescent cortical opacities in the third decade, sometimes resembling a Christmas tree cataract.

An image showing a Christmas tree cataract is shown below:



Option D: Rosette cataract is seen in the case of blunt trauma.

The image showing rosette catarct is shown below:

questions.text:
161. Which of the following is not associated with CRISPR-Cas9?

CRISPR- Clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats
questions.solution:
CRISPR-Cas9 is not associated with post-translational modification.

Clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats-associated gene 9, or CRISPR-Cas9, is a DNA editing/gene regulatory system. It involves two essential components: Cas9, an endonuclease that causes a double-stranded DNA break, allowing modifications to the genomic DNA to be made; and a synthetic single guide RNA or sgRNA responsible for guiding Cas9 to its target.

CRISPR-Cas9 is a tool used in modifying gene expression by the above-mentioned mechanism. It can be used to introduce breaks and bring out repairs in DNA by non-homologous end joining (Option B). After creating the same breaks, an RNA with complementary base can be added to silence the expression and knock out the desired gene (Option D).

FELUDA is a CRISPR-Cas9-based test to detect the genomic sequence of the SARS-CoV-2 virus and is used as a quicker, cheaper and effective alternative to RT-PCR. (Option C)

Many proteins are initially synthesised as inactive pro-proteins requiring post-translational modifications—such as N-terminal cleavage by aminopeptidases or addition of functional groups by specific enzymes—for activation. CRISPR, by contrast, operates at the DNA or RNA level and is not involved in post-translational modification.

The following image shows the CRISPR-Cas9 system:

questions.text: 162. A 57 year old man complains of low back pain. Radiological investigations reveal degenerative changes in the nucleus pulposus of the intervertebral disc. What is the embryological origin of this structure?
questions.solution:
The embryological origin of the nucleus pulposus of the intervertebral disc is the notochord. 

Notochord regresses entirely in the region of the vertebral bodies (during their embryological development) but persists in the region of the intervertebral disc, where it contributes to form the nucleus pulposus. 

The nucleus pulposus is a mucoid, gel-like substance that lies between the centre of the intervertebral disc and its posterior surface. At birth, it is almost completely gelatinous and liquid, but as the individual ages, it becomes less differentiated from the remainder of the intervertebral disc, becoming less hydrated and increasingly fibrous. The nucleus pulposus is indeed a direct remnant of the notochord. 

Below is the image showing vertebral formation and the nucleus pulposus:





During the third week of embryological development, the process of gastrulation occurs, which refers to the formation of the three germ layers: ectoderm, mesoderm and endoderm.

This is followed by the formation of the notochord, which is a rod-like axial structure that induces the formation of the neural tube above it. During the formation of the neural tube, some cells at the lateral border dissociate and form the neural crest cells, which are sometimes referred to as the fourth germ layer. 

After the formation of the notochord, which is the axial structure, the mesoderm on either side can be seen to be organized into three layers as follows:

* Para-axial mesoderm

* Intermediate mesoderm

* Lateral plate mesoderm 

Below is the image showing neural crest and neural tube:



Pearl PM2393: Derivatives of Mesoderm

 

Mesoderm derivatives
Paraxial mesoderm
  • Skeletal muscles of the trunk, limbs, head, and neck
  • Extraocular muscles
  • Intrinsic muscles of the tongue
  • Bones: Vertebrae, ribs
  • Dermis of Skin
  • Duramater
Intermediate mesoderm
  • Urinary system: Kidneys, ureters, trigone of the urinary bladder
  • Dorsal part of prostatic urethra (males)
  • Gonads: Testes and ovaries
  • Genital ducts
  • Adrenal cortex
Lateral plate mesoderm
  • Bones: Sternum, limb bones
  • Serous membranes of body cavities: Pleura, pericardium, peritoneum
  • GIT layers: Lamina propria, muscularis mucosae, submucosa, muscularis externa, adventitia
  • Blood cells: Microglia, Kupffer cells
  • Cardiovascular system
  • Lymphatic system
  • Laryngeal cartilages


Pearl PM1974: Neural crest derivatives

Neural

Mesenchymal

All ganglions

Connective tissue and bones of the face and skull 

All enteric plexus

Dermis of the head and face

Schwann cells and Satellite glial cells

Odontoblasts (Dentine)

Adrenal Medulla

Arachnoid and Piamater 

Parafolliular C cells of Thyroid

Conotruncal septum in the heart

Melanoblast/Melanocytes (except Retinal Pigment Epithelium)

questions.text: 163. A middle-aged man with a tingling sensation in his lower limbs underwent a lower limb Doppler study, and an image from the study is given below. The given waveform is most likely suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The given Doppler waveform showing a triphasic flow pattern is most likely suggestive of a normal arterial flow.

Elastic arteries like the femoral artery, supplying high-resistance beds, exhibit a pronounced triphasic flow pattern. The first wave shows a rapid systolic upstroke. This is followed by early diastolic flow reversal due to the combination of arterial wall rebound and high peripheral resistance, resulting in a transient negative Doppler component. It is followed by a slower, but still forward, flow of blood in late diastole.

Other Options:

Option B: Arterial flow with mild-moderate stenosis shows a biphasic waveform. The image showing a biphasic flow is given below:



Option C: A severely stenosed artery flow shows a monophasic waveform. The image showing a monophasic flow is shown below:



Option D:  The normal venous waveform shows a variation (phasicity) secondary to respiration, referred to as a respirophasic waveform. Loss of this phasic variation results in a monophasic waveform suggestive of a venous obstruction.

An image showing a normal Doppler waveform of the Inferior vena cava is shown below:

questions.text:
164. In severe asthma, reduced expression of histone deacetylase 2 (HDAC2) impairs the anti-inflammatory action of corticosteroids. Which of the following drugs has been shown to restore HDAC2 activity and potentially improve steroid responsiveness?

ICS - Inhaled corticosteroids
questions.solution:
Theophylline has been shown to restore HDAC2 activity and potentially improve steroid responsiveness.

Theophylline is a methylxanthine that has many mechanisms of action for bronchodilation, such as inhibition of phosphodiesterase, adenosine receptor antagonism, IL-10 release, and histone deacetylase activation. 

In severe asthma, especially steroid-resistant asthma, there is often a reduction in histone deacetylase 2 (HDAC2) activity.  HDAC2 is critical for the anti-inflammatory action of corticosteroids, as it helps in repressing pro-inflammatory gene transcription. Low concentrations of theophylline have been shown to increase HDAC2 activity, thereby improving corticosteroid responsiveness.

Other options: 

Option A: Montelukast is a leukotriene inhibitor and has no role in increasing corticosteroid responsiveness. 

Option C: Formoterol is a long-acting bronchodilator and does not have a mechanism of increasing HDAC2 activity. They are FDA-approved for the treatment of asthma and COPD. 

Option D: Benralizumab is an IL-5 receptor-alpha blocker that is used in severe asthma patients with high eosinophil count. It decreases oral corticosteroid dependence in asthmatic patients to come off steroid treatments.

questions.text: 165. A 25-year-old swimmer presents with severe neck pain after a diving injury into shallow water. The following is the CT of the cervical spine of the patient. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and the CT image is a Jefferson's fracture. 

A burst fracture of the C1 ring, as seen on this CT, resulting from an axial load, when the patient dived into shallow water, is known as a Jefferson's fracture. The fracture is identified on the open-mouth X-ray view (odontoid view). A CT or MRI scan can be used to confirm and define the fracture. As shown in the image, the two axial CT scans show the fracture lines at the bilateral lateral and ventral (red arrows) sides of the C1 ring. 

The treatment approach is as follows:

* Stable burst fracture - Use a rigid cervical collar. 

* Unstable fracture - Reduced by halo traction and managed by halo vest. 

* If there is residual instability, surgical fusion of the posterior atlantoaxial joint may be required.

Other options: 

Option A: Odontoid fracture, also known as dens fracture, whereby there is a fracture of the odontoid process of the axis vertebrae.



Option C: Clay shoveller’s fracture is an avulsion of the spinous process of the lower cervical vertebra.



Option D: Chance fracture/jack knife is a horizontal fracture of the vertebral body caused commonly by seat belt injury due to combined flexion and posterior distraction of the mid-lumbar spine.





Pearl PM1021: Jefferson's Fracture

A burst fracture of C1 ring resulting from an axial load is known as Jefferson's Fracture.

The fracture is identified on the open-mouth X-ray view (odontoid view). A CT scan will confirm and define the fracture.

If combined overhang of lateral processes of C1 on C2 > 7mm in the open-mouth view, the transverse ligament is likely to be ruptured (rule of Spence).





Pearl PM1477: Named fractures of the vertebra

Burst fracture - Vertical compression injury

Chance fracture - horizontal fracture of the vertebral body

Clay-shoveller's fracture - spinous process fracture of C6, C7 or T1

Dens fracture - Odontoid process fracture

Hangman's fracture - fracture of both pedicles of C2

Holdsworth fracture - unstable spinal fracture-dislocation at the thoracolumbar junction

Jefferson's fracture - fracture of first cervical vertebra

Motorcyclist's fracture - transverse fracture across base of the skull

Whiplash's injury - hyperextension followed by flexion 

Undertaker's fracture -Post-mortem fracture of the lower cervical spine with C6-C7 disc disruption

questions.text: 166. A 56-year-old male presents to the surgery clinic with pain and a tingling sensation in his fingers. On inquiring further, he describes this sensation as being restricted to the medial 1 ½ fingers. Additionally, he finds it difficult to hold his pen while writing. At what level does the affected nerve divide into superficial and deep branches?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation is consistent with Guyon canal syndrome, and the implicated nerve is the ulnar nerve. The ulnar nerve divides into its terminal branches at the level of the hook of the hamate, into a deep motor and superficial sensory branch. 

Guyon canal syndrome/handlebar palsy is caused by entrapment of the ulnar nerve as it courses through the Guyon canal in the wrist and is commonly seen in regular cyclists. This occurs due to prolonged pressure on the nerve against the bicycle handlebars. 

Guyon’s canal is located on the anteromedial side of the flexor aspect of the wrist. Guyon's canal is a 4 cm long canal formed by the splitting of the flexor retinaculum along the anteromedial side of the wrist. The Guyon canal is clinically significant because it contains the ulnar nerve and artery & is the site of compression injury.



At the hook of hamate, the ulnar nerve divides into:

* Superficial branch → sensory (palmaris brevis and skin of medial 1½ fingers).

* Deep branch → motor (hypothenar muscles, medial 2 lumbricals, interossei, adductor pollicis).

Depending on the site of compression, Guyon’s canal syndrome produces both sensory and motor symptoms in the hand. Proximal nerve compression affects both sensory and motor modalities. However, if the compression occurs distal to the bifurcation, either the sensory or motor branch will be compromised.

Clinical features include:

* Sensory: Tingling, numbness, and burning sensation in the medial 1½ fingers 

* Motor: Weakness of intrinsic hand muscles leads to difficulty with fine motor tasks like holding a pen, buttoning a shirt, and manipulating small objects.



Other options:

Option A: The ulnar nerve passes behind the medial epicondyle of the humerus in the cubital tunnel. At this site, the nerve is superficial and prone to injury, which causes cubital tunnel syndrome.

Option B: The proximal interosseous membrane is the site where the median nerve gives off the anterior interosseous nerve (supplying flexor pollicis longus, pronator quadratus, and part of flexor digitorum profundus).

Option C: Styloid process refers to the bony prominence at the distal radius near the wrist joint. The ulnar nerve passes near the pisiform and Guyon’s canal, not at the styloid process.

questions.text: 167. A 30-year-old P1L1 woman is found to have an asymptomatic invasive disease of the cervix penetrating to a depth of 4 mm and 6 mm wide. She wishes to preserve fertility. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Invasive cervical disease measuring 6mm in width and 4mm in depth is stage IA2. The most appropriate management here would be a radical trachelectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy.

Stage IA2 is defined as carcinoma that is strictly confined to the cervix and the measured stromal invasion is >3 mm and not >5 mm in depth and no wider than 7mm.

For patients who desire to preserve their fertility, radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy are the treatment of choice. For women who do not desire to preserve fertility, radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy are advised.

Other options:

Option A - Chemoradiation is indicated from stage IB onwards.

Option B - Conization is indicated in women who want to preserve fertility and with stage 1A1 disease.

Option D - Simple hysterectomy is indicated in women who do not want to preserve fertility and with stage 1A1 disease.

2. Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

Some IB2, IIA1

IVB Palliative chemotherapy or palliative radiotherapy or supportive care


Pearl PM1903: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

* A: Microscopic lesion

* A1 - stromal invasion ≤3mm depth

* A2 - a stromal invasion of >3 and ≤5mm depth

* B: Macroscopic lesion

* B1 - stromal invasion >5mm depth & tumor size ≤2cm 

* B2 - tumor size >2cm to ≤4cm 

* B3 - tumor size >4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

* A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement

* A1 - tumor size ≤4cm 

* A2 - tumor size >4cm 

* B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

* A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina

* B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)

* C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent

* C1: pelvic lymph node involved

* C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

* A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)

* B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text: 168. A 56-year-old male is admitted to the ICU with a heart rate of 160/min and blood pressure 70/46 mmHg. A decision was made to administer an infusion of norepinephrine to maintain blood pressure when not controlled on adequate fluid resuscitation. Norepinephrine has minimal action on which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
Norepinephrine has minimal action on beta-2 receptors. 

Norepinephrine is a catecholamine that acts on α-1, α-2, and β-1, and has relatively minimal action on β-2 receptors. 

Norepinephrine is a neurotransmitter and hormone that mainly acts on α-1, α-2, and β-1 adrenergic receptors. Its major actions include:

* Increasing heart rate and contractility 

* Causing vasoconstriction, raising blood pressure 

* Increase in systolic blood pressure and diastolic blood pressure

* Increase in peripheral vascular resistance

Overall, norepinephrine’s most prominent physiological effects are increased blood pressure and increased heart rate. Compensatory vagal reflex can decrease the heart rate, overcoming the direct action. 

Epinephrine acts via α-1, α-2, β-1, β-2 and β-3 which causes:

* Increase in heart rate and contractility

* Increase in blood pressure

* Slight decrease in peripheral vascular resistance

* Vasodilation

* Increase blood glucose and lactate

questions.text: 169. A 46-year-old male is scheduled for a tooth extraction procedure. He has a history of infective endocarditis, which was treated 5 years back. What is the preferred oral prophylaxis regimen which can be used for this patient?

choices.text: Clindamycin 4 doses of 600 mg every 8 hours
Amoxicillin 2 g, 1 hour before the procedure
Cefazolin 1 g, 30 minutes before the procedure

questions.solution:
The preferred oral prophylactic regimen for a patient with a history of infective endocarditis undergoing a dental procedure is a single dose of 2 grams of amoxicillin, 1 hour before the procedure.

High-risk lesions where antibiotic prophylaxis is indicated before a dental procedure:

* Prosthetic heart valves or material for valve repair

* LVADs or implantable heart devices

* History of endocarditis

* Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease (including shunts/conduits)

* Repaired congenital heart defects within 6 months

* Repaired congenital heart disease with residual defects near the prosthetic material

* Surgical/transcatheter pulmonary artery valve or conduit placement

Antibiotic Regimens for the prophylaxis of endocarditis in adults with High-Risk Cardiac Lesions: 

Situation  Agent Adults
Oral or standard regimen Amoxicillin 2g PO 1 hr before procedure
Unable to take oral medication Ampicillin  2g IV or IM within 1 hr before procedure
Allergic to penicillin
  1. Cephalexin
  2. Clarithromycin or azithromycin 
  3. Doxycycline

1. 2 g PO 1 h before procedure

2. 500 mg PO 1 h before procedure

3. 100 mg PO 1 h before procedure
Allergic to penicillin/ampicillin, unable to take oral medication Cefazolin or ceftriaxone  1 g IV or IM 30 min before procedure


Other options:

Option A: Clindamycin is no longer recommended for antibiotic prophylaxis before dental procedures.

Option C: Cefazolin is given as IV dosing when the patient is allergic to penicillin/ampicillin or unable to take oral medication. 

Option D: Doxycycline is given when the patient is allergic to penicillin, but can take oral medications.

questions.text: 170. What type of tympanogram is expected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image is diagnostic of serous otitis media, and type B tympanogram is seen with this condition.

Following features in the given image favours the diagnosis of serous otitis media:

* The golden yellow colour of the tympanic membrane (due to clear watery straw-coloured effusion filling the middle ear)

* Structures of the middle ear are seen clearly (due to the clear fluid in the middle ear cavity)

* Thin leash of blood vessels are seen along the handle of the malleus and the periphery of the tympanic membrane (this differentiates the condition from ASOM where there is marked congestion of the tympanic membrane)

Serous otitis media, also known as secretory otitis media, mucoid otitis media, or glue ear, is characterized by the accumulation of nonpurulent, serous effusion in the middle ear cleft. The fluid accumulation causes decreased mobility of the tympanic membrane, leading to a flat or dome-shaped curve, which results in a B-type tympanogram, as shown below:



Pearl PM0227: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: 171. Which of the following statements is false about the image shown below?

choices.text: Hot and humid weather is necessary for this change
It is a late sign of death

questions.solution:
The above image shows the mummification of the body. The false statement about mummification is that hot and humid weather is necessary for this change.

Mummification is a process of dehydration or drying and shrivelling of the cadaver that occurs from the evaporation of water. The absence of moisture in the air and the continuous action of dry or warmed air and hot weather are necessary for the process of mummification.

The mummified body is odourless (Option A). The natural appearances of the body and general facial features are preserved (Option C). It is a late sign of death (Option D).

Mummification begins in the exposed parts of the body and then extends to the entire body, including the internal organs.

The skin becomes shrunken and contracted, dry, brittle, leathery, and rusty-brown to black in colour, stretched tightly across anatomical prominences, followed by breakage of the subcutaneous adipose tissues, and the skin becomes translucent.

Unprotected bodies may become powdery and disintegrate, but properly protected bodies may be preserved for years. Collagen, elastic tissues, cardiac and skeletal muscle, cartilage, and bone tissues can be seen on the histologic examination of the mummified material.

questions.text:
172. A patient presents with fatigue, arthralgia, and palpable purpura over the lower limbs. He has a history of intravenous drug abuse and tested positive for anti-HCV antibodies. Laboratory studies reveal proteinuria and low complement levels. Serum cryoglobulins are positive. Which of the following types are seen in such patients?

* Type I cryoglobulinemia

* Type II cryoglobulinemia

* Type III cryoglobulinemia
questions.solution:
In the given scenario of cryoglobulinemic vasculitis and a history of intravenous drug abuse with positive anti-HCV antibodies status, the patient is likely suffering from hepatitis C infection, which is significantly linked with type II and III cryoglobulinemia.

Cryoglobulinemia is classified into three types based on immunoglobulin composition, according to the Brouet criteria.

Type I involves monoclonal immunoglobulins (usually IgG or IgM) and is linked to B-cell malignancies such as multiple myeloma, Waldenström macroglobulinemia, chronic lymphocytic leukaemia, or monoclonal gammopathies like MGUS.

Types II and III are considered mixed cryoglobulinemia. Type II includes a mixture of monoclonal IgM with rheumatoid factor activity and polyclonal immunoglobulins, commonly associated with hepatitis C virus (HCV), hepatitis B virus, HIV, autoimmune diseases such as lupus and Sjögren syndrome, and lymphoproliferative disorders. Around 10% of cases have no known cause and are called essential mixed cryoglobulinemia.

Type III consists of polyclonal IgM and IgG and is typically related to autoimmune conditions or infections, especially HCV.

questions.text: 173. A pregnant lady with an obstetric score of G2P1L1 was diagnosed with gestational diabetes at 26 weeks of gestation. Which of the following is unlikely to be seen due to this condition?

choices.text: Gross congenital anomalies in the fetus
Baby that is large for gestational age

questions.solution:
A gross congenital anomaly in the fetus is seen in the case of overt diabetes, not in gestational diabetes.

The first trimester is the period of organogenesis. Hyperglycemia and ketosis during this period cause excess free radical production, leading to congenital anomalies in the fetus. The rest of the complications given in the above options occur in both gestational and overt diabetic mothers.

Overt diabetes is a term used for pre-existing diabetes mellitus in pregnancy or diabetes mellitus detected for the first time during the first trimester of pregnancy.

According to the American Diabetes Association, a diagnosis of overt diabetes is made if

* The fasting plasma glucose exceeds 126 mg/dl

* The 2 hours post glucose (75 gm) value exceeds 200 mg/dl 

* HbA1C ≥ 6.5%

Maternal complications during pregnancy:

*

* Abortion: Recurrent spontaneous abortion may be associated with uncontrolled diabetes. (Option B)

* Preterm labour may be due to infection or polyhydramnios.

* Infection: Urinary tract infection and vulvovaginitis.

* Increased incidence of preeclampsia.

* Polyhydramnios: Large baby, large placenta, fetal hyperglycemia leading to polyuria, and increased concentration of glucose in the liquor irritating the amniotic epithelium are probable causes. (Option C)

* Maternal distress may be due to the combined effects of an oversized fetus and polyhydramnios.

* Diabetic retinopathy

* Diabetic nephropathy

* Coronary artery disease

* Ketoacidosis

During labour, there is an increased incidence of:

* Prolongation of labour due to a big baby.

* Shoulder dystocia is due to disproportionate growth with an increased shoulder/head ratio.

* Perineal injuries.

* Postpartum haemorrhage.

* Operative interference

Neonatal and fetal complications

*

* Congenital Malformations

* Altered fetal growth in the form of macrosomia- Maternal hyperglycemia → hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the fetal islets of Langerhans → increased secretion of fetal insulin → stimulates carbohydrate utilisation and accumulation of fat. (Option D)

* It can also present as growth retardation due to compromised maternal blood flow due to diabetes.

* Respiratory distress syndrome is more commonly due to prematurity

* Neonatal hypoglycemia

* Hypocalcemia

* Hyperbilirubinemia and polycythemia

* Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy primarily affects the inter­ ventricular septum.

questions.text:
174. Which of the following statements correctly describes the regulation of aldosterone secretion?

ECF - Extracellular fluid ANP - Atrial natriuretic peptide

choices.text: Large amount of ACTH is required for aldosterone secretion
Increase in ECF sodium increases aldosterone secretion
Increase in ANP decreases aldosterone secretion
Increase in angiotensin-II decreases aldosterone secretion

questions.solution:
An increase in ANP decreases aldosterone secretion correctly describes the regulation of aldosterone secretion.

Atrial natriuretic peptide is released when the cardiac atria are stretched and plasma volume increases, directly inhibiting the reabsorption of sodium and water, and thereby inhibiting renin and subsequently angiotensin II and aldosterone. This results in the urinary excretion of sodium and water (natriuresis), which helps bring plasma volume back to normal. ANP levels are highly increased in congestive cardiac failure. 

The following factors play a role in the regulation of aldosterone:

* Increase in ANP decreases aldosterone secretion (Option C)

* Increase in ECF potassium significantly increases aldosterone secretion 

* Increase in ECF sodium decreases aldosterone secretion (Option B)

* Increase in angiotensin-II increases aldosterone secretion (Option D)

ACTH has a permissive role in aldosterone secretion, which means even a small amount of ACTH from the anterior pituitary would secrete the required amount of aldosterone in the body (Option A).

Note: Potassium ion concentration and angiotensin-II are the most potent in regulating aldosterone secretion.

questions.text: 175. A 6-year-old male child comes to the OPD with features of anaemia. Investigations show megaloblastic anemia, but the Schilling test is inconclusive. The paediatrician suspects a rare disease affecting the cubulin receptors in the ileum. Which of the following syndromes is the clinician suspecting?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Imerslund–Gräsbeck syndrome (IGS), a rare autosomal recessive disorder causing childhood-onset megaloblastic anemia.

Imerslund–Gräsbeck syndrome occurs due to mutations in the CUBN (cubilin) or AMN (amnionless) genes. These encode the ileal receptors responsible for uptake of the vitamin B12–intrinsic factor (IF) complex. When defective, vitamin B12 cannot be absorbed despite normal intrinsic factor secretion.

Schilling test is inconclusive. It does not improve with intrinsic factor administration, differentiating it from pernicious anemia.

Clinical features include megaloblastic anemia in school-age children and non-specific proteinuria, which is seen in the majority of cases, due to the cubilin role in proximal renal tubules.

The treatment of Imerslund–Gräsbeck syndrome requires lifelong parenteral vitamin B12 (hydroxocobalamin), as oral therapy is ineffective.

Other options:

Option B. Bassen–Kornzweig syndrome (abetalipoproteinemia) is caused by mutations in the MTP gene (microsomal triglyceride transfer protein ), leading to the absence of apolipoprotein B-containing lipoproteins. Features include fat malabsorption, steatorrhea, acanthocytosis, progressive ataxia, and retinitis pigmentosa. It does not cause B12-related megaloblastic anemia.

Option C. Wolfram syndrome (DIDMOAD) is a rare genetic disorder with Diabetes Insipidus, Diabetes Mellitus, Optic Atrophy, and Deafness. It is neurodegenerative and unrelated to cobalamin absorption.

Option D. Shwachman–Diamond syndrome is a condition due to mutation of the SBDS (Shwachman-Bodian-Diamond syndrome) gene, characterized by exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, bone marrow dysfunction (neutropenia, anemia), and skeletal abnormalities. The anemia is not megaloblastic from B12 malabsorption, but usually due to marrow failure.

Pearl PM1554: Schilling Test

The Schilling test is done to determine the cause of vitamin B12 deficiency. It involves the administration of radiolabeled vitamin B12 followed by the 24-hour collection of urine. The test is then repeated with an additional component that can promote vitamin B12 absorption. If the additional component is able to correct the defect and radiolabeled vitamin B12 is absorbed, it will be detected in the urine.

questions.text: 176. A patient presented with thyroid swelling that moved on deglutition and not on protrusion of the tongue. USG of the thyroid gland followed by FNAC was done. The FNAC reports suggested Thy3. What does it imply?
questions.solution:
Thy3 in FNAC reports implies Follicular lesion.

FNAC is the investigation of choice in discrete thyroid swellings. FNAC has good patient compliance, is a simple and quick procedure to perform in the OPD and is readily repeated. FNAC results should be reported using standard terminology (Thy1 to Thy5). Ultrasound-guided FNAC allows more accurate sampling and reduces the rate of unsatisfactory aspirates.

Based on the FNAC reports, the management of the thyroid swellings can be determined.

Category Lesion
Thy1 Non-diagnostic
Thy1c Non-diagnostic cystic
Thy2 Non-neoplastic
Thy3 Follicular
Thy4 Suspicious for malignancy
Thy5 Malignant


Another cytology reporting system is "The Bethesda System for Reporting Thyroid Cytopathology" (TBSRTC):



Pearl PM1748: AJCC 8th edition Changes in the TNM staging of Thyroid neoplasms:

Differentiated Thyroid Cancer:

* The age cutoff used for staging is increased from 45 to 55 years of age at diagnosis. 

* Minor extrathyroidal extension detected only on histological examination is removed from the definition of T3 disease and therefore has no impact on either T category or overall stage.

* N1 disease no longer upstages a patient to stage III. If < 55 years of age at diagnosis, N1 disease is stage I. If ≥ 55 years of age, N1 disease is stage II.

* T3a is a new category for tumors > 4 cm confined to the thyroid gland

* T3b is a new category for tumors of any size demonstrating gross extrathyroidal extension into strap muscles (sternohyoid, sternothyroid, thyrohyoid or omohyoid muscles)

* Level VII lymph nodes, previously classified as lateral neck lymph nodes (N1b) is re-classified as central neck lymph nodes (N1a) to be more anatomically consistent and because level VII presented significant coding difficulties for tumor registrars, clinicians and researchers.

* In differentiated thyroid cancer, the presence of distant metastases (M1) in older patients is classified as IVB disease rather than IVC disease. Distant metastasis in anaplastic thyroid cancer continues to be classified as IVC disease.

questions.text: 177. Which of the following findings will be seen in eosinophilic oesophagitis on upper GI endoscopy?
questions.solution:
Feline oesophagus is a finding typically seen on endoscopic examination of the oesophagus in cases of eosinophilic oesophagitis. 

Eosinophilic esophagitis is an acute, eosinophil-dominated inflammation of the oesophagus often linked to atopic diseases. Many patients also experience concurrent atopic conditions like asthma, allergic rhinitis, or atopic dermatitis, and some may even have mild peripheral eosinophilia. It is increasingly common, especially among white males in urban areas. Symptoms include GERD-like complaints, food impaction, dysphagia, vomiting, and feeding intolerance in infants.

Endoscopic examination may reveal a "feline oesophagus," characterised by stacked circular rings resembling a cat's tail, along with strictures and linear furrows. The definitive diagnostic feature is the presence of numerous intraepithelial eosinophils, which distinguishes eosinophilic esophagitis from other conditions like Crohn's disease or GERD. 

Treatment includes dietary allergen elimination and, if needed, corticosteroids are sometimes combined with PPIs. An image showing the endoscopic appearance of the feline oesophagus is given below:



Other options: 

Option A: Serpiginous ulcers are seen in CMV oesophagitis, which commonly occurs in transplant recipients on immunosuppressants.

Option C: Volcano ulcers are small, punched-out lesions seen in HSV esophagitis.

Option D: Luminal narrowing with distal sparing of the oesophagus is seen in pill oesophagitis. Pill esophagitis causes a solitary deep ulcer at luminal narrowings (e.g. near the carina), sparing the distal oesophagus. Healing may result in a stricture.

Pearl PM1852: Endoscopic Findings in Esophagitis

 

Conditions Endoscopic findings
Infectious esophagitis Diffuse and involve the proximal esophagus  
HSV esophagitis Vesicles and small punched-out lesions (volcano ulcers)
CMV esophagitis Serpiginous ulcers
Peptic esophagitis Solitary and distal  
Eosinophilic esophagitis Multiple esophageal rings, linear furrows, or white punctate exudates (feline esophagus)
Pill esophagitis Singular and deep at points of luminal narrowing with sparing of the distal esophagus
Candida esophagitis White friable plaques, in advance form - adherent, grey-white pseudomembranes.


 

The image below shows the lesions of CMV esophagitis.



The image below shows the lesions of candida esophagitis.



The image below shows feline esophagus in eosinophilic esophagitis.



The image below shows the erosive lesion of pill esophagitis.



The image below shows the lesions of HSV esophagitis.



Pearl PM2445: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance



Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.



Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.



Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.



Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.



Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.



Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.





Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: 178. A young sexually active female presents with complaints of dysuria and frothy greenish vaginal discharge. On staining, the causative agent shows morphology as shown in the image. Which of the following is true regarding the pathogen?

choices.text: It grows on CPLM culture medium

questions.solution:
The clinical background of dysuria, frothy greenish vaginal discharge with the presence of flagellated trophozoites, confirm Trichomonas vaginitis, which shows growth on CPLM culture medium.

Trichomonas vaginalis has a jerky or twitching type of motility on the wet saline mount (option B). It has 4 anterior flagella and a 5th flagellum running along the undulating membrane (option D). T. vaginalis is the only protozoan with one stage in its life cycle, i.e., trophozoite form (no cyst stage) (option C).

It is an obligate parasite. Sexual transmission is the main route of infection. Other modes are fomites, and babies during passage through the infected birth canal. The common presentation of trichomoniasis is foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge, itching, dysuria, and dyspareunia. Petechial haemorrhage and mucosal capillary dilation give the appearance of a strawberry cervix. 

The image given below shows a strawberry cervix:



The gold standard for diagnosis is culture on cysteine-peptone-liver-maltose (CPLM) medium or plastic envelope medium (PEM). The treatment of choice is metronidazole 2 g orally as a single dose.

questions.text: 179. Well-defined line of demarcation is seen in?
questions.solution:
A well-defined line of demarcation is a hallmark of dry gangrene.

Gangrene refers to the tissue death, which results in the black discoloration of the affected part because of the breakdown of hemoglobin and the formation of iron sulfide. It usually affects the most distal part of a limb because of arterial obstruction (from thrombosis, embolus, or arteritis). 

Dry gangrene occurs when the tissues are desiccated by the gradual slowing of the blood supply to the part. It is typically the result of atheromatous occlusion of arteries. It is dry, shriveled, and mummified in appearance. A zone of demarcation is seen between viable tissue and dead tissue. If the blood supply of the proximal viable tissue is adequate, a granulation tissue layer forms between dead and living tissue. 

Wet gangrene (Option B) occurs when superadded infection and putrefaction are present. It is due to the cessation of both arterial and venous blood supply, leading to gangrene with a poor line of demarcation. It is edematous and putrefied in appearance with a rapid rate of spread proximally.

Crepitus may be felt on palpation as a result of infection by gas-forming organisms, commonly in diabetic foot problems, and should be considered a surgical emergency, with urgent need for tissue debridement or amputation.

Dry gangrene Wet gangrene 
Clear line of demarcation  Poor line of demarcation 
Dry, shriveled, mummified appearance  edematous, putrefied, discoloured appearance 
Slow, gradual loss of blood supply sudden loss of blood supply
Separation by aseptic ulceration  Separation by septic ulceration 
Treatment—limited amputation  Treatment—aggressive amputation 
Causes: thromboangiitis obliterans, atherosclerosis, etc. Causes: emboli, trauma, etc.


 

Below are the images showing wet gangrene and dry gangrene respectively:





Other options:

Option C: Gas gangrene is caused by infection with Clostridium perfringens and related anaerobes in devitalized wounds. Gas formation produces crepitus, with severe toxemia and shock. The disease spreads explosively, so a line of demarcation never develops. Management requires urgent debridement and high-dose antibiotics.

Option D: Mixed gangrene has features of both dry and wet gangrene coexisting—initial ischemia due to arterial occlusion is later complicated by bacterial infection. As a result, the boundaries are irregular and poorly defined, and the line of demarcation is not distinct.

questions.text:
180. Clindamycin is used to treat which of the following infections?

* Skin infections caused by Streptococci

* Actinomycosis

* Otitis media

* Toxoplasma gondii encephalitis

* Urinary tract infections caused by Pseudomonas spp.
questions.solution:
Clindamycin is used to treat skin infections caused by Streptococci, actinomycosis, otitis media and Toxoplasma gondii encephalitis (in combination with pyrimethamine) (Statements 1, 2, 3, 4). It is not used to treat urinary tract infections caused by Pseudomonas spp.

Clindamycin binds to the 50S ribosomal subunit and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis.

Therapeutic uses of clindamycin include:

* Skin & soft tissue infections (especially in β-lactam allergy)

* Necrotising fasciitis & gas gangrene (because it inhibits toxin production)

* Actinomycosis

* Acne (topical)

* Lung & pleural infections (anaerobic, lung abscess)

* Sinusitis, pharyngitis, otitis media (as an alternative agent)

* Osteomyelitis (good bone penetration)

* Toxoplasma encephalitis (with pyrimethamine + leucovorin)

* Non-severe malaria (with quinine)

* Bacterial vaginosis (vaginal application)

All aerobic gram-negative bacilli, including Pseudomonas, are resistant to clindamycin. (Statement 5)

Adverse Effects:

* Diarrhea

* High risk of C. difficile colitis

* Skin rash - more common in HIV

* Rare: Stevens-Johnson syndrome, elevated liver enzymes, granulocytopenia, thrombocytopenia

* IV use: Local thrombophlebitis

Pearl PM1271: Protein synthesis inhibitors: Primary subunit of ribosome binding

Mnemonic: 50 CELLS arranged into 30 TEAM

50s subunit binding:

* C: Chloramphenicol, Clindamycin

* E: Erythromycin (macrolides)

* L: Lincosamides

* L: Linezolid

* S: Streptogramins

30s subunit binding

* Te: Tetracyclines

* Am: Aminoglycosides

Bacteroides fragilis Aminoglycosides,Ampicillin

Staphylococcus saprophyticus  Novobiocin
Enterococcus fecalis/fecium Cephalosporins,Aminoglycosides,Clindamycin,Polymyxin B
Clostridium species  Aminoglycosides
