questions.text: 181. A patient with the hearing aid shown in the image below was brought to you in the ENT OPD for follow-up. All of the following options represent the indications for this type of hearing aid, except _____.

choices.text: A 7-year-old patient with single-sided hearing loss
A 13-year-old patient with bilateral ear discharge unresponsive to treatment
A 10-year-old patient with bilateral canal atresia
A 20-year-old patient with bilateral acoustic neuroma

questions.solution:
The above image shows a bone-anchored hearing aid (BAHA), and all the given options are indications for BAHA, except for patients with bilateral acoustic neuroma, as they have bilateral sensorineural hearing loss for which it has no role.

A bone-anchored hearing aid (BAHA) is based on the principle of bone conduction. They are used in the following conditions:

* Single-sided deafness (Option A)

* When an air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used:

* People who have chronic inflammation or infection of the ear canal associated with discharge, and cannot wear standard “in the ear” air-conduction hearing aids(Option B)

* Children with malformed or absent outer ear and ear canals, as in microtia or canal atresia (Option C)

* Conductive or mixed hearing loss, e.g., otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis, where surgery is contraindicated.

BAHA combines a sound processor with a small titanium fixture implanted behind the ear. It allows the bone to transfer sound to a functioning cochlea rather than via the middle ear—a process known as direct bone conduction.

It consists of three parts:

* An innermost titanium fixture in the bone

* A middle abutment 

* Sound processor 

Note- A cochlear implant is used in cases of severe B/L sensorineural hearing loss.

Pearl PM1818: BAHA (Bone Anchored Hearing Aid)

It replaces the external auditory canal and middle ear and directly stimulates cochlea.

Indications:

* When air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used:

* Canal atresia, congenital or acquired, not amenable to treatment

* Chronic ear discharge, not amenable to treatment

* Excessive feedback and discomfort from air-conduction hearing aid

* Conductive or mixed hearing loss, e.g. otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis where surgery is contraindicated

* Single-sided hearing loss

Eligibility:

* Cochlea and nerve should be functional

* BC threshold should be better than or equal to 45 dB on PTA

Components:



Mechanism of action:



Pearl PM1817: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:



Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC). The electrodes of the cochlear implant are placed in the scala tympani and are passed through the round window from the middle ear.

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

* Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)

* Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: 182. A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of facial puffiness and frothy urine. Given below is the histological image of the condition. What do you think is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the image is suggestive of membranous nephropathy. The given hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stained image shows uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall (intense pink color).

Membranous nephropathy is one of the most common causes of nephrotic syndrome. It is a form of chronic immune-complex-mediated disease.

* Light microscopy: diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall without cellular proliferation. Irregular spikes projecting from the basement membrane are best seen with silver stains.

* Immunofluorescence microscopy: granular deposits containing Ig and complement along the glomerular basement membrane

* Electron micrograph: electron-dense subepithelial deposits and effacement of foot processes of podocytes.

Image: The silver stain of the glomerulus highlights the proteinaceous basement membranes in black. There are characteristic "spikes" of the basement membrane between the immune deposits of membranous nephropathy. The black basement membrane material shown here appears as projections in the capillary loops.

Note:

questions.text: 183. You are examining a 6-month-old infant with delayed development and persistent hypocalcemia. He has a cleft lip and a cleft palate. An echo at birth had shown an atrial septal defect. Which test should be done additionally in this patient with regards to his clinical presentation?

choices.text: Flow cytometry to assess T cell levels

questions.solution:
This patient with hypocalcemia, cleft palate, atrial septal defect, and delayed development most likely has DiGeorge Syndrome. A flow cytometry should be done in this patient to assess his T cell function to guide future therapy. 

DiGeorge syndrome is a clinical syndrome that occurs due to a deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22. It results from the failure of the development of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches. They give rise to the thymus, the parathyroids, some of the C cells of the thyroid, and the ultimobranchial body.

The absence of cell-mediated immunity causes poor defense against certain fungal and viral infections. The T-cell zones of lymphoid organs, i.e., paracortical areas of the lymph nodes and the periarteriolar sheaths of the spleen, are depleted. Ig levels may be normal or reduced, depending on the severity of the T-cell deficiency. T cell function is evaluated to guide further management, like vaccination recommendations and the requirement for any antibiotic prophylaxis. 

Other options:

Option A: X Ray of the chest can be used to look for the absence of the thymus, but it is a very nonspecific sign and is present in only 15% of cases.

Option B: Serum phenylalanine levels can be measured to rule out Phenylketonuria(PKU). Phenylketonuria (PKU) results from a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. It manifests as a progressive intellectual disability. Patients with PKU have a musty or mousy odor due to phenylacetic acid accumulation and a positive dinitrophenylhydrazine test. The given symptoms are consistent with DiGeorge syndrome. 

Option C: MRI of the brain can be done to evaluate organic causes of delayed development. However, this patient has the classic features of DiGeorge syndrome and should be evaluated for T cell function.

Pearl PM0535: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

* C – Cardiac defects

* A – Abnormal facies

* T – Thymic aplasia

* C – Cleft palate

* H – Hypocalcemia

The image below shows the abnormal facies in DiGeorge syndrome.

questions.text: 184. The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare set up a programme represented by the logo below to create awareness of a disease prevalent in India. Based on sentinel surveillance data, Goa is classified as a moderate-prevalence state of this disease. What will be the % of infection in high-risk groups and antenatal women in this state?

choices.text: >5% in high-risk group and >1% in antenatal women.
<5% in high-risk group and >1% in antenatal women.
<5% in high-risk group and <1% in antenatal women.
>5% in high-risk group and <1% in antenatal women.

questions.solution:
The red ribbon shown is a part of the logo of the National AIDS Control Organization (NACO) programme set up by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. Moderate prevalence states like Goa have an infection of >5% in the high-risk group and <1% in antenatal women.

Based on sentinel surveillance data, the HIV prevalence in the adult population can be broadly classified into three groups- 

* Group I High Prevalence States: includes states of Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, Andhra Pradesh, Manipur, and Nagaland, where the HIV infection is >5% in the high-risk group and >1% in antenatal women.

* Group II Moderate Prevalence States: includes states of Gujarat, Goa, and Puducherry, where HIV infection is > 5% or more among high-risk groups but the infection is <1% in antenatal women.

* Group III Low Prevalence States: includes remaining states where the HIV infection in any of the high-risk groups is <5% and is < 1% among antenatal women. 

The logo of NACO:

questions.text:
185. A 43-year-old male presents with a 2-week history of fever, fatigue, and malaise. On physical examination, he is found to have mild splenomegaly. Laboratory investigations are given below. Which of the following clinches the diagnosis of leukemoid reaction over chronic myeloid leukemia?

WBC count: 59,000/μL Differential count: Metamyelocytes: 15% Myelocytes: 10% Bands: 20% Segmented neutrophils: 45% Lymphocytes: 10% LAP score: High
questions.solution:
A high LAP score is what clinches the diagnosis of leukemoid reaction.

A leukemoid reaction represents an exaggerated but benign response of the bone marrow to stress, infection, or inflammation. The peripheral smear shows increased neutrophils with a left shift, including myelocytes and metamyelocytes, along with toxic granules and Döhle bodies. Since the neutrophils are normal and reactive, their metabolic activity is high, leading to a high leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score.

In contrast, chronic myeloid leukemia is a clonal myeloproliferative neoplasm caused by the BCR-ABL fusion gene (Philadelphia chromosome). It also presents with leukocytosis and a left-shifted differential count, but here, the neutrophils are clonal and metabolically abnormal. As a result, they show a low LAP score.

Other options:

Option B: Splenomegaly can be seen in both conditions, but with different patterns. In CML, splenomegaly is often massive and common due to infiltration by leukemic cells, whereas in leukemoid reaction, it is usually absent or only mild unless there are comorbidities like liver disease.

Option C and D: Segmented neutrophil predominance, and raised WBC count occur in both conditions. A leukemoid reaction typically shows marked neutrophilia with a left shift (metamyelocytes, myelocytes), while CML may present with the entire myeloid spectrum, including basophils and eosinophils. However, percentages of neutrophils overlap, and high WBC counts (>50,000/µL) can be seen in both, making these findings non-specific.

Pearl PM1467: Leucocyte Alkaline Phosphatase Score

Alkaline phosphatase activity is found predominantly in mature segmented neutrophils. LAP score is obtained by assessing the staining intensity in 100 consecutive neutrophils, with each neutrophil scored on a scale of 1–4. 

Conditions that result in an increase in leukocytes in all stages of maturity will reflect a corresponding increase in LAP.

Elevated LAP score

Decreased LAP score

Leukemoid reaction

Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)

Pregnancy

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria

Polycythemia vera

Sickle cell anemia

Multiple myeloma

Hypophosphatasia

Obstructive jaundice

Aplastic anemia

Hodgkin lymphoma

questions.text: 186. A 20-year-old woman comes to the physician due to irregular menstrual cycles. She is 160 cm tall and weighs 78 kg. You notice she has dark coarse hair on her chin and thinning of hair on her scalp. She also has severe acne on her face and spread over her back. Which of the following do you expect to be reduced in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests that the patient is likely suffering from polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD). In a patient with PCOD, there is a reduced FSH/LH ratio in the serum.

Polycystic ovarian disease is an endocrinopathy in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems. Rotterdam criteria is used to diagnose polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS.

Rotterdam criteria (ASRM/ESHRE- European society of human reproduction and embryology, 2003):

* Clinical/biochemical hyperandrogenism

* Oligo/anovulation

* Polycystic ovaries on USG

This patient's irregular menstrual cycles (signifying irregular ovulation/ anovulation), obesity (BMI 30.4), coarse dark hair on the chin (hirsutism signifying clinical hyperandrogenism), androgenic baldness (thinning of scalp hair), and severe acne are suggestive of PCOD.

Obesity leads to insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia. Hyperinsulinemia induces luteinizing hormone (LH) to cause thecal hyperplasia, which in turn increases the production of androgens (testosterone). Androgens are further aromatized in the periphery to form estrogens. Due to increased adipose cells in obesity, there is increased peripheral production of estrogens. This in turn causes a surge in LH in the hypothalamo-pituatry-ovarian axis (HPO axis). (Option A and B)

Increased circulating androgens have negative feedback on the HPA to decrease the production of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). As FSH levels decrease and LH levels increase, there is a low FSH/LH ratio in PCOD patients. (Option D)

Hyperinsulinemia and increased androgens also suppress sex-hormone binding globulin levels. This leads to increased levels of free testosterone, which is responsible for hirsutism and acne.

On USG, polycystic ovaries show multiple follicles arranged in a necklace of pearls appearance. (image below)



Pearl PM1151: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

* Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.

* LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.

* Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.

* Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)

* Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor

* DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated

* DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour

* Serum SHBG is reduced.

* Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.

* Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance

* Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases

* Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases

* Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)

* 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

* Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Pearl PM1152: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene


Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text: 187. A 35-year-old male presented in the ICU with chief complaints of yellowish discoloration of eyes, face, palms, and soles with anorexia, vomiting, and gross ascites. You, as a resident doctor, decided to send a full workup of liver function tests. Which of the following will test the synthetic function of the Liver?
questions.solution:
The serum albumin test measures the synthetic function of the liver. 

Serum albumin, serum globulins (α and β), and coagulation factors (all except VIII) are synthesized by hepatocytes and measure the biosynthetic function of the liver. Levels of serum albumin are decreased in chronic liver conditions like cirrhosis, which indicates hepatocyte damage and decreased albumin synthesis.

Hypoalbuminemia <3g/dl is seen in chronic liver conditions, but is less significant in acute hepatitis because of albumin's long half-life. Other than liver diseases, low levels of albumin are also significant in nephrotic syndrome and protein-losing enteropathy. 

Liver Function Tests include: 

Function Assessed Test/Marker
Hepatocytes integrity
  • Serum aspartate aminotransferase (Option A)
  • Serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
  • Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)
Biliary excretory function
  • Serum bilirubin
  • Total- unconjugated plus conjugated
  • Direct-conjugated
  • Urine bilirubin
  • Serum alkaline phosphatase (Option B)
  • Serum γ-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT)
  • Serum bile acids (Option C)
Hepatocyte synthetic function
  • Serum albumin
  • Coagulation factors (factors II, V, VII, IX, X, XI, XII)
  • Prothrombin time (PT) and partial thromboplastin time (PTT)
  • Fibrinogen
Hepatocyte metabolism
  • Serum ammonia
  • Aminopyrine breath test

questions.text: 188. Which of the following types of CNS tumours show ‘fried-egg’ and ‘chicken-wire’ appearance on histopathology?
questions.solution:
Oligodendroglioma shows ‘fried-egg’ and ‘chicken-wire’ appearances on histopathology. 

Oligodendrogliomas are infiltrating gliomas composed of cells that resemble oligodendrocytes. The lesions are primarily located in the cerebral hemispheres, with a particular predilection for the white matter. Mitotic activity is low and is characterised in low-grade WHO-grade II tumours. 

Histopathology shows regular cells with spherical nuclei, finely granular chromatin, and a vacuolated cytoplasmic halo creating a "fried egg" appearance. A "chicken-wire" anastomosing capillary network is present. Tumour cells often gather around neurons, called perineuronal satellitosis.

A histopathological image of oligodendroglioma is shown below:



Other Options:

Option B: Diffuse astrocytomas are grade II  poorly defined, infiltrative grey glial tumours with variable size and consistency. Microscopically, they show increased cellularity, nuclear atypia, and infiltration into surrounding tissue.

Option C: Anaplastic astrocytomas are grade III glial tumours that show greater cellularity and mitotic activity.

Option D: Glioblastoma multiforme is a WHO grade 4 astrocytoma. It is a necrotic, infiltrating tumour, and a characteristic histopathological finding is a geographic necrosis in a serpentine pattern and tumour cells along their edges producing pseudo-palisading.

The histopathological image of glioblastoma multiforme is given below:



Pearl PM2482: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

* Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas

* Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 

* Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions

* Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 



 

Medulloblastoma:

* Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells

* Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped

* Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil



 

Ependymoma:

* Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 

* Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel



 

Oligodendroglioma:

* Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 

* Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries



 

Retinoblastoma: 

* Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei

* Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen

* Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center

* Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: 189. In a healthy individual, albumin is usually absent in the urine. This absence of albumin in urine can be best explained by which of the following primary reasons?

choices.text: Narrow slit pores between podocyte foot processes

questions.solution:
In a healthy individual, albumin is usually absent in the urine mainly due to its negative charge. 

The glomerular capillary wall carries a negative charge due to its protein composition, which repels negatively charged molecules such as albumin. As a result of this electrostatic repulsion, albumin, despite having a relatively small effective molecular diameter, is present in the glomerular filtrate in trace amounts. Any trace amount of albumin, if filtered, is reabsorbed completely, leading to its absence in the urine. 

In nephritis, the negative electrical charges in the glomerular wall are lost or reduced, which can cause albumin to leak into the urine without an increase in the size of the pores in the membrane. 

Other options:

Option A: Neutral substances smaller than 4 nm are freely filtered through the glomerular filtration barrier, while filtration approaches zero for substances larger than 8 nm. For molecules between 4 and 8 nm in diameter, filtration is inversely proportional to their diameter. Albumin, although a large molecule (~66 kDa), has a relatively smaller effective diameter (~7 nm, i.e., < 8 nm). Therefore, the absence of albumin in urine cannot be explained solely by its effective diameter.

Option C: Trace amounts of albumin are reabsorbed completely; however, this is not the primary reason for the absence of albumin from urine.

Option D: The slit pores allow neutral substances of size less than 4 nm to freely pass through the glomerular filtration barrier, and hence, narrow slit pores are not responsible for the absence of albumin from the urine.

questions.text: 190. A surgeon performing a modified radical neck dissection preserves a structure. Which of the following structures is preserved?
questions.solution:
The spinal accessory nerve is preserved in modified radical neck dissection (MRND). 

Modified radical neck dissection (MRND) involves preservation of at least one or more of the non-lymphatic neck structures - the spinal accessory nerve, the sternocleidomastoid muscle or the internal jugular vein - with clearance of all nodal levels (I-V). 

Modified radical neck dissections (MRND) are classified as types I, II, or III based on which structures are preserved.

           Types of MRND                      Structures preserved
Type I 
  • Spinal accessory nerve (CN XI)
Type II
  • Spinal accessory nerve (CN XI)
  • Internal jugular vein (IJV)
Type III
  • Spinal accessory nerve (CN XI)
  • Internal jugular vein (IJV)
  • Sternocleidomastoid muscle (SCM)


 

Radical neck dissection involves the removal of the following structures:

* All lymph nodes from levels I to V (Option B and C)

* Spinal accessory nerve

* Internal jugular vein

* Sternocleidomastoid muscle 

* Submandibular gland (Option D)

questions.text: 191. Given below are anti-obesity medications and their mechanism of action. Which of the following pair is incorrectly matched?
questions.solution:
Liraglutide is not a GLP-2 agonist. Liraglutide is a GLP-1 agonist used in the treatment of obesity.

Antiobesity medications can be considered in patients with a BMI of ≥30, or a BMI of ≥27 with comorbidities related to weight. The patients should be counseled that the medications should be viewed as an additional measure rather than a replacement for a healthy diet and exercise. 

The drugs that are currently approved for the management of obesity include:

* Phentermine: adrenergic agonist

* Orlistat: inhibitor of gastric and pancreatic lipase; reduces dietary fat absorption

* Phentermine plus topiramate: adrenergic agonism and appetite suppression

* Naltrexone plus bupropion: reduction of appetite and food cravings

* Liraglutide, semaglutide: GLP-1 agonists

Note: Teduglutide is a GLP-2 agonist that is used for short bowel syndrome.

questions.text: 192. As part of a national public health directive, all refugees seeking asylum undergo mandatory screening for latent tuberculosis infection. Individuals who test positive are asymptomatic and healthy, but are offered prophylactic treatment. This strategy of screening is best classified as:
questions.solution:
The most appropriate type of screening in this context, given the worry that refugees might transmit infections to the general population, is prospective screening. 

Prospective screening is a type of screening that is performed for the benefit of others or public health purposes rather than solely for the benefit of the individual being screened. It is used for disease control and transmission prevention.

Examples include screening of immigrants for infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and syphilis to protect the home population. The screening program may, by leading to early diagnosis, permit better treatment and lower the spread and/or mortality from the disease. 

Other options:

Option A: Mass screening involves screening a large population or community, usually for conditions that are common and have a significant impact. An example of mass screening would be newborn screening for metabolic disorders or public health screenings for diseases like hypertension.

Option B: Opportunistic screening implies that individuals are entered into the screening program whenever the opportunity arises, usually when the patients present to the medical professionals about a concern unrelated to screening. E.g., when a patient presents for a gynaecological complaint, screening for STIs or cervical cancer can be conducted. 

Option D: Multiphase screening is a type of screening that involves multiple tests or stages, typically used to rule out or confirm a diagnosis. It may involve an initial test followed by a more specific or confirmatory test if the first one indicates a potential issue.

questions.text: 193. Identify the type of astigmatism in a patient with refractive error of +1DS with +2DC at 180 degrees.
questions.solution:
The patient has compound hypermetropic astigmatism, as both meridians are hyperopic but with different powers.

Step 1: +1.00 D spherical indicates a power of +1.00 D on both vertical and horizontal axes.

Step 2: +2.00 D cylindrical at 180 degrees means the cylindrical power acts perpendicular to the axis, i.e., at 90°. So, an additional +2.00 D is added to the vertical meridian.

Resulting powers:

* At 180° (horizontal): +1.00 D

* At 90° (vertical): +1.00 D + 2.00 D = +3.00 D

Since both meridians are hypermetropic (positive), but of unequal power, this is classified as compound hypermetropic astigmatism.

Astigmatism is a refractive error in which the rays of light entering the eye are refracted differently in different meridia of the eye. Meridians of the eye correspond to the lines of longitude on a globe.

There are two types of astigmatism. In regular astigmatism, refractive power changes uniformly from one meridian to another. In irregular astigmatism, there is an irregular change of the refractive power in different meridians. Corneal scars can cause it.

Aetiology of regular astigmatism:

1) Corneal: due to abnormalities of curvature (most common) 2) Lenticular

* Curvatural: seen in lenticonus

* Positional: due to the tilting or oblique placement of the lens, subluxation

3) Retinal: due to the oblique placement of the macula.

Regular Astigmatism can be classified based on refraction or axis.

A) Refractive types of regular astigmatism:

* Simple astigmatism: rays are focused on the retina in one meridian: either in front (simple myopic) of the retina or behind the retina (simple hypermetropic).

* Compound astigmatism: rays in both meridians are focused either in front of or behind the retina.

* Mixed astigmatism: Light rays in one meridian are focused in front of the retina, and those in the other meridian are focused behind the retina. This allows the formation of a circle of least diffusion on the retina, which leads to less severe symptoms.



B) Regular astigmatism based on axis:

* With-the-rule astigmatism: The vertical meridian is more curved than the horizontal meridian, but they are placed at right angles to one another.

* Against-the-rule astigmatism: Here, horizontal meridians are more curved than the vertical meridians.

* Oblique astigmatism: Here, the two principal meridians are not the horizontal and vertical meridians, although they are at right angles to each other. It is a type of regular astigmatism. eg, one may be at 45 degrees and the other at 135 degrees.

* Bioblique astigmatism: Here, the two principal meridians are not at right angles to each other; for example, one may be at 40 degrees and the other at 100 degrees.



Other options:

Option A: Compound myopic astigmatism - Both meridians are myopic, but to different degrees. Example: -1.00 DS with -2.00 DC. Both powers would be negative, unlike in the given question.

Option B: Simple hypermetropic astigmatism - One meridian is emmetropic (focuses on the retina), and the other is hypermetropic (focuses behind the retina). Example: +0.00 DS with +2.00 DC — ruled out because in the question, both meridians are hyperopic.

Option D: Simple myopic astigmatism - One meridian is emmetropic and the other is myopic. Example: 0 DS with -1.00 DC — ruled out because in the given case, there’s no myopia.

questions.text: 194. A 34-year-old male patient presented with a black-colored nodule on his face as shown. There was no prior nevus in the area. The nodule has progressively increased in size over the last 1 week. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a nodular variant of melanoma. It is more aggressive than other variants.

Nodular melanoma accounts for 15% of all melanoma cases. The lesions arise de novo in the skin and are more frequently seen in males. They appear as black or blue papular lesions. They lack a horizontal growth phase but have a prominent vertical growth phase. This is why they tend to be sharply demarcated and more aggressive. Lesions can also be amelanotic.

Other important variants of melanoma include:

Superficial spreading melanoma is the most common variant of melanoma. It usually arises from a pre-existing nevus after a long period of slow change in the morphology of the lesion. There is rapid growth in few months prior to the presentation. These lesions tend to develop a vertical growth phase later, which manifests clinically as nodularity in the lesion. Superficial spreading melanoma is shown in the image below:



Lentigo maligna melanoma (Hutchinson’s melanotic freckle) is a variant of malignant melanoma that occurs due to cumulative exposure to UV radiation, while the other variants occur due to short-lasting but intense exposure, such as holiday tans. It presents as a variegated brown macule (as shown below) on the face, neck, and hands. The patients are usually elderly females. The lesion progresses slowly and has less metastatic potential than other variants.



Acral lentiginous melanoma is more commonly seen in dark-skinned patients. It affects the skin of palms and soles. It presents as an irregular macule as shown below.



Hutchinson's nail sign is an important clue towards the diagnosis of subungual melanoma. It is characterized by pigmentation of the proximal nail fold, that widens progressively to produce a pigmented macule and nail dystrophy.



Pearl PM0391: Clinical Findings suggestive of Melanoma

The ABCDE of melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:



A : Asymmetry

* Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape

B : Border irregular

* Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill-defined

C : Color variation

* The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color

D : Diameter >6 mm

* Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser)

E : Evolution

* There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole

Pearl PM1114: Breslow’s Classification of Malignant Melanoma

Breslow's classification of malignant melanoma:

Stage Depth
Stage I ≤ 0.75mm
Stage II 0.76 mm - 1.50mm
Stage III 1.51 mm - 4 mm
Stage IV >4 mm


 

TNM staging based on the thickness of invasion according to AJCC:

* T1 - ≤1.0 mm

* T2 - 1.01-2.0 mm

* T3 - 2.01-4.0 mm

* T4 - >4.0 mm



Pearl PM0390: Main Prognostic Factors for Primary Melanoma

The following are the prognostic factors for primary melanoma (predictive value from *** high to * low):

* Thickness (Breslow index)***

* Sentinel node status***

* Ulceration**

* Mitotic rate** (negative value especially in thin tumours)

* Regression* (underestimation of Breslow)

* Age* (negative for older age)

* Sex* (negative for males)

* Location* (negative for head and neck)

questions.text: 195. A patient diagnosed with unilateral renal artery stenosis is started on telmisartan for the management of hypertension. Which of the following is not an indication for a revascularization procedure?

choices.text: Failure to achieve adequate blood pressure control

questions.solution:
In a patient with unilateral renal artery stenosis who is on optimal medical therapy, a prior history of any atheroembolic disease is not an indication for a revascularization procedure.

Renal artery stenosis is the narrowing of one or both renal arteries, most commonly due to atherosclerosis or fibromuscular dysplasia. It leads to reduced kidney perfusion, triggering the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), which can cause secondary hypertension and potentially lead to ischemic nephropathy if left untreated.

Indications of medical therapy with revascularization:

* Progressive decline in GFR during treatment of systemic hypertension (Option A).

* Unable to achieve adequate blood pressure control with medical treatment (medical failure) (Option B).

* Rapid or recurrent decline in the GFR with a reduction in systemic pressure.

* Decline in the GFR during therapy with ACE inhibitors or ARBs.

* Recurrent congestive heart failure (leading to recurrent pulmonary edema) where left ventricular dysfunction does not explain the cause (Option D).

 Revascularization is not indicated (medical therapy with surveillance only) :

* Stable blood pressure and renal function.

* No progression of renal artery stenosis on surveillance studies. 

* Advanced age and/or limited life expectancy.

* Comorbidities that make revascularization risky.

* High risk or history of an atheroembolic event (Option C).

* Concomitant renal parenchymal diseases are responsible for progressive renal dysfunction.

questions.text: 196. Which of the following statements regarding Nateglinide is true?

choices.text: Nateglinide's insulinotropic effect lasts longer than repaglinide's
Nateglinide is primarily excreted unchanged by the kidneys
Nateglinide causes more hypoglycemia than repaglinide

questions.solution:
Nateglinide effectively reduces post-prandial glucose.

Nateglinide is an oral insulin secretagogue that stimulates insulin secretion by blocking K-ATP channels in pancreatic beta cells. It promotes rapid, less sustained insulin secretion (Option A), primarily reducing postprandial glycemic elevations in type 2 diabetes patients (Option C). It's most effective at 120 mg, three times daily, 1-10 minutes before meals.

Some drugs, such as NSAIDS, salicylates, MOA inhibitors, and non-selective beta blockers, can increase hypoglycemia risk if given along with netaglinide. 

Netaglinide is metabolized primarily by hepatic CYPs (2C9, 3A4); thus requires caution in hepatic insufficiency (Option B). About 15% of oral netaglinide is excreted unchanged in the renal system. Nateglinide causes less hypoglycemia than other oral insulin secretagogues, including repaglinide (Option D).

questions.text: 197. The parents of a 4-year-old boy presented to the psychiatric OPD with complaints that their son was not able to make friends easily, and liked to stay alone. He had difficulty completing sentences and never made eye contact. They had noticed a lack of social interaction in him since he was an infant. He also insisted on having the same food for dinner every day and would create a fuss if not provided with the same. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of early onset of the disease, lack of social interaction, impairment in social eye contact, and difficulty in maintaining and nurturing relationships suggests a diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder. 

Autism spectrum disorder, previously known as the pervasive developmental disorders, is a phenotypically heterogeneous group of neurodevelopmental syndromes with polygenic heritability, characterized by a wide range of impairments in social communication and restricted and repetitive behaviors. 

The characteristic features of Autism spectrum disorders, as per DSM-5, are:

* Persistent deficits in social communication (all three given below)

* A. Deficits in social-emotional reciprocity

* B. Deficits in non-verbal communicative behaviour, such as impairments in social eye contact

* C. Deficit in developing and maintaining relationships

* Restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior (2 of the following four symptoms)

* A. Stereotyped or repetitive speech, motor movements or use of objects

* B. Excessive adherence to a routine

* C. Highly restricted and fixated interests

* D. Hyper or hypo-reactivity to sensory input. 

* Symptoms must be present in early childhood

* Symptoms together limit and impair everyday function

* Symptoms not better explained by intellectual disability (intellectual developmental disorder) or global developmental delay

Other options: 

Option A: Rett’s syndrome is seen almost exclusively in girls, where deterioration of developmental milestones, head circumference, and overall growth occurs after 5 months of age. The absence of such a history of deterioration from previous normal development, along with the absence of other characteristic features of Rett's syndrome like stereotypic motions (hand wringing), poor coordination, ataxia, complete loss of verbal abilities, respiratory difficulties, and seizures, makes a diagnosis of Rett syndrome unlikely.

Option C: Tourette's syndrome is a neurobehavioral disorder characterized by sudden, rapid, recurrent, non-rhythmic motor movements and vocalizations, called tics. Vocal tics can be socially offensive, such as loud grunting, barking noises, or shouted words. Coprolalia may be seen, which refers to shouting or speaking socially unacceptable or obscene words.

Option D: Social Communication disorder is also known as Pragmatic Language Impairment and is a neurodevelopmental condition characterized by difficulties in using verbal and nonverbal communication for social purposes. Unlike Autism Spectrum Disorder, individuals with social communication disorder do not exhibit restricted or repetitive behaviors.

Intellectual disability Present in 30% of the cases Present Absent Present

NOTE: Rett's syndrome has been removed from DSM-5 because it was found to have a clear genetic basis.

questions.text: 198. You are working at an NGO eye hospital which provides affordable eye-care to people in need. Under the program whose logo is given below, NGO eye hospitals are considered ____________
questions.solution:
Under the National Programme for the Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCBVI), whose logo is shown above, NGO eye hospitals are considered secondary level.

The levels of eye care, according to NPCBVI are:

* Primary level: Sub-district level hospitals, community health centers, mobile ophthalmic units, upgraded PHCs, link workers, Panchayats.

* Secondary level: District hospitals, NGO eye hospitals

* Tertiary levels: Regional institutes of Ophthalmology, medical colleges.

questions.text: 199. A 30-year-old man presents with a shallow ulcer as shown on his left foot, which developed after rupture of a blister. Pain and swelling improved after immersing the affected foot in water. Which of the following is a feature of the causative agent likely involved in the patient’s pathogenesis?

choices.text: The adult worm resides in lymphoid tissue

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a person with an ulcer on the foot and pain subsiding on immersion in water, with the image showing a worm coming out of the ulcer, is representative of Guinea worm disease, which doesn't have an animal reservoir.

Dracunculus medinensis, also known as the 'serpent worm', is acquired by drinking unfiltered water containing infected cyclops (option A). Humans are the definitive host (option B). They get infected by the larvae that come out once the cyclops are killed in the stomach and penetrate the wall of the duodenum. 

They reach the retroperitoneal and subcutaneous connective tissues and develop into adults (option D). The fertilised female worm grows and migrates within the subcutaneous connective tissues. It reaches a site where it is likely to come into contact with water, like the leg (most common). Here, the gravid female worm secretes a toxin that causes blister formation. The blister ruptures, discharging a milky white fluid containing numerous L1-stage larvae.

The larvae survive for about a week in water. They are swallowed by the intermediate host, freshwater cyclops. The larvae penetrate the gut wall of the cyclops and develop into the infective third-stage larvae. The lifecycle continues when humans drink water containing infective cyclops.

The following image shows the life cycle of the guinea worm:

questions.text: 200. In which of the following conditions is this procedure avoided?
questions.solution:
The above image is of Hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT). It is absolutely contraindicated in an untreated pneumothorax. This is due to the risk of rapid expansion and tension pneumothorax during decompression.

HBOT is the administration of 100% oxygen at pressures greater than 1 atmosphere (usually 2–3 ATA) inside a hyperbaric chamber, which allows higher dissolved oxygen in plasma and improved tissue oxygen delivery.

It also enhances fibroblast and collagen activity for wound healing, reduces gas bubble size (Boyle’s law) in conditions like decompression sickness and air embolism, inhibits anaerobic bacterial growth, potentiates certain antibiotics, and augments neutrophil-mediated bacterial killing.

Some indications of Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy:

* Air or gas Embolism

* Decompression sickness (Option C)

* Poisoning—Carbon monoxide, cyanide (Option D)

* Infections—Clostridial myonecrosis, necrotizing soft tissue infections

* Crush Injury, compartment syndrome

* Compromised Skin flaps

* Intracranial abscess (Option A)

* Osteomyelitis (refractory to other therapy)

* Sudden sensorineural hearing loss
